reviewnospace: This place blows your mind, it's an iconic place of the city so it's a must see when in Valencia. The complex, designed by the wellknown valencian architect, Santiago Calatrava, lies on the dried bed of the river (which was diverted), and it's an impressive example of modern architecture. Be prepared to spend the whole day there because it's worth it. I would recommend getting the tickets online, in advance, on their official website.
titleopinion: Blows your mind!!. This place blows your mind, it's an iconic place of the city so it's a must see when in Valencia. The complex, designed by the wellknown valencian architect, Santiago Calatrava, lies on the dried bed of the river (which was diverted), and it's an impressive example of modern architecture. Be prepared to spend the whole day there because it's worth it. I would recommend getting the tickets online, in advance, on their official website.

reviewnospace: The buildlings themselves were absolutely breathtaking. I have never felt so involved as a spectator or viewer with contemporary architecture. The contrast between the blue sky and the white lines of the buildings and bridge was sublime. I went in February and the weather was around 24 degrees Celsius! I did not visit the inside of all the buildings, but I did visit the aquarium, which was cool. A must see in Valencia, as it is a great and interesting contrast against the Classical, Rococo and Baroque architecture of the city centre.
titleopinion: Stunning architecture. The buildlings themselves were absolutely breathtaking. I have never felt so involved as a spectator or viewer with contemporary architecture. The contrast between the blue sky and the white lines of the buildings and bridge was sublime. I went in February and the weather was around 24 degrees Celsius! I did not visit the inside of all the buildings, but I did visit the aquarium, which was cool. A must see in Valencia, as it is a great and interesting contrast against the Classical, Rococo and Baroque architecture of the city centre.

reviewnospace: This City of Arts and Sciences is one of the most impressive innovative buildings I've ever seen! It looks as if it is out of space. It has been designed by the famous Santiago Calatrava and Félix Candela. The water adds up to its mystical atmosphere. The complex consists of 7 buildings some of which are museums, concerts halls and tropical gardens. The Aquarium there is magnificent! The Opera House is stunning! I'd love to see an Opera performance there one day!

reviewnospace: this is a modern neighborhood of Valencia that I would actaully say is a cluster of buildings more than a neighborhood. my architect friends tell me the buildings are quite famous. the architect was a lover of nature and designed the buildings to mimic things from the natural world (a huge fish, for example). a feet of engineering, for sure. however, clearly they haven't had as much love and attention as they need -- peeling paint, etc. an interesting place to see but only for half an hour.

quote: A must see masterpiece in the heart of Valencia
reviewnospace:
The eastern end of the gorgeous 14km-long Turia garden park houses some of Valencia’s most identifiable landmarks. The City of Arts and Sciences, designed by world-renowned Valencian architect, Santiago Calatrava and Madrid’s Felix Candela, is a 2km long (approx.) archictectural masterpiece featuring an opera house, science centre, reflecting pool, aquarium and exhibition hall. The latter plays host to events like ATP Tennis and the MTV Europe music awards.

Rising 14 stories, the Calatrava-designed Palau de les Arts Reina Sofia is the tallest opera house in the world and resembles a giant warrior helmet. This is one of the most visually stimulating architectural features of this Spanish port.

Close to home, in addition to other notable structures the world over, Calatrava also designed the Allen Lambert Galleria in Brookfield Place, Toronto (see our GL facebook page) as well as the Mimico (pedestrian) Bridge over the Humber River.
titleopinion:
A must see masterpiece in the heart of Valencia. The eastern end of the gorgeous 14km-long Turia garden park houses some of Valencia’s most identifiable landmarks. The City of Arts and Sciences, designed by world-renowned Valencian architect, Santiago Calatrava and Madrid’s Felix Candela, is a 2km long (approx.) archictectural masterpiece featuring an opera house, science centre, reflecting pool, aquarium and exhibition hall. The latter plays host to events like ATP Tennis and the MTV Europe music awards.

Rising 14 stories, the Calatrava-designed Palau de les Arts Reina Sofia is the tallest opera house in the world and resembles a giant warrior helmet. This is one of the most visually stimulating architectural features of this Spanish port.

Close to home, in addition to other notable structures the world over, Calatrava also designed the Allen Lambert Galleria in Brookfield Place, Toronto (see our GL facebook page) as well as the Mimico (pedestrian) Bridge over the Humber River.

The exhibits were very ok but not worth the entrance fee. The cafeteria was being refurbished and some of the es alors were out of order. Not user friendly! We went to the shopping centre nearby for lunch - a bit of a walk but better than the small cafeteria we were directed to in the cinema.

I would recommend going on the VLC website, which is the tourist site and buy a combination ticket to all of these including the Bioparc and public transport, great savings and makes life easy.

reviewnospace: Buildings look fantastic from the outside. However, the science centre was poorly designed, a lot of empty spaces, badly timed exhibitions, no food facilities and really boring. Some exhibits had no translation. There are better things you can do with your €8 entry fee
titleopinion: Waste of time and money. Buildings look fantastic from the outside. However, the science centre was poorly designed, a lot of empty spaces, badly timed exhibitions, no food facilities and really boring. Some exhibits had no translation. There are better things you can do with your €8 entry fee

reviewnospace: The design of this complex is unbelievable, and even the best photographs can not beat seeing it for yourself. Rent a bike, cycle through the lovely park to this complex and then continue to the beach if you want. Take your time and enjoy Valencia!
titleopinion: Go just for the architecture. The design of this complex is unbelievable, and even the best photographs can not beat seeing it for yourself. Rent a bike, cycle through the lovely park to this complex and then continue to the beach if you want. Take your time and enjoy Valencia!

reviewnospace: Great place to spend a day. So much to see and do and learn about. Wonderful facility for all ages to enjoy.
titleopinion: Incredible!. Great place to spend a day. So much to see and do and learn about. Wonderful facility for all ages to enjoy.

reviewnospace: Went twice. Once via a bike tour and once to take sunset / evening photos. Check on google for the subset tines. When I went it was slightly windy. We are told that wind occurs March /April. Why mention this. Simply because if you want the best reflections the water needs to be still. You need to walk all around to assess the best views for your shot. Don't t miss the tall bridge at the end. There is a bike hire at the end of the complex. Also along the terrace artists do a display. Currently looks like a collection of thin totem poles. Not my taste but good to allow the displays. If you want to go inside the buildings there are various combinations. Just need to check them.
titleopinion: Great architecture . Went twice. Once via a bike tour and once to take sunset / evening photos. Check on google for the subset tines. When I went it was slightly windy. You need to walk all around to assess the best views for your shot. Don't t miss the tall bridge at the end. There is a bike hire at the end of the complex. Also along the terrace artists do a display. Currently looks like a collection of thin totem poles. Not my taste but good to allow the displays. If you want to go inside the buildings there are various combinations. Just need to check them.

reviewnospace: very modern over the top buildings, steel & concrete, many many photo opportunities, didn`t have time to go inside, the aquarium is expensive so you need plenty of time for your visit.

reviewnospace: We were unsure if this would be good for young children but it was. The place is beautiful and there is lots to do. We had booked the Oceanographic and the Cinema too. We saw the showing of a million stars. This was amazing. It really felt like you were in space. It was very interesting and really enjoyable. Our son commented on how he was going to tell his friends he went to space on his holidays.

If you're visiting Valencia, you have to visit the city of Arts ans Sience.

reviewnospace: Futuristic and awe inspiring. An incredible architectural feat. This is a photographers dream. Stroll along the old riverbed (now a park) & take in the views as you get there. The exhibitions are so-so and I think just wandering around outside is way better.

reviewnospace: Probably one of the greatest attractions in Valencia, besides old town and the beach. This could easily be "federation hq" in the future :-) loved everything about it!

quote: The building is amazing, the exhibitions could improve
reviewnospace: We paid a brief visit one Saturday and while the building is amazing from outside, inside the space is not so well used. The exhibitions we saw were partly interesting, partly not so well done - some objects were out of order, couldn't try them. It's a shame they don't repair them. The price is also too high.

reviewnospace: Valencia is an absolutely charming place, gorgeous mixes of old and new - all with a rather friendly cosmopolitan twist. There is a lot to see so hiring a scooter is really worthwhile. The architecture is stunning and I wish it had been completed when we were there. Nightlife is excellent. Overall this place is a real winner.

Overall this place is a real winner.

reviewnospace:
Amazing architecture set in a tranquil and beautiful setting.

Science museum is good although it didn't have as many exhibits as I was expecting.
titleopinion:
Spectacular. Amazing architecture set in a tranquil and beautiful setting.

Science museum is good although it didn't have as many exhibits as I was expecting.

reviewnospace:
This is something honestly out of this world, made me feel like something you would see at Disneyworld. It is huge, and worth to go and see. We were going to go into one of the museums but we didn't have the time. We walked around it and saw some amazing scenery and buildings. Looks like spaceships. Its free to walk around outside.

The arquitect is the same one as the "Turning Torso" in Malmo, Swe. Worth a google search.

Then the movie Tomorrowland(2015) was filmed here.
titleopinion:
The city of the future.. This is something honestly out of this world, made me feel like something you would see at Disneyworld. It is huge, and worth to go and see. reviewnospace: I was looking forward to this museum but it proved to be a big disappointment. I think that is because it was very fragmented and I found it difficult to follow. It is a large airy light space on several levels with zones for the various exhibits. Many of the hands on activities were not working and there were lots of school groups in so it was quite noisy. The cafe was not open so we had to eat outside and it was a very cold day so not a pleasant experience. Overall it did nothing for me but I am sure others will love it.
titleopinion: Disappointing!. I was looking forward to this museum but it proved to be a big disappointment. I think that is because it was very fragmented and I found it difficult to follow. It is a large airy light space on several levels with zones for the various exhibits. Many of the hands on activities were not working and there were lots of school groups in so it was quite noisy. The cafe was not open so we had to eat outside and it was a very cold day so not a pleasant experience. Overall it did nothing for me but I am sure others will love it.

reviewnospace: Loved it! Didn't have much time to visit inside but everytime we passed infront of it I made its picture from different angles. Never seen anything like it, so extraordinary!!!

reviewnospace:
The buildings of the City of Arts and Sciences are a beautiful architectural masterpiece. The pools are beautiful around them too.

When I went here, the Oceanografic was closed (disappointed) and there wasn't as much to do round here as I thought there might have been - although I wasn;t sure what I expected. We saw the models that had been made for the Fallas (?) festival, which was interesting.

Most of the place seemed closed or out of action. February is probably not the best time to go to somewhere like this. I expect there would be a bit more to do around the summer time.

Probably more enjoyable for families with kids.
titleopinion:
Great buildings.... The buildings of the City of Arts and Sciences are a beautiful architectural masterpiece. The pools are beautiful around them too.

When I went here, the Oceanografic was closed (disappointed) and there wasn't as much to do round here as I thought there might have been - although I wasn;t sure what I expected. We saw the models that had been made for the Fallas (?) festival, which was interesting.

Most of the place seemed closed or out of action. February is probably not the best time to go to somewhere like this. I expect there would be a bit more to do around the summer time.

reviewnospace: The basic concept is parklands in the middle of the city containing half a dozen or so fabulous blue and white buildings surrounded by water feature. The Architecture is wonderful. Make the trip if you have any interest in architecture. Plenty of on street parking. Suprisingly peaceful for the middle of a city.
titleopinion: Truely Spectacular. The basic concept is parklands in the middle of the city containing half a dozen or so fabulous blue and white buildings surrounded by water feature. The Architecture is wonderful. Make the trip if you have any interest in architecture. Plenty of on street parking. Suprisingly peaceful for the middle of a city.

reviewnospace: Unless you have young children that would like the interactive exhibits, I would not waste your time. Half of the exhibits seemed to be broken anyways, so even children may get bored. The only items that seemed interesting (space academy, zero gravity, etc.) needed separate tickets that had be purchased in addition to the museum fee.
titleopinion: Don't Waste Your Time. Unless you have young children that would like the interactive exhibits, I would not waste your time. reviewnospace: There is an admission cost to the museums, but if you don't fancy paying this, just to walk around the buildings and water pools is fascinating in itself. The architecture is a feast for the eyes, though why do all modern architects have such a fascination with armadillos? You can hire clear plastic boats to paddle around the ponds which looks such fun. Also, there are zorbs you can hire.

reviewnospace:
I'm a creative so i was attracted by the architecture but the exhibits themselves were nothing special. If this is the most accessible arts and science compound by all means enjoy it. I'm a "you'll regret it later kind of guy" so we had to get the full experience. I mean, why not its just time and some money.

Do i regret spending the time and money? Of course not. Pendulum exhibit was neat.

Would i do it again? No way.

Should you do it? Sure, if you want to.


if you decide to visit make sure to wear comfortable walking shoes.

reviewnospace: Have just spent the whole day at this place, taking in a 3D film of the Valencian Fallas and just a small part of the great, and really interactive Museum of Sciences. You could return to this museum time and time again, as one visit really doesn't do it justice.

reviewnospace: We visited the Science museum as the Oceanagrafica was closed for a refurb.! We were a bit disappointed at first, the place was full of youngsters who beat us to all the exhibits, but on going up one level it improved a lot and there were quite a few interesting hands-on exhibits. we would have preferred the aquarium, but did quite enjoy the museum.

reviewnospace: Decided to visit Valencia when we were in Spain last year and saw the CITY OF ARTS AND CULTURE advertised. We intended to visit all the possible sections of this enormous attraction, but ended up spending some 8 hour in the Oceanographic exhibition. This is a permanent exhibition of Ocean life and is probably 20 times the size of the Sealife places in the UK. If you have any interest AT ALL in the creatures of the sea then this is not to be missed. The exhibition is divided into various sections such as Arctic, Red Sea, Deep Ocean Tropical etc brilliant for all the family

reviewnospace: Especially when the sun is shining, it is nice to go here and just walk around. The buildings are enormous and there's a nice park to rest and relax somewhat. From the city centre you can take the bus (19) for 1,50 euros to get there. Especially nice if you want to visit the beach as well, as it is on the way from Valencia to the beach. I would only go here if you have enough time to also see the city centre, though.

reviewnospace:
This is a must see free admission place that is visited by all of the guided tours with space for thousands of visitors daily. They have a one way in and out visitor’s lot that allows a large number of tour buses to park right next to the sidewalks. Just be sure you remember which bus is yours as there are many that look similar.

The buildings are architectural wonders that will amaze you all in one giant complex. Each building is unique and will surprise you with the way they were constructed and the fascinating details that went into each one. The picture taking opportunities are endless as you walk around the huge blue water pond in the middle that is surrounded by all of the attractions including the Opera House, the IMAX theater, the Aquarium and the Arts and Science Buildings. Tour guides were very busy taking pictures of tourists together as were the tourists taking thousands of pictures at one time.

The Bottom Line:
This is the best free attraction I have ever seen with buildings and picture taking opportunities that will amaze you and provide memories of a lifetime. They have the tour bus parking down with a huge lot that allows a large number of people to easily enjoy the attraction at the same time.
titleopinion:
Amazing Buildings and Picture Opportunities. This is a must see free admission place that is visited by all of the guided tours with space for thousands of visitors daily. reviewnospace:
Amazing buildings from the outside and well worth a look.
If you walk from the Old Part of Town, lets say from the Plaza del la Virgin through the Turia River bed that is now a park it should take you about an hour to get there at a relaxed pace. It will also take about an hour to look around the outside which is free.
I don't recommend you buy a ticket and go inside the building exhibits if you are on a budget as it can be expensive and really the main interest is the building design.
Tip. On the outside of the science museum there is a large arch, if you stand at one end and the friend stands at the other and you talk you can hear each other clearly.

reviewnospace:
The architecture is beautiful, stunning and a must see in Valencia. I can recommend to go there during sunset. Then the buildings are the most beautiful. Then you can go for dinner in the neighboring Rusaffa neighborhood and come back for a show in the opera or drinks in the Umbracle nightclub.

I would not recommend the science museum. It is old, dated and badly maintained.

Great architecture. The architecture is beautiful, stunning and a must see in Valencia. I can recommend to go there during sunset. Then the buildings are the most beautiful. Then you can go for dinner in the neighboring Rusaffa neighborhood and come back for a show in the opera or drinks in the Umbracle nightclub.

I would not recommend the science museum. It is old, dated and badly maintained.

reviewnospace:
Even if you are not interested in architecture you will be fascinated and amazed by these examples of Santiago Calatrava's designs. The make you think what a feat of engineering that designs such as this can even stand!
The only buildings we truly went into were in the Oceanografic, but enjoyed walking the length of the buildings and through the accessible part of the Umbracle, and its palm trees. We understand the sealed section of the Umbracle is now used as an amazing night club. Alongside it we understand there are regularly displays from various artists.
As it was just after Christmas, on our walk under the Umbracle we encountered a little artisan Christmas market with amazing foods, gift items and even an entertainment area for small children.

Although the city was free to walk around, there are charges if you want to go into the aquarium. Easily accessible from the city centre by bus.

reviewnospace:
While in Valencia I had to see this- I had heard about it as a lavish spending project that overtook common sense. As I heard the story- political leaders, who also influenced boards of local financial institutions, received funding for a huge range of bigger-than-life civil infrastructure projects to make Valencia even better. Now the city has more beautiful monuments, albeit underused, and debt and interest and maintenance costs when least affordable.

The buildings are located in the former river bed of the river Turia, which was redirected following a series of floods, with the 1957 flood empowering the Spanish government to decide to redirect the river. The river bed offers a great location- central, yet spacious.

The buildings are all modern, large and expansive and contrast to the old-town an easy walk away. The scene is very photogenic, but few people are around and it gives a quiet feeling. We stopped for a coffee, almost alone, outdoors.

With more time- we would like to check out the museums and oceanographic park, and listen to a concert. More time required. We instead walked to the beach for a beautiful meal.
titleopinion:
Looks great, quite the story. While in Valencia I had to see this- I had heard about it as a lavish spending project that overtook common sense. As I heard the story- political leaders, who also influenced boards of local financial institutions, received funding for a huge range of bigger-than-life civil infrastructure projects to make Valencia even better. Now the city has more beautiful monuments, albeit underused, and debt and interest and maintenance costs when least affordable.

The buildings are located in the former river bed of the river Turia, which was redirected following a series of floods, with the 1957 flood empowering the Spanish government to decide to redirect the river. The river bed offers a great location- central, yet spacious.

The buildings are all modern, large and expansive and contrast to the old-town an easy walk away. The scene is very photogenic, but few people are around and it gives a quiet feeling. We stopped for a coffee, almost alone, outdoors.

With more time- we would like to check out the museums and oceanographic park, and listen to a concert. More time required. We instead walked to the beach for a beautiful meal.

quote: Wonderful !!! Wish we had more time
reviewnospace:
Be sure to plan your visit very well ahead because there are so many things to see and you will need at least one full day .

Bring your kids with you .

Work of the Valencian architect Santiago Calatrava is amazing !!! It is a scientific and cultural leisure complex which can be enjoyed with family or friends, covering around two kilometres.

A must when you are in Valencia . Don't miss it .

quote: The Cuidad de las Artes y las Ciencias Will Definitely Wow You
reviewnospace: This is a complex that any city in the word would be proud of, but it is not anywhere else, it is in Valencia! This collection of futuristic buildings housing, among other things, the finest aquarium in Europe, a first class science museum, and a performing arts center is an excellent reason to come to Valencia all by itself. It is much like Bilbao's Museo Guggenheim - the product is excellent, but the packaging is awesome! You need to see it to believe it.

reviewnospace: We visited Valencia while on a cruise. We took a private excursion with Spain Day Tours. When the van pulled up close to this ultra modern group of buildings, it was jaw dropping. It was so unexpected in what most people think of as the old world city of Valencia. Valencia isn't old world anymore. It is a great addition to a city that has so much to see and do. I would love to be able to visit the interior of these buildings; but that would take a land trip and a few days stay. If you don't have the time, at least check out the lovely exterior's. Everyone thinks Wow when they see them.

reviewnospace:
This particular science museum is somewhat structured and pretty well needs to be visited from top down, covering climate and communication to gravity and geology to space; the second floor down deals with Spanish Nobel prize winners; below that we are back to earth or almost, including the nitty gritty of molecules... On the ground floor we find mostly TV and media studios.
The exhibits are of wide spectrum and often one day is not enough to go from top to bottom, unless you just walk non-stop. But if you want to learn, to see and to experience, go for the gust and come back the next day.
Some of the hands-on exhibits are challenging and sometimes there have been hands at work trying to figure out how it works by dismantling, something I have observed also in other European hands-on exhibits. I suspect the cause to be parents who are themselves so intrigued by the exhibits that children are left unsupervised... There are also some very special exhibits which require additional entrance fees like the space academy or th Theatre of electricity.
While the top floor deals mostly with physics, the lower floors deal more with humanity and geology, I could not take all in due to time constraints. If the top was an indication, these too, were excellent exhibits. All of the lower floor events require additional fees between 3 and 4 Euros.
titleopinion:
Hands-on yes, but.... quote: A breathtaking, gobsmacking journey into the future.

Then you enter into the exhibition halls, which are astounding. The exhibitions are in mainly in Spanish, English, French and German, so understanding is easy. We saw one about communications, the Body and Spanish scientists. Brilliant!

The price is reasonable considering the amount available to see and it is not as far to walk as it looks on the map down the dry river bed.

quote: Must see, but from the outside
reviewnospace:
As a big fan of Calatrava's buildings I was excited to visit the City of Arts and Sciences in Valencia.
Architectures are amazing from all points of view, and the group of buildings could be observed for hours discovering interesting features and details.
We visited the museum of sciences, to have a flavor of what is inside, but were a bit disappointed: some stands are placed in the huge hall apparently without a logical order, and contents are not really amazing. I had the impression that there is quite a bit of everything related to science, but with no real focus.

You would need a 3-4 hours to see and try everything, a few of the items were not working which was a shame, most of the exhibitions are in several languages, but some of the instructions on how to use them were only in Spanish, would definetly recommend if you have children and the weather isn't to good.

quote: Interesting but not "knock your socks off"
reviewnospace: The science museum is a nice diversion for a few hours, but much of it is not translated into English and probably 25% of the hands-on exhibits were not working. The current display about communication (televisions, radios, telegraph machines) is pretty cool. The human body displays are interesting and informative. But honestly, for me, the highlight of the museum is the architecture of the building, not the stuff inside.
titleopinion: Interesting but not "knock your socks off". The science museum is a nice diversion for a few hours, but much of it is not translated into English and probably 25% of the hands-on exhibits were not working. The current display about communication (televisions, radios, telegraph machines) is pretty cool. The human body displays are interesting and informative. But honestly, for me, the highlight of the museum is the architecture of the building, not the stuff inside.

reviewnospace: I'd read the reviews and planned to visit, but didn't expect anything special. However me and my partner absolutely loved it here. Just walking around is nice. I felt like I was on the set of a Star Wars film. The nearby park makes for a great walk also. We liked this part of town so much that we came back to see it at night and then returned another day.

quote: Most exhibits not working, only real interest was the architecture
reviewnospace:
Very disappointing. After trekking out here and having to be redirected twice to find an entrance (I think because they were preparing for a tennis tournament) we eventually paid to get in and walked back to the escalators to the first floor.

Most of the exhibitions on this floor that had working exhibits seemed a bit disjointed and many of the rest were only in Spanish.

The second floor, which on the face of it had a more interesting range of exhibits about life and the human body, had even fewer working exhibits.

By the time we got to the telephony, TV and space exhibitions at the top we were too bored to really take in much, although it didn't help that we started at the wrong end and found our selves working back through inventions across the ages!

reviewnospace: The architecture of this array, consisting of an Imax cinema, opera house and a science museum, is breathtaking. But the science museum contents are very dull and unimaginative: nowhere near the standard of the Science Museum in London, or the Smithsonian. It needs a total re-think to make the most of a fabulous space. As for the opera: when we visted, there was nothing on, sadly.

It needs a total re-think to make the most of a fabulous space. As for the opera: when we visted, there was nothing on, sadly.

reviewnospace: After checking into our hotel close to the City of Arts and Sciences we did a two part tour--the first to see the cite and the second to visit the downtown. Our local guide was excellent in giving us the history of the location and the flood of 1957 that eventually led to rerouting the river and the 10 plus years it took to construct the various buildings. My disappointment was not having the time to see the insides of at least one of the strutures. I really like the art on the walkway across from the L'Hemisferic. Our guide recommended coming back after dark when the wind would de down and see the reflections in the ponds. We did and they were wonderful. The downtown is interesting in part because of the attempts to save many of the older building facades. There we numerous building that fit into the architecture but had a new insides. Every one at least once should she what can be done too renovate an area and rebuild using outstanding architects.

quote: Don't miss this fantastic photo opportunity!
reviewnospace: Only a 10-15 minute bus ride from the city centre, the various buildings and their setting, make for some great photos. Make sure you also go when it is dark to capture the illuminated images. fantastic!
titleopinion: Don't miss this fantastic photo opportunity!. Only a 10-15 minute bus ride from the city centre, the various buildings and their setting, make for some great photos. Make sure you also go when it is dark to capture the illuminated images. fantastic!

reviewnospace: Everything is amazing about this place, starting from the fact that it is built in the former river canal. It is grandiose, we haven't imagined this complex would be so huge. It was a beautiful sunny day so we decided not to enter (OK, we took also into account the relatively high ticket prices), but to walk and explore all corners and paths. And it was incredible! Each building has its own and unique architectonic peculiarity which is developed to perfection. Combined with the lines of palm trees, they make for an almost fairy-like atmosphere. Not many cities in Europe can offer this sort of experience. If you have time and are interested in science and oceanography, I can only imagine how interesting the museums are on the inside! So, a bit of advise to the future visitors: wear comfortable shoes, if it's warm bring some water, bring the camera and enjoy! This place will definitely stay carved in your memory for a long time....

reviewnospace: The City of Arts and Sciences in Valencia is a unique complex devoted to scientific and cultural dissemination In Europe. which is made up of five main elements: the Hemisfèric (IMAX cinema and digital projections), the Umbracle (a landscaped vantage point and car park), the Príncipe Felipe Science Museum (an innovative centre of interactive science), the Oceanográfico (the largest aquarium in Europe with over 500 marine species) and the Palau de les Arts Reina Sofía (which takes care of the operatic programme). The Ágora gives the complex a multifunctional space
titleopinion: High light of the city. The City of Arts and Sciences in Valencia is a unique complex devoted to scientific and cultural dissemination In Europe. which is made up of five main elements: the Hemisfèric (IMAX cinema and digital projections), the Umbracle (a landscaped vantage point and car park), the Príncipe Felipe Science Museum (an innovative centre of interactive science), the Oceanográfico (the largest aquarium in Europe with over 500 marine species) and the Palau de les Arts Reina Sofía (which takes care of the operatic programme). reviewnospace: During our working visit to valencia we visited the city of art and science. We were reallt impressed with this place. Very interesting and a must see once on valencia
titleopinion: Short visit in valencia. During our working visit to valencia we visited the city of art and science. We were reallt impressed with this place. Very interesting and a must see once on valencia

reviewnospace:
If you are interested in photography this is a great place to visit. The Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias is one of the best urban areas in Europe for photography. The buildings are visually interesting at all scales and there are no tripod police. When I was there in October 2015, the Palau de las Artes Reina Sofia was undergoing some external refurbishment with cranes present during the day and some blotches of cement on the structure where the tiles were being replaced. And although there are supposed to be 2 tours (11.30 and 13.00) every day, I waited outside on three days for a guided visit of the building without success - you need to work on your communication skills Palau de las Artes!!!

Other than that, I spent a lot of time early morning and late afternoon/sunset around the buildings taking photographs. I was happy with what I came away with and also very much enjoyed the ambience of the city and it's people. I would definitely recommend Valencia and the Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias as a destination for those looking for photographic holiday.
titleopinion:
City of Arts and Sciences. If you are interested in photography this is a great place to visit. The Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias is one of the best urban areas in Europe for photography. The buildings are visually interesting at all scales and there are no tripod police. When I was there in October 2015, the Palau de las Artes Reina Sofia was undergoing some external refurbishment with cranes present during the day and some blotches of cement on the structure where the tiles were being replaced. And although there are supposed to be 2 tours (11.30 and 13.00) every day, I waited outside on three days for a guided visit of the building without success - you need to work on your communication skills Palau de las Artes!!!

Other than that, I spent a lot of time early morning and late afternoon/sunset around the buildings taking photographs. I was happy with what I came away with and also very much enjoyed the ambience of the city and it's people. I would definitely recommend Valencia and the Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias as a destination for those looking for photographic holiday.

reviewnospace: We rented a bicycle in the center and in about 10 minutes we arrived at the site. (a lot of rentals in the historic center, but some of them were sold out, so if you are sure you want to do this, I would suggest to book in advance!) This is a wonderful way to visit because it is huge and you can easily get around. We were not really interested in the museums, but the architecture is amazing. I have seen Calatrava buildings elsewhere, but here you have a whole site. This makes it unique! You have not been to Valencia if you did not see this!

quote: Top place to visit in Valencia
reviewnospace:
This place provides an expansive amount of knowledge and hands on experiences of the sciences.
On the top floor it has a permanent exhibition of genome science, how our genes effect us all or the lack of them. One could spend hours here and be fascinated and educated in this fast growing area of medical science. There are other science areas such as communications throughout the ages etc.
All are housed I n a magnificent park with stunning architecture, small lakes and a completely pedestrianized area.

Top place to visit in Valencia. This place provides an expansive amount of knowledge and hands on experiences of the sciences.
On the top floor it has a permanent exhibition of genome science, how our genes effect us all or the lack of them. One could spend hours here and be fascinated and educated in this fast growing area of medical science. There are other science areas such as communications throughout the ages etc.
All are housed I n a magnificent park with stunning architecture, small lakes and a completely pedestrianized area.

reviewnospace: Great architecture - very unique and space age. Among the main attractions are the science museum. the oceanarium and the hemispheric (IMAX theatre). I visited the first two. Lot's of fun hands-on activities in the science museum. The oceanarium has a "sea world" type of arena and lots of large aquariums with all kinds of sea life. The area is easily accessible by regular bus service from the city. Takes about 15-20 minutes or so.
titleopinion: Good place to visit. Great architecture - very unique and space age. Among the main attractions are the science museum. the oceanarium and the hemispheric (IMAX theatre). reviewnospace: Very futurist and awe inspiring, as a seasoned traveller its rare something stands out like this does, for a moment it almost feels like you have jumped 100 years into the future.
titleopinion: Awe inspiring. Very futurist and awe inspiring, as a seasoned traveller its rare something stands out like this does, for a moment it almost feels like you have jumped 100 years into the future.

reviewnospace:
Visited Valencia for the F1 three years ago and walking to the track was wow'd by the sights of this along the way.
First chance to revisit 2015 and have time to explore and appreciate the sights. Visiting Alicante a day trip to Valencia was most definitely on the cards.
Parked in the shopping centre opposite the attraction and didn't realise there was dedicated parking onsite, underground parking.
Overall spent 1-1.5 hours wandering round enjoying the modern architecture and taking snaps. Would recommend walking all the way round and over the bridge to fully take in the enormity and perspective of all the building. Stunning. Places to have a drink and some light bites. The sun was splitting the trees, not too hot and not a cloud in the Sky made it a perfect day. I love buildings and architecture without being too serious about it and for that reason love this place. Hope I can come back in the future. Right up there for me from everything I have seen on my travels.
26/09/15 YB Alicante

quote: Space Age or other worldly? An incredible triumph in modern architecture!
reviewnospace:

I would say this was a must visit in Valencia.

reviewnospace:
Whilst walking around Valencia, I came upon the City of Arts and Sciences by accident even though i intended to visit. It was later in the evening so everything had closed and they were setting up for a wedding. It is like arriving on a different planet and I was amazed by the architecture, the white mosaic and the way it lit up even when it was getting dark.

I went back the next day and we took a clear/perspex boat out on the pools which was just amazing and very reasonably priced.

It is definitely a must see for anyone visiting Valencia.. Loved it

reviewnospace: This is something that everyone needs to see if you are visiting Valencia! What a wonderful experience. We walked from the city center and saw many things along the way. There was also music venues in two different areas.

reviewnospace: The architecture of the CAS was the best part of the visit. We paid for a two day ticket that included the Oceanografic and a show at the Hemisferic. The science exhibits were ok. I personally think that the Science Centers that I have visited in other cities were much better. We were tired from all of the walking around and ended up missing the start time of our movie by about 10 minutes. We had to rebook but in the end we missed that also because it was too late. We paid over 100 euros for the two day pass for a family of four and in the end I did not think that it was worth it.

reviewnospace:
I took fast train from Madrid -left at 8 am returned after11 pm. Visited the old part via double deck bus and on foot, but also wanted to go to the beach. There are two lines in the double deck bus red( old town) and yellow (modern part) -you can use both in the same price. Yellow will take you to the amazing modern structures designed by Calatrava (the same who designed Milwaukee Art Museum amongst other structures in the USA). My destination was the beach but saw the structures on my way- amazing!
consider your timing- we took taxi from the beach to get back to train- make sure you mention what train station... (about $15)- best option.
While you are in Valencia try horchata (xorchata) drink. :) is different than Mexican -if you are familiar with it... Have fun!
titleopinion:
One day in Valencia. I took fast train from Madrid -left at 8 am returned after11 pm. Visited the old part via double deck bus and on foot, but also wanted to go to the beach. There are two lines in the double deck bus red( old town) and yellow (modern part) -you can use both in the same price. Yellow will take you to the amazing modern structures designed by Calatrava (the same who designed Milwaukee Art Museum amongst other structures in the USA). My destination was the beach but saw the structures on my way- amazing!
consider your timing- we took taxi from the beach to get back to train- make sure you mention what train station... (about $15)- best option.
While you are in Valencia try horchata (xorchata) drink. :) is different than Mexican -if you are familiar with it... Have fun!

quote: The place to be in Valencia: a staple
reviewnospace: If you have not visited this you have not visited Valencia. First of all this marvel of architecture is located on an old river bed, the old Turia river. In the nineties they started building several major architectural buildings by the Spanish architect and engineer Santiago Calatrava. There is a science museum, a film theatre and a opera house. Later there were two more but these three are the most important ones. You can visit all three easily and not too expensive. I recommend starting with science museum and afterwards going to see a special movie. There are combi tickets including two or more attractions. Do not forget to also take a canoe on the pools next to the science museum: it is great fun, specially when it is summer time. You can take some very nice pictures here. Also to be visited during night time.
titleopinion: The place to be in Valencia: a staple. If you have not visited this you have not visited Valencia. First of all this marvel of architecture is located on an old river bed, the old Turia river. In the nineties they started building several major architectural buildings by the Spanish architect and engineer Santiago Calatrava. There is a science museum, a film theatre and a opera house. Later there were two more but these three are the most important ones. You can visit all three easily and not too expensive. I recommend starting with science museum and afterwards going to see a special movie. There are combi tickets including two or more attractions. Do not forget to also take a canoe on the pools next to the science museum: it is great fun, specially when it is summer time. You can take some very nice pictures here. Also to be visited during night time.

reviewnospace:
I spent a day and a half to have an extended relaxing week-end with my family. The balance is reasonably positive, but I found CAC somehow overvalued.

At first glance, it is a breath-taking piece of architecture, worth of a visit if you are in Valencia.

Museum of Sciences is not so rich in expos but shows an articulated view across many subjects. Not my preferred actually but good enough to spend 3 hours with some nice experiment. If you have a kids, there is a dedicated area where they can spend their energies: I recommend to do it to break the visit.

Oceanografico, the largest acquarium in Europe, was a delusion. It is a large actually, and with a perfect weather (you spend most of time outdoor) as we had and not much crowd is enjoyable. However, the number of real acquaria was incredibly low, let's say two dozens. The best have been Arctic and Antarctic (my first penguins and beluga), delphinarium was good, but the rest falls very short from Barcelona. With no much crowds and taking it VERY easy (including lunch), it was over in less than 4 hours.

Emispherico hosts an iMax cinema, that is always well spent time, just book well in advance your ticket.

I strongly recommend online booking, as you can secure your seats for the right spectacle at Emispherico and save some money.
titleopinion:

quote: Oceanografic is astonishing, Hemisferic is fairly good
reviewnospace: We loved the City of Arts and Sciences, especially the Oceanografic. We spent nearly an entire day there, being especially fascinated by the underground vaults surrounded by aquariums, including sharks. The Hemisferic is a bit outdated, but still a worthy visit. I recommend watching a non-3D movie, even if you are with kids, because only the 2D ones use the entire screen. In the end, we skipped the science museum to spend more time in the Oceanografic, but I guess that was a wise decision, as I heard from others that the museum is not as good.

reviewnospace:
The City of Arts and Sciences complex is visually stunning and such an asset to the beautiful city of Valencia. It seems Calatrava is like marmite and I fall firmly in the love him category. It is enough just to wander the site taking in the awesome structures that look as though they've materialised from another world.

I bought a combined ticket for the Science Museum, the Oceanografic and the Hemisferic for me and my son which wiith hindsight was a mistake. There is so much to see and do (although the quality of the science exhibits was variable and the exhibitions change over time) and we felt we would have been far better off doing a two day tour as the Oceanografic warrants a day on it's own.

The Hemisferic has the potential to be spectacular with it's IMAX cinema in the centre but the film we saw was disappointing and I slept through most of it! Surrounding the Hemisferic there is a large body of water where you can hire a boat or a Zorb Ball which looked great fun.

Room for improvement but all in all a big thumbs up.
titleopinion:

Room for improvement but all in all a big thumbs up.

Out of this world!. A really wonderful place, you can take pictures, walk or just relax looking at this beauty. But there are also a lot of things to do, there's a big aquarium, one of the newest and biggest in Europe, there's hemisferic (imax) and science museum.
Make sure you don't miss it!

reviewnospace: Architecture is stunning but there wasn't much else. Seems more like a science centre than a tourist attraction. Would have been good if there was an exihibition of Spain's modern arts and science. Have to go on a sunny cloudless day to get good pictures.
titleopinion: Avante garde architecture. Architecture is stunning but there wasn't much else. Seems more like a science centre than a tourist attraction. Would have been good if there was an exihibition of Spain's modern arts and science. Have to go on a sunny cloudless day to get good pictures.

reviewnospace: We didn't go inside, but just walking around here, seeing the architecture is great. Haven't seen anything like this before!
titleopinion: Nice place. We didn't go inside, but just walking around here, seeing the architecture is great. Haven't seen anything like this before!

reviewnospace: This seemed more like a learning center for children interested in science than something a tourist would like to do. But it was raining so ...

reviewnospace: We went through the aquarium to start, which is certainly worth the price of the ticket for the first time you travel to Valencia. It's a lovely few hours of sea life viewing as well as enjoying the architecture. Afterwards, we walked around the rest of the buildings to take it all in and wow, it's really an incredible experience. The architecture is truly innovative and it's something everyone should enjoy and not just architects or designers. Highly recommend!

reviewnospace: It's an amazing newly built area with contemporary beautiful artistic constructions. Lots of activity are happening there. The opera, exhibitions and the aquarium are all there. reviewnospace:
Begining with the wonderful architecture and continuing with all the experiments you can try in the Science museum, the different species of fish at the Oceanografic, and a pleasent walk in the Umbracle, the City of Arts and Science is simply wow in my opinion.
It's a must go in Valencia. I spent here arround 2 days, the first in the science museum and seeing a film in the Hemisferic. The other one at the Oceanografic. Loved it!

reviewnospace: Started in the aquarium. Very well laid out. Differnt oceans, all undergound connected by plexiglass tunnels. Reasonably priced cafe and a very expensive restaurant. In the science section, sepereate tickets for science center and Space academy. Also has a museum that rotates different themes. Pixar was the theme when I went. Story bords and clay sculpures for the artists to go by. Really interesting. To do it all and really enjoy it, plan for the whole day. The Tour bus stops there so you can pick it up anytime to get back.

A pity the city is not yet completed; still, it looks fantastic. And despite all the Spanish brightness and sunlight, it is quite cool inside.

reviewnospace:
This place is a must see, if in Valencia. It's pretty unique and reminded me of the Opera structure in Sydney. At night they also have the dolphin show which we missed.

Overall an awesome attraction in the middle of the city!

reviewnospace: Never seen anything like it. Unique architecture. Sadly, building was abruptly stopped due to the economic crisis. A must-see if you visit Valencia.
titleopinion: Futuristic and unique. Never seen anything like it. Unique architecture. Sadly, building was abruptly stopped due to the economic crisis. A must-see if you visit Valencia.

reviewnospace: The building is wonderful - huge, modern and spacious. Lots of interactive exhibits, information in English and Spanish. The DNA and Space exhibits very interesting. The Space Academy on the 3rd Floor worth the extra Euro 2,50 , buy the ticket when you go in and book a time - otherwise you have to trek down to the entry to buy a ticket like I did. There are two English tours of the Space Academy a day, we went on the Spanish one anyway and got by. Not exactly a wild ride, but the taking off and landing simulation is good. This is more of a interactive/ discovery type centre, don't expect to see old cars, planes, trains and machines because there aren't any. Great fun anyway, one of Valencia's more cost effective venues. Spent most of the day there. You can exit to eat and go back in without any problem.
titleopinion: Great fun and interesting too. The building is wonderful - huge, modern and spacious. Lots of interactive exhibits, information in English and Spanish. The DNA and Space exhibits very interesting. The Space Academy on the 3rd Floor worth the extra Euro 2,50 , buy the ticket when you go in and book a time - otherwise you have to trek down to the entry to buy a ticket like I did. There are two English tours of the Space Academy a day, we went on the Spanish one anyway and got by. Not exactly a wild ride, but the taking off and landing simulation is good. Great fun anyway, one of Valencia's more cost effective venues. Spent most of the day there. You can exit to eat and go back in without any problem.

reviewnospace: Simply amazing complex. Architecturally "off the charts" it has to be seen to be believed. We did the Oceanographic section in detail and jus loved the experience...its a must do. So much to see, experience and enjoy, wow.

reviewnospace: When visiting this area we did not have time to go round everything properly, and only went into Oceanographic. However, just wandering through the buildings here is enjoyable as they are all so different and it has been really well designed with water running through the area. The main downside to it is that there is no metro station near the area and we found the busses rather confusing! Well worth a visit though.

reviewnospace:
I must admit that we did not give the City an awful lot of time within our trip of Valencia. For a morning we roamed the area, taking in the sci-fi like buildings and then resting near the water features for a drink. In the evening we visited the Umbracle for the pre-Tomatina party by PP travels. The interior was lighted up and the music reverberated through the modern structure.
Not to be missed as part of understanding Valencia- the modern beside the contrast of the charming old City quarters.

If you compare science museum in London it's much more interesting. Where in Valencia you have to pay to get in to and there is literally nothing to see. If you are there just avoid it and go to Aquarium instead. Where there are shows with animals and a lots to see. It's nice on the outside where you can take pictures, but not inside.

quote: a must see and a must know
reviewnospace: Impressive constructions by Santiago Calatrava, loosing slowly the glamour of unique buildings, not only because some need restoration, but because the people of Valencia consider them as cash-burners , which do not contribute to the welfare of the city. right or wrong- it is impressive and must-see!!!

reviewnospace: I ended up at the City of Arts and Sciences after walking along the river parkland from the city centre. It took about 35-40 minutes but it's a lovely walk through a shady and green area. The architecture on show here is definitely worth a wander around the buildings. It's a must for travelers in Valencia. If you're lazy or pressed for time a taxi would only cost €5 from the city centre.

Would go back to explore more at another time.
I'm sure children will enjoy this area.

quote: Not for a hot summers day.
reviewnospace: It is hard to plump for a word to sum up this attraction. It might be a great location in Autumn or Spring but in August 39degree heat the concrete was not appreciated by this visitor. reviewnospace: This place truly looks amazing. The outside promises a unique, technologically-advanced experience. But the so-called "science museum" inside, which I was so excited about, was just awful. The exhibits were old and at least 1/4 of them were completely broken. Nothing was cool or fun; I didn't learn anything. Literally every other science museum I've been to before (at least 5) was better than this. Skip it.

reviewnospace: We went here on our way home from the aquarium next door, or part of this really. We never visited the museum we stayed in the park area and rented a 4 seater bike that was great fun for us all, the were activities going on in the lakes which were nice to watch.
titleopinion: Great fun. We went here on our way home from the aquarium next door, or part of this really. We never visited the museum we stayed in the park area and rented a 4 seater bike that was great fun for us all, the were activities going on in the lakes which were nice to watch.

reviewnospace: The architecture here is pretty impressive, but certainly not worth paying to get into the museum. The museum is bland, certainly not engaging, with loads of boards of text, over 3 floors...There were some 'interactive' exhibits, but we were really disappointed with the number that were broken, needed reinitialising or just a screen showing an old newspaper. We mentioned this to the lady on the information desk who just laughed, shrugged her shoulders and said other visitors had broken them. We said this wasn't acceptable and after 5 minutes, she phoned a colleague. Then she told us to make an official complaint downstairs, but when we got there, there was a queue!! We didn't bother in the end. Extremely poor customer service and uninspiring. Definitely not worth the entry fee to go in.

quote: The best cultural and entertainment complex
reviewnospace: I spent my summer holiday in Valencia, Spain this year and I liked the city very much. And I visited the City of Arts and Sciences with my family a few times as it is a wonderful landmark for its architecture and for its ability to teach and entertain the children and adults. I would recommend anybody to visit this complex and meet the sculptures of Jimenez Deredia. The city of Arts and Sciences in Valencia is the most fantastic place I've ever visited in Europe.

reviewnospace:
This is a must see in Valencia. The architecture is beautiful and strikingly different to the old city centre.

We visited the science museum - wasn't too expensive and included entry to the Pixar exhibition which was a pleasant surprise find. The museum is very hands on, so perfect for families with inquisitive children. Some of the exhibits were not fully functioning but this isn't unexpected. We didn't stay long but you could easily spend an entire morning or afternoon here in the museum alone.

Just under half an hour on foot from the city centre or 10 minutes by taxi. A short 10 minute drive to the beach also.
titleopinion:

We didn't stay long but you could easily spend an entire morning or afternoon here in the museum alone.

quote: It's a must seen for the architecture and for what it's inside!
reviewnospace: You can get here by the bus, the station is called Inst. Obrer de Valencia, ask at you're hotel reception for direction. You will see it from the bus, but attention you need to ask for stop in all the bus in Valencia, if not the driver do not stop. If you want to visit the interior and exterior you will need a whole day. It is open at 10 am, to avoid the line be there at 9:45, or something like that, and go to the building with the museum of science, there is the place where you can buy tickets for all of them. They are different kind of tickets, we took the general one which include all the thing, at it cost as around 25 euro/ person. You can get out an in from a building to other as many time as you want. They give you a ticket which you need to scan at any entry. I absoluty love the architecture and my partner could not exist the museum of science. Every thing is presented very interacting. We love it!

reviewnospace: my teenage daughter absolutely loved her time here (a morning)- the only day it rained; there were lots of well laid out exhibits from furniture to transport, and then on the top floor, lots of hands on science experiments to try for yourself, there were english as well as spanish information guides, and we spent a good hour or so here, having fun, and testing out hypotheses. Well worth the entrance charge, the exterior of the buildings fun to photograph, wonder if it would have been very hot on a sunny day as there was so much glass?

quote: Futuristic buildings in a fab setting!
reviewnospace: All of the buildings here are very futuristic and a marvel of architecture. They are all surrounded by the lovely clear blue 'lake' giving everywhere an air of tranquility. There's a nice bar for a cold drink and as it's so large it never feels crowded, even in the middle of August when we went. Remember to go up to the upper level where there are some beautiful gardens and some interesting sculptures!

reviewnospace:
This is where the Disney movie "Tomorrowland" with George Clooney was filmed. But Disney added too many things, and the original, that is to say, the City of Arts and Sciences, is much more beautiful.
If you arrive to the City of Arts and Sciences walking through the gardens of the Antiguo cauce del Río Turia, the view is really breathtaking, and instead of the many additions of the movie, you can see six magnificent buildings: the Palau de les Arts (Opera), the Hemisferic (Imax cinema), the Museum of Sciences, the Umbracle (a hanging garden above the parking overlooking the City of Arts and Sciences), the Agora (exhibitions and tennis) and the Oceanografic, besides two bridges.
You have to pay to get into the Palau, the Hemisferic, the Museum and the Oceanografic, but you can walk freely with no fee among all the buildings and along the Umbracle garden.
At night it is beautifully lighted and if it is not too windy, you can see the reflection of the buildings in the ponds.
I go very often to Valencia because, although I travel a lot around the whole world and specially Europe, Valencia is my favourite city and every time I go to Valencia I walk among the buildings, ponds and gardens of the City of Arts and Sciences, and the more I visit it the more I like it.
I really envy the Valencia people who can see this wonder every day.
I wish I could live there!

At night it is beautifully lighted and if it is not too windy, you can see the reflection of the buildings in the ponds.
I go very often to Valencia because, although I travel a lot around the whole world and specially Europe, Valencia is my favourite city and every time I go to Valencia I walk among the buildings, ponds and gardens of the City of Arts and Sciences, and the more I visit it the more I like it.

quote: So much beautiful things in one place
reviewnospace:
If you are in Valencia you must visit City of the Arts and Sciences. Open daily, the Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias (also known as the City of the Arts and Sciences) is a traveler favorite. Built on the Old Turia River, the museum's contemporary architecture (by Santiago Calatrava) shelters the Science Museum, the Hemisfèric (a planetarium and IMAX theater), the Oceanográfico aquarium and the Queen Sofia Palace of the Arts (a performing arts venue), among other attractions.

Most travelers raved about the complex's myriad offerings, and suggest you wear comfortable shoes; the City is so massive, you'll be doing a lot of walking. The City is open daily, though with varying hours depending on the season. You can purchase tickets based on individual attractions, or you can buy a combined ticket
titleopinion:
So much beautiful things in one place. If you are in Valencia you must visit City of the Arts and Sciences. Most travelers raved about the complex's myriad offerings, and suggest you wear comfortable shoes; the City is so massive, you'll be doing a lot of walking. The City is open daily, though with varying hours depending on the season. You can purchase tickets based on individual attractions, or you can buy a combined ticket

reviewnospace:
This was my absolute favourite place in Valencia - the buildings are all so modern and cool, and unlike anything at home. We wanted to visit the aquarium, but it was really pricey, so we skipped it. We walked through L'Umbracle, which is the gorgeous walkway with tons of plants and palm trees.
As it was 20C the day we went (in February, no less!), we bought ice cream, and just relaxed and enjoyed the sunshine and palm trees. When I've got more funds, I am definitely coming back to visit all the different buildings!

A couple of hours in an air conditioned building is also a bonus.

quote: Very interesting place to visit with plenty to do
reviewnospace:
I went to the science museum on a recommendation from a friend who had lived in Valencia for a year. It was easy to find as I was staying near which was a bonus.

The outside of the whole area is wonderful! The park looks very green and beautiful and the architecture of the building is very stunning and modern. Parking was easy and tickets well priced.

I didn't stay long as it was busy and other tourists were just hogging the interactions so I moved about quickly. The main part I enjoyed was the Space part showcasing European Space Agency's work and how certain things work I space, a must see for anyone interested in space and the universe.

In all I really enjoyed the museum but felt let down a bit by the Pixar part however still worth a visit.

In all I really enjoyed the museum but felt let down a bit by the Pixar part however still worth a visit.

reviewnospace:
This will be a short review, most of the time I write... a lot, but this time, I try to be short and simple. ( Well I already wasted 100 words but anyways)

We were staying in the NH Hotel just about a 100 metres walk until we reached the arts and science city. The first thing we noticed were the huge buildings, and in comparison to the center of Valencia, there were less people over there.

We bought a combine ticket, that means it includes the Aquarium, the Cinema and the science museum and we just enjoyed visiting, walking around over there.

+ The architecture is awesome
+ Lots of activities to do, also for younger children, I will be sure, children love the aquarium!
+ If you want some peace and quiet, walking around this place is great! (well only the sound of cars can be a bit annoying, but still its much quieter than the center)

- Well, basically because it is so huge, you can get lost ;)

quote: Nice science exposition! Lots of exploration things to try!
reviewnospace:
Very nice museum (8 euro's) about sciences, because you can experience and try lots of things. For example: there are eggs and you can see the little chicken break out! For the moment, there is an exposition of pixar, with nice movies about the creation of Finding Nemo, Cars, Ratatouille, Toy Story... (it's included in the price of the museum).
I would recommend this, certainly on very warm or rainy days, but also overall!
We were there with my tho step-siblings (16 and 17) and they really enjoyed!

reviewnospace: We visited only the Aquarium section of this modern complex. It is divided into several sections, encompassing different aspects of wildlife in water conditions. There are wetlands, ponds, waterfowl, penguins, Belugas, Arctic and Antarctic vistas, and the most amazing glassed-in saltwater tank. That tank is so large that it is possible to walk through a glass tunnel with sharks, rays, and fish swimming overhead. It is marvelous. Even on a busy summer day, the there are so many different areas to explore that you don't feel the crush of all the many tourists. Most people find their way to the dolphin show. Although we don't usually like these shows (not sure about the treatment of the animals), the dolphins seemed well cared for and eager to please their trainers. We spent about four hours here and felt we had seen almost everything. You could stay longer, or go to one of the other sections of the City of Arts and Sciences. It is all beautiful.
titleopinion: This was impressive and wonderful. We visited only the Aquarium section of this modern complex. It is divided into several sections, encompassing different aspects of wildlife in water conditions. There are wetlands, ponds, waterfowl, penguins, Belugas, Arctic and Antarctic vistas, and the most amazing glassed-in saltwater tank. That tank is so large that it is possible to walk through a glass tunnel with sharks, rays, and fish swimming overhead. It is marvelous. Even on a busy summer day, the there are so many different areas to explore that you don't feel the crush of all the many tourists. Most people find their way to the dolphin show. Although we don't usually like these shows (not sure about the treatment of the animals), the dolphins seemed well cared for and eager to please their trainers. We spent about four hours here and felt we had seen almost everything. You could stay longer, or go to one of the other sections of the City of Arts and Sciences. It is all beautiful.

The aeronautical and space exhibit by ESA was better. On the downside, there was an charge extra for the zero-G 'experience'. The staff service was mediocre to poor on average. The oceanographic pavilion was better. But its outside architecture is fantastic!

quote: Don't let the exterior deceive you...
reviewnospace:
We visited Valencia for its supposed art and science attractions, the city of the Arts and Sciences being the main attraction for the visit. We were not impressed. We had a day ticket to the science museum and oceanographic pavilion. The science museum is a massively large building, but contains a lot of air. Many of the installations I have seen better presented from our local science museum, many did not work and I had frankly much higher expectations with interactive and motivating installations/themes. The aeronautical and space exhibit by ESA (temporarily?) was better. Personally, I was impressed that they had on display the old FOC instrument of Hubble Space Telescope. On the downside, there was an charge extra for the zero-G 'experience'. The staff service was mediocre to poor on average (the low end of which was the attendant of the electricity "show", who bluntly turned away half of the people who had queued up for the next show complaining that they should get the tickets for entry at the ticket office and better read the printed prerequisites posted among a long and small printed poster by the entry door). With a pointless policy like that they had better inform visitors about this when you purchase the tickets at the entry and post it clearly.

The oceanographic pavilion was better and is the only reason for not rating the experience poor. It is more diverse and the dolphin show was very well managed, although the first 15 min of the show was spent selecting 'volunteers' among the kids in the audience, which was about 10 minutes too long. I don't care for zoo's and this marine zoo is no exception, many of the species show obvious signs of stress and trauma from being locked in what is a very real prison.
titleopinion:
Don't let the exterior deceive you.... We visited Valencia for its supposed art and science attractions, the city of the Arts and Sciences being the main attraction for the visit. We were not impressed. We had a day ticket to the science museum and oceanographic pavilion. The science museum is a massively large building, but contains a lot of air. Many of the installations I have seen better presented from our local science museum, many did not work and I had frankly much higher expectations with interactive and motivating installations/themes. The aeronautical and space exhibit by ESA (temporarily?) was better. Personally, I was impressed that they had on display the old FOC instrument of Hubble Space Telescope. On the downside, there was an charge extra for the zero-G 'experience'. The staff service was mediocre to poor on average (the low end of which was the attendant of the electricity "show", who bluntly turned away half of the people who had queued up for the next show complaining that they should get the tickets for entry at the ticket office and better read the printed prerequisites posted among a long and small printed poster by the entry door). With a pointless policy like that they had better inform visitors about this when you purchase the tickets at the entry and post it clearly.

The oceanographic pavilion was better and is the only reason for not rating the experience poor. It is more diverse and the dolphin show was very well managed, although the first 15 min of the show was spent selecting 'volunteers' among the kids in the audience, which was about 10 minutes too long. I don't care for zoo's and this marine zoo is no exception, many of the species show obvious signs of stress and trauma from being locked in what is a very real prison.

quote: stunning buildings, great photo opportunity and the insides explained!
reviewnospace:
Loving architecture this was a must visit, it's great to wander around the buildings and there is a 'green/park area' and also the water to sit and wander around. There is also a small inexpensive train to take a 30 minute tour if you don't want to walk. You can also buy a drink and a small snack here. The outside of the buildings are amazing but to explain what's in each: The city of arts and sciences are made up of 5 buildings, the Palau de les arts Reina Sofia is the concert and opera hall open when events are on. The L' Hemisferic is an IMAX cinema with various shows and viewings available. In 3 D.
Museu de Ciences Principe Felipe is an interactive science museum. The L'Umbracle is a green house but closed when we went. The L' Oceangraphic is a marine park, it's quite expensive but takes a good 3-4 hours to look around andeveruthing is free when in including the dolphin show. Nice for a family visit, we thought it was ok but then if you have been to Florida nothing ever compares. If you have a family this is good place to go to the cinema, marine park and the science museum or if you have a particular interest in these. Otherwise wander around the buildings, it's very different from the old cultural side of most city's to see something like this. We didn't go at night but I can imagine with the lights this also is amazing.

If you are a student don't forget to ask for a students discount on your ticket.
