Beautiful, interesting, uber-stylish. We visited on very hot sunny days, and as the buildings are white and covered with shiny mosaic tiles the centre is kept cool while you explore the site. The buildings are surrounded by large expanses of crystal clear water. We hired a Kayak with hilarious results! Well worth getting soaked for. Kids will love this place loads of space to run around and lots to see. There's a museum, cinema famous concert hall and bars and restaurants, also within walking distance of the huge Oceanografic All in all a must do!

reviewnospace: Great architecture and very spacious. Kids love the place because they can touch and experience all kind of things. Unfortunately most is in spanish so not exactly tourist friendly. But a good place to spend some hours on a rainy day.
titleopinion: Nice museum with kids. Great architecture and very spacious. Kids love the place because they can touch and experience all kind of things. Unfortunately most is in spanish so not exactly tourist friendly. But a good place to spend some hours on a rainy day.

reviewnospace: Worth a visit just to walk rund the extensive site as it looks stunning both day and night. The buildings on site are each very different and it isn't until you see an ariel shot of the site that you realise that the whole complex looks like a fish with each building addiings its shape to the whole.

reviewnospace:
It's amazing architecture, great walk, and lovely atmosphere there, but pricy entrances, not much to offer and all installation are worn off and old. We were deeply disappointed and paid 65€ for 2 persons to see all 3 attractions (Hemispheric, Oceanographic, and Science Museum) plus count at least 40-50€ for meals as they are way too overpriced.
It's much nicer on the outside as to what it holds on the inside.
Won't be back.

quote: There must be something better to do
reviewnospace: It's quite out of the way and expensive. Not really my cup of tea. Nothing really interesting although the structure itself is quite a sight. Would not recommend.
titleopinion: There must be something better to do. It's quite out of the way and expensive. Not really my cup of tea. Nothing really interesting although the structure itself is quite a sight. Would not recommend.

reviewnospace: parabolas abound in this remarkable collection of bold looking buildings! More here than you would imagine, signature look of modern Valencia.
titleopinion: Architectural wonder. parabolas abound in this remarkable collection of bold looking buildings! More here than you would imagine, signature look of modern Valencia.

reviewnospace:
The City of Arts and Sciences is a magical place. I was really impressed! Architecture is really amazing and stunning.
The Oceanographic, the largest aquarium in Europe, is structured really well. Each wing is found a different marine area: Ocean, Mediterranean, Red Sea, Arctic and Antarctica.
The Science Museum is very interesting.
The Hemispheric, a cinema screen ball that gives the impression of being surrounded by the scene of the film.
In all The City of Arts and Sciences is a place where one can walk from past to future and learn lot of things.
Undoubtedly, its a must visit place in Valencia.
titleopinion:
Beautifully Crafted!. The City of Arts and Sciences is a magical place. I was really impressed! Architecture is really amazing and stunning.
The Oceanographic, the largest aquarium in Europe, is structured really well. Each wing is found a different marine area: Ocean, Mediterranean, Red Sea, Arctic and Antarctica.
The Science Museum is very interesting.
The Hemispheric, a cinema screen ball that gives the impression of being surrounded by the scene of the film.
In all The City of Arts and Sciences is a place where one can walk from past to future and learn lot of things.
Undoubtedly, its a must visit place in Valencia.

reviewnospace: Who thought this monstrosity was a good idea? It's ugly and it's not holding up very well. If you visit Valencia, a beautiful city, you kinda hafta see it. But I thought it looked like a movie set from a bad sci-fi movie.
titleopinion: Erector set architecture. Who thought this monstrosity was a good idea? It's ugly and it's not holding up very well. If you visit Valencia, a beautiful city, you kinda hafta see it. But I thought it looked like a movie set from a bad sci-fi movie.

reviewnospace:
This place. or area, looked mind- blowingly beautiful- the buildings are amazing and the scale is immense. Somebody had very deep pockets - that'd be us then? However, due to the economic situation, I guess, it is plonked in the middle of a somewhat sad brownfield site - there is a proposed metro line that stops unfinished, and a lot of undeveloped areas that are obvious from the top of the ho-ho bus! We went into all the buildings - the science museum and the cinematographic centre, but there are a couple of buildings that are purely shells. We would have like to visit the oceanographic centre but we arrived at end of afternoon and the entry cost was too high to justify the short time we could have spent.
Considering this area is the jewel in Valencia's crown there is still some work to be done, but I'd be interested to know who will pick up the tab for it now Europe is broke!

reviewnospace: Worth a visit just to look at the architecture. It is marvelous the combination of buildings, lines, angles, styles. I think I took a million pictures. We visited the aquarium. Although you must dedicate at least 3 hours, it is worth it. All the exhibits are great and worth seeing. Must interject here that the food at the park is terrible-- american fast junk. And speaking of Valencia, you must must must walk from Ciudad de las Artes through the old river bed park to the old city. Valencia has incredible buildings and bridges but its green areas and urban parks are a most valuable asset. Valencia is for walking, walking, walking. Go ahead and take the trek. You will not regret it.

reviewnospace: We visited this area which is on the edge of the centre purely to see the architecture and were not disappointed. Love the designs of all the buildings and the use of water. One building was either not finished or being repaired which we think was a theatre but for some reason we had thought it was an art gallery. We did not go into any of the buildings other than the cafeteria in the Science Museum which was ok. Definitely worth a visit just to explore the buildings and park.

We did not go into any of the buildings other than the cafeteria in the Science Museum which was ok. Definitely worth a visit just to explore the buildings and park.

reviewnospace:
It is worth coming here just to admire the architecture, it's truly impressive and on the edge of the Rhine park so you could spend the day in the park if you're not interested in the museum or aquarium.

The museum is definitely more suited to children, very interactive but still interesting for adults. Most displays have English and/or German.

The ESA display on the walkway to the museum entrance is interesting and free to look at.

I did not visit the aquarium or theatre so cannot comment but enjoyed the museum and especially the architecture, you can't come to Valencia and not visit this place!

reviewnospace: Went to this place a windy afternoon, and was literally blown away by the science museum and the opera. The blue building did not seem finished, and there were broken windows in the first floor - the complex somehow gave us the impression of not being fully used, and that it suffered from the bad economy of this city. Nevertheless, it's worth visiting with the Turia park next to it.

The blue building did not seem finished, and there were broken windows in the first floor - the complex somehow gave us the impression of not being fully used, and that it suffered from the bad economy of this city. Nevertheless, it's worth visiting with the Turia park next to it.

reviewnospace: To be given the opportunity to be shown such wonderful modern buildings as the 'City of Arts and Sciences' was breathtaking. It is an ensemble of six areas in the dry river bed of the now diverted River Turia and a must for tourists from everywhere.

reviewnospace: The place is so pretty! The white and special architecture definitely go along very well with the blue sky and the sun. It was do nice just chilling out there. And the aquarium is a must! Love it!
titleopinion: Awesome!. The place is so pretty! The white and special architecture definitely go along very well with the blue sky and the sun. It was do nice just chilling out there. And the aquarium is a must! Love it!

quote: Fantastic photographic at any time of day
reviewnospace:
On a trip to Valencia we visited the City of Arts & Sciences many times, from early till darkness. It is almost impossible not to be inspired by or to take poor photos of, the futuristic buildings - and the activity around them. One or two viewpoints - The steps of the Science Museum for instance - are out of bounds, which is a shame. Generally, all around access is great and at the end of September, although still busy, it was still possible to get shots without crowds of fellow tourists included. As darkness falls and the lights come on it looks fantastic. As a photographer with 30,000 photos on Flickr the Valencia ones are some of my most popular.
A great place to sit with a glass of wine and watch the world go by - in the sun of course.

Even though some of Calatravas buildings haven`t withstood wind and weather as well as was hoped, this is a glimpse of what modern architecure can achieve.

quote: Buy the ticket online and spend a day here
reviewnospace:
You can buy the tickets online and have a 10% discount. The Oceanografic is awesome, from dolphins to sharks, from stingrays to my beloved penguins you'll have a lot to see! The Museo del las Ciencas is nice and interactive but it's more suited for children. The Hemisferic is kinda like a mix between a planetarium and a very cool 180° cinema.
Last but not least don't forget to have an orchata wandering throught the complex admiring the outstanding buildings.

reviewnospace: Impressive creations. For me the buildings are more like monuments and in many ways unpractical for full scale use for cultural or entertaining purposes. It is also sad to see, that after so short living period, the monumental buildings already need huge reconstruction work. For a tourist the area is a delightful place to visit, but for the local community it seems to be a burden,at least a financial one for sure.

reviewnospace: The things people build there are really amazing. The city of artes is very big. You ll need a full day or maybe more to visit everything. The arhitecture is very special, modern. Love it!

reviewnospace: This place is just a must-see and a must photograph attraction. Against a blue sky the fantastical architecture is breathtaking and more than a bit bonkers. The buildings do look like alien spacecraft, apart from one angle where they look like the second bit of the title ;-) Personally we didn't bother going into the buildings, just wandered around filling up our memory cards.

Against a blue sky the fantastical architecture is breathtaking and more than a bit bonkers. The buildings do look like alien spacecraft, apart from one angle where they look like the second bit of the title ;-) Personally we didn't bother going into the buildings, just wandered around filling up our memory cards.

quote: Great day out for the family
reviewnospace:
Fantastic place to visit, buildings and surrounding area very photogenic and will take your breath away - if you are not careful you can spend all day taking photos. The science museum is good fun and a great building. the IMAX is worth a visit, but check when the films are on and book when you first get there. The science museum and Imax cinema are reasonably priced.

We also went to the Oceanographic, largest in Europe and had a fantastic family day out. The cost was high, but we did book a ticket for all three - science museum, Imax and Oceanographic, which reduced the price (three of us circa 150euros). Not cheap by any standards. The most expensive part was the Oceanographic, but we spent a good half day walking round as there is plenty to see and the layout is excellent as it takes you through several buildings.

We would definitely visit again if we were in Valencia - was it worth 1.1billion to build - you will have to decide when you look at your photos when you get home.
titleopinion:
Great day out for the family. Fantastic place to visit, buildings and surrounding area very photogenic and will take your breath away - if you are not careful you can spend all day taking photos. The science museum is good fun and a great building. the IMAX is worth a visit, but check when the films are on and book when you first get there. The science museum and Imax cinema are reasonably priced.

We also went to the Oceanographic, largest in Europe and had a fantastic family day out. The cost was high, but we did book a ticket for all three - science museum, Imax and Oceanographic, which reduced the price (three of us circa 150euros). Not cheap by any standards. The most expensive part was the Oceanographic, but we spent a good half day walking round as there is plenty to see and the layout is excellent as it takes you through several buildings.

We would definitely visit again if we were in Valencia - was it worth 1.1billion to build - you will have to decide when you look at your photos when you get home.

reviewnospace: My trip to the city of arts and sciences was incredible! I got to pet a dolphin, and I saw a ton of really cool fish in the aquarium. I really enjoyed the other parts of the museums. the architecture is also beautiful
titleopinion: Pet a dolphin!. My trip to the city of arts and sciences was incredible! I got to pet a dolphin, and I saw a ton of really cool fish in the aquarium. I really enjoyed the other parts of the museums. the architecture is also beautiful

quote: The T.V. show leaded us there
reviewnospace:
When we saw this magnificent complex on the T.V.show, my husband and I rearranged our trip to go to Valencia and visit City of the Arts and Sciences. What a great trip! Would like to go back again.
This complex has 6 individual impressive buildings located at the end of Jardín del Turia park.
El Palau de les Arts Reina Sofia is the first building you will see, it looks like a Roman soldier helmet with a long slide on the top. Reina Sofia is an opera house and cultural centre.
The second building is L'Hemisfèric, an IMAX theatre that's hidden between Reina Sofia and El Museu de les Ciències Príncipe Felipe. It looks like a half of an Americian football soaking in the water.
The third building is El Museu de les Ciències Príncipe Felipe, is an interactive museum of science that looks like a skeleton of a whale. Lots of things inside for you to touch and play.
L'Umbracle is the fourth building beside El Museu de les Ciències Príncipe Felipe. It’s a well designed and maintained garden. All kind of trees and shrubs are carefully planned there. Shaped like the belly of a whale.
The fifth building is Agora, look like a blue hat. Its a place for sporting events and exhibitions, and conventions. While we were there nothing was happening.
The sixth is the Oceanographic. It’s the largest marine complex in Europe. Lots to see and lots of fun.
We spent one and a half day there, still not cover the whole area. If you go there just for a few photos, you really don’t know what you are missing.
Happy Travelling!

be ready to spend the entire day at this attractions.

reviewnospace: If you in Valencia, you must visit this center. Architecture at its best, nice area for walking and relax.
titleopinion: Fantasitc arkitecture. If you in Valencia, you must visit this center. Architecture at its best, nice area for walking and relax.

reviewnospace:
The architecture is very interesting. The science museum is okay at best and doesn't compare to a world class science museum. We didn't in the oceanography part so I can't comment on that (other than the cost to get in there is about 4x the cost to get in the science part).

If you're visiting for the architecture, there is a department store to the east of the museum just across the park. Go to the restaurant and cafe on the top floor and you'll get nice views from the outside deck up there.
titleopinion:

reviewnospace:
It is an amazing sight, it is as if you have been transported to another planet or into the future.

The all white mosaic landscape with its amazing organic architecture are an absolute MUST for anyone visiting Valencia, it is the #1 destination for everyone.

I would not recommend actually entering except if you are with kids who might enjoy the 3D imax and the science museum inside, try the oceanografic instead, it is an amazing aquarium.
titleopinion:

I would not recommend actually entering except if you are with kids who might enjoy the 3D imax and the science museum inside, try the oceanografic instead, it is an amazing aquarium.

reviewnospace: As some-one not overly scientific, I wasn't really bothered about visiting but am really glad that I did! The walk through the Turia Gardens was lovely and the first sight of the buildings was amazing. We had purchased a combined ticket online from the tourist centre before leaving home. Once we got in there we booked the time to go to the Hemispheric as there were different films on hourly. The ground floor had the cafe, where we had a lovely breakfast before embarking on a very interesting tour of the, often, interactive exhibits. Some presentations were in English once a day but not all. It didn't spoil it though, we saw the one on electricity. There were chickens hatching, exhibits on the body, the natural world, in fact too much to remember! We spent a very interesting 4/5 hours there, before going to the Hemispheric.

reviewnospace: Really impressive place with space age buildings and good to wander around. The Oceanographic (Aquarium) was expensive and I imagine gets very busy during peak season, but was very impressive with a wide selection of aquatic mammals and fish. The museum was fun with loads of things to do, buttons to press, things to play with that was aimed at teaching young and old alike.

The Oceanographic (Aquarium) was expensive and I imagine gets very busy during peak season, but was very impressive with a wide selection of aquatic mammals and fish. The museum was fun with loads of things to do, buttons to press, things to play with that was aimed at teaching young and old alike.

reviewnospace: Go for Calatrava's futuristic architecture and admire it from the outside. On a sunny winter's day it is pretty impressive - the white and glass contrasted with Valencia's impossibly blue skies. In summer it must be a real suntrap and probably not for the fainthearted or those prone to sunstroke. However there are already signs of weather damage, rust and wear and tear and the concert hall was covered in scaffolding. The Hemispheric and science Museum are in good shape and you can get inside at least the atrium to get a sense of the interior design. The advice seems to be not to pay the cost of admission as, similar to the Milennium Dome, there hasn't been much thought of how to make use of all the space.
titleopinion: Controversial but arresting architecture. Go for Calatrava's futuristic architecture and admire it from the outside. On a sunny winter's day it is pretty impressive - the white and glass contrasted with Valencia's impossibly blue skies. In summer it must be a real suntrap and probably not for the fainthearted or those prone to sunstroke. However there are already signs of weather damage, rust and wear and tear and the concert hall was covered in scaffolding. The Hemispheric and science Museum are in good shape and you can get inside at least the atrium to get a sense of the interior design. The advice seems to be not to pay the cost of admission as, similar to the Milennium Dome, there hasn't been much thought of how to make use of all the space.

quote: A modern twist to a cultural city
reviewnospace: We caught bus 35 from town to the city of arts and science for 1.5€ each and really enjoyed this whole area which is a legacy to the Olympics. The science area was impressive and while we did not enter the oceanarium or museums this time we enjoyed the space and walks around the site. We will definitely be back with our boys in the Spring to complete these tours.
titleopinion: A modern twist to a cultural city. We caught bus 35 from town to the city of arts and science for 1.5€ each and really enjoyed this whole area which is a legacy to the Olympics. We will definitely be back with our boys in the Spring to complete these tours.

reviewnospace: When in Valencia, this is must visit. Enjoy the morning in the city of arts and sciences and visit to the aquarium. Calatrava piece of art is simply breathtaking.

quote: Good place and the only thing to do in Valencia
reviewnospace: Good place to go to while in Valencia. A bit steep in price, but will keep to busy for an entire day.
titleopinion: Good place and the only thing to do in Valencia. Good place to go to while in Valencia. A bit steep in price, but will keep to busy for an entire day.

reviewnospace: At the outset, I must state that I would give a high rating for the futuristic architecture. Avid photographs, amateur or professionals, would spend a good 1-2 hours snapping away at the different structures. But it ends there because the attractions are not really worth your time, unless of course you have never been to an IMAX theatre (and you would therefore rave about L'Hemisferic) or a large aquarium (and therefore, Oceanografic). This "city" is still a must-visit for the postcard-worthy pictures, but don't expect to be entertained much apart from that.
titleopinion: Futuristic Architecture. At the outset, I must state that I would give a high rating for the futuristic architecture. Avid photographs, amateur or professionals, would spend a good 1-2 hours snapping away at the different structures. But it ends there because the attractions are not really worth your time, unless of course you have never been to an IMAX theatre (and you would therefore rave about L'Hemisferic) or a large aquarium (and therefore, Oceanografic). This "city" is still a must-visit for the postcard-worthy pictures, but don't expect to be entertained much apart from that.

reviewnospace: Came to Valencia on a very short break, we visited the science museum and went to the hemispheric, both were very impressive. the site is massive and takes a long time to see everything, we didn't have that much time so we have to visit again to see the rest! overall, a very nice experience.

reviewnospace: One of the outstanding sights of three weeks in Spain. A walk through the park in the bed of the diverted river to approach this magnificent view of modern architecture. There are many old to ancient sites to visit in Spain, but this is one of, if not the outstanding, site for modern architecture not only in Spain, but possibly worldwide. We only were able to enter one of the buildings, but the exteriors of the buildings and plazas alone are well worth your time if you enjoy modern architecture.
titleopinion: Architectural "Tour de Force". One of the outstanding sights of three weeks in Spain. A walk through the park in the bed of the diverted river to approach this magnificent view of modern architecture. There are many old to ancient sites to visit in Spain, but this is one of, if not the outstanding, site for modern architecture not only in Spain, but possibly worldwide. We only were able to enter one of the buildings, but the exteriors of the buildings and plazas alone are well worth your time if you enjoy modern architecture.

reviewnospace: Saw this place first when I was attending a late night party in the botanical garden and I felt like I was on a different planet! We went back the next day to see it all when the sun was going down, and it was unbelievable! A definite must see!

Do splash out and go to the sea world show..it even has an enviromentalist message through music, dance, and human and dolphin shows.
On a hot summer evening there is no better place to be!
We went from 9pm ( when the are reduced in price) until midnight...yes its summer and its Spain so most people only leave home to eat at 10pm. You´ll love it!

quote: City of art and science..ciudad de las artes y sciencias, Valencia, España.
reviewnospace:
From the moment you see the city of arts and sciences you know you are in an exciting location.
Just a short taxi drive from the very centre of the old town and you are in a modern landscape of glass, water and funky designs.
The Aqua park on a hot summer evening is the place to be, with a great water show that actually had a great enviromentalist message. The power was not only in the dance ,music and swimming humans and dolphins but also in the message of conservation of sea faring cultures and preservation of the seas .
We were there from 9pm when the entrance fee was cheaper until midnight...yes this is España en verano!!!

quote: A Must See! Try out day and night!
reviewnospace:
It´s too bad that there´s a lot of maintenance going on but inspite of that, this futuristic city is by far one of the most spectacular projects I´ve ever seen. On a bright and sunny day with no wind, you can take great pictures of the buildings and the reflection in the water. Overwhelming views as well during night time when the city is lit and even more futuristic than you can imagine.

The rooftop of the Reina Sofia is ugly since they had to scrape of most of the little mosaic tiles and many people worry for it to stay like that for years, until the architect Santiago Calatrava and the city of Valencia have worked out their differences about who´s gonna pay for a new solution.

Knowing these things take years anyways, visitors will have to use their imagination I´m afraid. Nevertheless....If you haven´t seen this project in Valencia, you haven´t seen the city at all. Don´t miss this!
titleopinion:

Overwhelming views as well during night time when the city is lit and even more futuristic than you can imagine.

Knowing these things take years anyways, visitors will have to use their imagination I´m afraid. Nevertheless....If you haven´t seen this project in Valencia, you haven´t seen the city at all. Don´t miss this!

large natural tanks. The best feature was the last building which
is hard to find and had a sensational orca tank with the whale
continuously circling and coming right at you. Also a tank with
huge walruses playing with a ball and cube. Fantastic experience.

reviewnospace: I was blown away by how beautiful the building was, and the whole feel of the place from the outside, but inside there were half-hearted science displays that looked like they were installed in the 1970s and hadn't been touched or updated since then. It was not worth the 4 euros I paid to enter, there are definitely better things to do in Valencia.

I was blown away by how beautiful the building was, and the whole feel of the place from the outside, but inside there were half-hearted science displays that looked like they were installed in the 1970s and hadn't been touched or updated since then. It was not worth the 4 euros I paid to enter, there are definitely better things to do in Valencia.

Really fantastic views of the city.

quote: The gem in the crown of the Turia
reviewnospace:
The architecture is spectacular. The Hemisferic and the high level walkway of the Science Museum were closed when we were there, but this did not detract in anyway from the stunning vistas created by the shinning white buildings and blue reflecting pools as they snake along around a mile of the equally beautiful Turia river bed. We went into the Science Museum and the Umbracle arboretum both as brilliant inside as out.

Buildings and pools make extensive use of Guadi style tiling which sparkles in the sunshine.

We went into the Science Museum and the Umbracle arboretum both as brilliant inside as out.

Buildings and pools make extensive use of Guadi style tiling which sparkles in the sunshine.

reviewnospace:
This place is an architectural highlight of the region. There are a number of interesting and unusual buildings set together in the former bed of the Turia River. The buildings were designed by a native son architect, Santiago Calatrava. We only walked around the outside and didn't actually go in any of the buildings but it was still very impressive. Definitely worth a visit.
There is no fee to walk around the buildings outside. I believe there is a fee to enter the museums and theaters.
The major drawback for me was lack of restroom facilities at the site.
titleopinion:
awesome architecture. This place is an architectural highlight of the region. There are a number of interesting and unusual buildings set together in the former bed of the Turia River. The buildings were designed by a native son architect, Santiago Calatrava. We only walked around the outside and didn't actually go in any of the buildings but it was still very impressive. Definitely worth a visit.

After a long walk as it seemed the locals including a taxi driver had no knowledge of this place I did enjoy my walk around the perimeter of this massive contemporary public space.

The contrast to the rest of the city one cannot help but be impressed at the undertaking.
Sadly already some decay is evident in the exterior.

Worth a couple hours..

reviewnospace: Stunning architecture coupled with some good museums are the main attractions of the City of the Arts and Sciences. There are some nice photo locations for everlasting memories of the place.
titleopinion: Stunning Architecture. Stunning architecture coupled with some good museums are the main attractions of the City of the Arts and Sciences. There are some nice photo locations for everlasting memories of the place.

reviewnospace: This is an exciting idea, but did not live up to expectations sadly....The museum is okay, although 2 or the 3 floors are not that engaging and written mostly in Spanish - no English. The third floor is much better and in both languages, exploring the physical world and ecology, space flight etc. It is not on a scale with, say, the Science Museum in London, but it is an okay place to go on a cloudy day...we went on a cloudyish October day and it was still very hot in there, so not sure how it would be in August...we also went to the Oceangrafic next door ( on a dual ticket) which was much, much better...try that instead!
titleopinion: Okay.... reviewnospace: Loved everything about this place, stayed all day and could easily have stayed more. Highly recommended to anyone going,
titleopinion: Best visit this year. Loved everything about this place, stayed all day and could easily have stayed more. Highly recommended to anyone going,

reviewnospace: great views; impressive architecture; easy access and plenty of space to walk in/on the surrounding parks and paths.
titleopinion: Interesting architecture. great views; impressive architecture; easy access and plenty of space to walk in/on the surrounding parks and paths.

reviewnospace: I was on a cruise around southern Spain with my family. Before departing the boat to Valencia I checked out online the attractions. The architecture of Santiago Calatrava interests me as it's very like Zaha Hadid. The other members of my family decided they'd rather go to the old town. I took myself in a taxi and stayed the whole day. I took over 300 photographs in all and loved every minute of the trip. One of the buildings contains an oceanographic building (similar to a Sea World), one of the largest in Europe. Of the many things I saw there were walruses - amazing!! To say that I felt like a lil kid was an understatement. Loved every minute. Definitely a must-do, in fact do as I did and buy a ticket for the science building at the same time. You will not be disappointed. PS you don't have to pay to see the architecture from the outside.
titleopinion: Art Student's Heaven. I was on a cruise around southern Spain with my family. Before departing the boat to Valencia I checked out online the attractions. The architecture of Santiago Calatrava interests me as it's very like Zaha Hadid. The other members of my family decided they'd rather go to the old town. I took myself in a taxi and stayed the whole day. I took over 300 photographs in all and loved every minute of the trip. One of the buildings contains an oceanographic building (similar to a Sea World), one of the largest in Europe. Of the many things I saw there were walruses - amazing!! To say that I felt like a lil kid was an understatement. Loved every minute. Definitely a must-do, in fact do as I did and buy a ticket for the science building at the same time. You will not be disappointed. PS you don't have to pay to see the architecture from the outside.

quote: Run down & no atmosphere. Ghost Town.
reviewnospace:
I really don't get this place or why it's so reviewed in a positive light. The architecture is different yet the place is so run down and tired that it overshadows it all. The Turia riverbed which is now transformed into a park is also tired. The play areas which used to be buzzing are now ghostly with broken turnstiles without entry fee. Very depressing.

Maybe get a bike and if it's on route go cycle round the arts and sciences place but the whole area is like a ghetto. We went for a walk after wandering around and it's not a nice place at all. No restaurants, no bars no nothing it's so random and unfriendly.

The Aquarium is 27 Euro for an adult and based on the area decided it probably wasn't worth it. We went to the Bioparc instead on another day and i would 100% recommend spending you money there than here.

Such a disappointment.

The walk to the beach is far from here so maybe hop on a bus.

reviewnospace: As an architecture buff I have long admired Santiago Calatrava but was unprepared for the variety and magnitude of his work at the Ciudad. The name translates to the City of Arts and Sciences which sounds a bit formal and off putting. It isn't. I travelled there by city bus and could see the very distinctive shapes of the structures from a couple of bus stops away. I had to restrain myself and wait until the bus stopped in front of the Ocranographic at the far end of the complex. As its name implies, the Oceanographic is a huge Aquarium and also an underwater city incorporating the seven seas and all their inhabitants. There's also a cool gift shop. I especially enjoyed visiting the Agora, a huge open market place featuring an exhibit of the construction of the Ciudad. The space is large enough to hold more than one tennis court and it has indeed hosted a major tennis tournament. Walking across the Calatrava bridge took me back to Buenos Aires and his awesome Puenta de la Mujer. I stopped for a drink at the magnificent Opera House, formally named Palau de las Artes Reina Sofia (Queen Sofia's Palace of Arts) and enjoyed the cool breeze coming off the fountains lining the walkway to Prince Philip's Science Museum where kids of all ages are positively encouraged to become involved with all aspects of the scientific experience. Then there's the Umbracle, a weirdly named but architecturally fascinating narrow exhibition space that cleverly conceals the parking area. There's too much more to describe here. Each structure, on its own, would be an architectural masterpiece. There are at least 6 phenomenal buildings, each distinct from the others but each bearing Calatrava's distinctive style. Not to be missed. Kids will love it. Adults will marvel at different aspects. It would be an awesome adventure for 3 generations. It's possible to walk through the entire City, the Agora and Umbracle for free; the museums and Oceanografic have entrance fees. Best to purchase a ticket combining several attractions. Plan a full day or even 2. You won't be sorry.

reviewnospace: Sandra, Travelagent: I have visited the C.A.C. during a tour around the city. we went there by bike - (bicycle tour, through tfhe turial-river which is now a beautiful park/walkway).. if you follow the river you end up at the CAC. the buildings have been put there to compete with cities as Barcelona and Madrid.. Ofcourse it is not old and historical; and they have cost a fortune.. - but still it is an amazing thing to see. You can only get how large the buildings are; once you actually visit them.. The contrast of blue water and white buildings is very pretty.. We have visited one of the buildings: the waterparc, which is great for kids with large fishtanks & tunnels to walk through.. I have heard that the science museum in the CAC is great too.. When visiting Valencia; this place is a must-see.. you can take some great pictures there and cycling through this area is great. (there are several layers of buildings/walking bridges, so its nice to have a bike and have different views over the buildings.)

reviewnospace:
We were docked in Valencia for the day, so my friend and I took a walk around. The first thing you notice is the row of museums, along with the opera house and an aquarium. They are big and they are beautiful.

We decided to go into this museum and see what was there. WOW! I've got to say, I was totally blown away from the moment we walked in. There was so much to see and learn about. There are tons of hands-on displays and interactive exhibits. We even went to one of the shows, despite the fact that neither of us speaks much Spanish.

I think we spent about 4-5 hours in the museum and we still didn't get to see everything...but we sure saw a lot.

If you go to Valencia, you've got to check this museum out. The architecture alone is worth the visit. They even have a reflecting pool outside where guests can sit, relax, enjoy a snack, or even take a ride in a giant inflatable hamster ball. No kidding!

By the way, I think we paid somewhere in the neighborhood of 8 or 10 Euros for the Science Museum, but they have packages available for the other attractions too.

reviewnospace: As a whole, this huge project is enormously impressive. Even if you didn't go inside any of the buildings you would still be blown away by the architecture. And don't miss out going at night for photographs because the reflections make the buildings look even more spectacular. As far as attractions go we loved the aquarium (but the standalone restaurant needs to get real with its prices, we wouldn't go over the doorstep) and found the science centre rather dull and a bit like an airport lounge; it seems sterile inside. But, as a whole, this complex of buildings takes your breath away.

reviewnospace:
When my friend and I arrived in Valencia, the City of Arts and Sciences was the first place to visit.
Although it's far more glamorous in the pictures than in real life (the buildings could be maintained better), it is a stunning experience.

If you're an art/architecture or engineering professional (or even enthusiast) there is a lot to learn about composition, harmony and the organisation of public space.

If you're not familiar with the works of Santiago Calatrava, Valencia, and especially this particular buildings complex is a good place to start.

I recommend allowing yourself a good 4-5 hours (minimum) or even a whole day for this attraction. Just rushing through isn't really worth it.
If you're lucky enough, you can stumble upon different events or concerts (the complex was first intended as an entertainment center anyway).

Although walking around the complex is free of charge, I would also recommend visiting the Science Museum. Unlike most science museums, this one isn't boring at all; it's rather interactive and entertaining.
If you're not into film projections skip the Hemispheric.
Be sure to talk to the lady/sir at the info point before deciding what tickets to buy. The cashiers speak little to no English.
Protip: if you want to visit the Oceanografic, you can get tickets from the Science museum (let's say, Oceanografic+Science museum - small discount) and avoid the queue at the Oceanografic.

quote: Welcome to the World of Tomorrow!
reviewnospace:
Now we know what Fry from Futurama felt like when he woke up a thousand years in the future. The City of Arts and Sciences really does look like a 1960s vision of the future.

The architecture is simply stunning and you have to go there to fully appreciate the the scale and audacity of this enterprise.

For the architecture and landscaping I would have no hesitation in giving five stars or six if that was an option. Sadly, the contents of the Science Museum were a bit mundane in comparison with the surroundings. Many of the exhibits appeared a bit lost in the huge building and it wasn't coherently themed (I've seen a lot better). This is the reason for four stars.

quote: Was I in the Capitol City of Hunger Games?
reviewnospace: We had an unexpected half day to spend in Valencia recently and asked for suggestions on what to visit that was near to our hotel. Imagine our excitement (I felt like I was transported to the Capitol City of Hunger Games) when we came upon the Paseo de la Alameda and continued to "just take a quick look" at the City of Arts and Science. What a magnificent experience! We were overwhelmed by the each-one-different-from-the next modernist architecture of Santiago Calatrava. As we are marine life enthusiasts, (have visited several aquariums in the states) we returned a week later to spend several hours at the Oceanografic. We were not disappointed, a true treasure in the city.

What a magnificent experience! We were overwhelmed by the each-one-different-from-the next modernist architecture of Santiago Calatrava. As we are marine life enthusiasts, (have visited several aquariums in the states) we returned a week later to spend several hours at the Oceanografic. We were not disappointed, a true treasure in the city.

reviewnospace: Stunning visually from afar and just as good up close lets hope they continue with it's up-keep. The tiles had fallen off the outside of the Palace of Arts Reina Sofia and the rest had to be removed. It's rumoured they cannot afford a permanent fix. Some other areas were also not quite up to the very top end of expectations IMAX etc but where this place really scores is the architecture and construction really impressive.

reviewnospace: We spent a day at the Oceanografic part of the City of Arts and Sciences, and I cannot wait to go back to see the rest! The Oceanografic museum is absolutely beautiful, and even on a very well visited day it never felt crammed. The aquariums are fascinating with species that you would not see in many places in the world, the exhibitions around intersting. Make sure you arrive in time for the dolphin show as it gets filled up quickly. There are restaurants onsite, but it seemed to be accepted to eat your own picknick as well. There are many toilets all over the place, so no queues, which is nice when you visit with children. A huge parking can be found under the site, very convenient. Make sure you plan a full day here.

reviewnospace: Wandering around the City of Arts and Sciences (Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias) was a lovely way to spend our last morning in Valencia. We were completely in awe of the incredible design and sheer size of 9 buildings in this entertainment precinct. With construction starting in 1994, I was amazed at how incredibly modern and futuristic the buildings looked. We walked around for over an hour taking photos of every inch of this beautiful place, there are so many different camera angles you can fill a memory card up and still feel like you have captured enough to do the place justice. The city of arts and sciences is definitely a must see if ever in Valencia, even if you decide not to go inside the buildings, the place itself is worthwhile to spend an hour walking through.
titleopinion: Beautiful. Wandering around the City of Arts and Sciences (Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias) was a lovely way to spend our last morning in Valencia. We were completely in awe of the incredible design and sheer size of 9 buildings in this entertainment precinct. With construction starting in 1994, I was amazed at how incredibly modern and futuristic the buildings looked. We walked around for over an hour taking photos of every inch of this beautiful place, there are so many different camera angles you can fill a memory card up and still feel like you have captured enough to do the place justice. The city of arts and sciences is definitely a must see if ever in Valencia, even if you decide not to go inside the buildings, the place itself is worthwhile to spend an hour walking through.

reviewnospace: Big, nice looing, well kept, interesting, in excellent surroundings. The aquarium is for young and old!!!
titleopinion: It is a must. Big, nice looing, well kept, interesting, in excellent surroundings. The aquarium is for young and old!!!

quote: The architecture is excellent, the attractions are pretty good
reviewnospace: My visit to The City of Arts and Sciences in Valencia, Spain, was mainly to see firsthand the architectural work of Santiago Calatrava. As an architectural photography aficionado, I was not disappointed, and the beauty of the architectural concept of the entire space is fantastic. This is a site not to be missed, if this is what you seek. The events and attractions at The City were pretty good, but in the interest of full disclosure, I live and entertain myself in Southern California, and as such, have a huge variety of world class entertainment venues at my disposal, and the aquatic, scientific, and IMAX events available at home are hard to compete with. Nevertheless, I did attend the IMAX Hidden Universe showing and found it very interesting and entertaining, though the technical audio equipment is about a decade or so behind the IMAX equipment in California. This made it less impressive for me personally, but it was still quite adequate. The Science Museum is in need of a complete makeover- the displays were not impressive, and were mainly of high school or elementary school educational display quality. The reduced scale model of the European Space Agency's portions of the International Space Agency was my highlight, and that might not be enough to impress the average traveler. The Oceanografic was to be the high point of our visit- however, as I said before, California has Sea World in Mission Bay near San Diego, and it is difficult to compete on that scale. Oceanografic was still a very nice aquarium, in particular I enjoyed that all world continents and ocean environments were represented. We visited on a very hot and humid day, and the ability to duck into the air conditioned environments at the aquariums was welcome. The price was 32 euros per person for all 3 venues, purchased online with online discount. That price is probably reasonable, but in US dollars it feels a bit overpriced.
titleopinion: The architecture is excellent, the attractions are pretty good. My visit to The City of Arts and Sciences in Valencia, Spain, was mainly to see firsthand the architectural work of Santiago Calatrava. As an architectural photography aficionado, I was not disappointed, and the beauty of the architectural concept of the entire space is fantastic. This is a site not to be missed, if this is what you seek. The events and attractions at The City were pretty good, but in the interest of full disclosure, I live and entertain myself in Southern California, and as such, have a huge variety of world class entertainment venues at my disposal, and the aquatic, scientific, and IMAX events available at home are hard to compete with. Nevertheless, I did attend the IMAX Hidden Universe showing and found it very interesting and entertaining, though the technical audio equipment is about a decade or so behind the IMAX equipment in California. This made it less impressive for me personally, but it was still quite adequate. The Science Museum is in need of a complete makeover- the displays were not impressive, and were mainly of high school or elementary school educational display quality. The reduced scale model of the European Space Agency's portions of the International Space Agency was my highlight, and that might not be enough to impress the average traveler. The Oceanografic was to be the high point of our visit- however, as I said before, California has Sea World in Mission Bay near San Diego, and it is difficult to compete on that scale. Oceanografic was still a very nice aquarium, in particular I enjoyed that all world continents and ocean environments were represented. We visited on a very hot and humid day, and the ability to duck into the air conditioned environments at the aquariums was welcome. The price was 32 euros per person for all 3 venues, purchased online with online discount. That price is probably reasonable, but in US dollars it feels a bit overpriced.

reviewnospace:
At the seaward end of the park, we finds the City of Arts and Science an outstanding achievement of Spanish architects, began in 1995, which includes a number of buildings with such amazing architecture and size. It is integrated harmoniously into the landscape, the transition from the natural to the artificial being done gradually, replacing the green grass from TuriaPark with blue water green. At this moment are completed:
L'hemispherical form of the eye - an IMAX cinema and planetarium (access via underground);
Prince Felipe Science Museum - the shape of a dinosaur skeleton;
L'Umbracle - an alley with a structure that creates the feeling of a pavilion - has something of the structure of the main nave of the basilica Sagrada Familia;
L'Oceanographic - the largest oceanographic aquarium in Europe
Palace of Arts Reina Sofia - has four concert rooms,
Bridge L'Assut de l'Or - a spectacular achievement integrated harmoniously in the landscape and also in general note of the area. The main pillar has a height of 125 m;
Agora - a structure designed mainly for tennis tournaments, as well as for public events and other sport competitions.

reviewnospace:
We only visited the science museum and I thought it would be boring, but it was amazing. If you're Australian it's a bit like Questacon in Canberra, but better. From the kids in the inflatable anti gravity balls on the outdoor pool, to the DNA helix, the pendulum illustrating the earth's movement, and the interactive environmental show, there are a huge variety of models and hands on activities for all ages.
Part of the spectacular design of this whole precinct, it's worth a visit for the architecture alone.
titleopinion:
Spectacular inside and out. We only visited the science museum and I thought it would be boring, but it was amazing. If you're Australian it's a bit like Questacon in Canberra, but better. From the kids in the inflatable anti gravity balls on the outdoor pool, to the DNA helix, the pendulum illustrating the earth's movement, and the interactive environmental show, there are a huge variety of models and hands on activities for all ages.
Part of the spectacular design of this whole precinct, it's worth a visit for the architecture alone.

reviewnospace:
It's worth going to just to walk around the vast complex. The buildings are like something from a sci fi set and wouldn't look out of place in Astana. The umbracle makes for a pleasant walk. The science museum is good but probably better if you have lots of time and want to engross yourself. Plenty to keep kids entertained. Oceanographic was good, particularly the aquarium with the sharks and the long tunnel where the fish swim over your head. There's a dolphin show and other aquatic zones from around the world.
Recommend buying a tourist card at the airport which pays for between 24-72 hrs of metro but gets you a discount on entry to places like this and numerous others - was well worth it.

quote: not to miss if you are in Valencia
reviewnospace: Amazing buildings and public space around them! We did not have time (and desire) to visit the museums, but we went to the Citta twice in our 6-days stay in Valencia (and I would revisit it again). Beautiful, lively place with quiet nooks. Breathtaking sights. Nicely lit by night. Bravo to Calatrava! A must-see for sure.
titleopinion: not to miss if you are in Valencia. Amazing buildings and public space around them! Breathtaking sights. Nicely lit by night. Bravo to Calatrava! A must-see for sure.

reviewnospace:
Visited Valencia to view the futuristic buildings of the Arts and Science Park. Stayed in nearby excellent hotel - Medium Valencia so that we could visit at different times of the day to get sunset photographs and also the buildings lit up and not have to travel back to a town centre hotel in the dark with expensive camera equipment. Bus stop outside took us into old town for 1.5 euros, also taxi rank nearby.
The Imax has different shows throughout the day. The Opera House is expensive for shows but has a guided tour at 11am each morning. The Oceanografico needs a full day to see everything, we only had an afternoon and the main eating places were shut by the time we came to them. We did not have time for inside the science museum but were told it is very good for children. The outside of the buildings, walkways and parkland are all free and in March when we went they were almost deserted except for others taking photos. Bridges take you above the buildings and pools of water surround them with lovely reflections especially at night. Beware that unless there are events in the evening the buildings are not lit up, we were lucky with a concert at the Opera House and an event in the Imax. Large shopping centre nearby for rainy days and food outlets.
titleopinion:

This is a fantastic experience , the museum was great for all ages and the Oceanografico is the most amazing aquarium in Europe and especially the night dolphin show is amazing , a crossover between synchronized swimming , ballet , acrobatics and a dolphin show !

reviewnospace:
Though my stay in valencia was very short i fell in love with this quiet & beautiful city with its wide tree lined roads & wonderful buildings.The City of Arts & sciences was just a few minutes of crossing a single road from my NH Las Artes Hotel ! It was an impressive example of modern architecture.i had divided my visit here by visiting my Fave Oceanografic earlier & now i devoted my time to the remaining beautiful buildings housing the other fields-opera house & performing arts center,Imax Cinema,planetorium,Laserium,garden & finally the Science Museum.The last building is the Agora which holds various events,conventions etc.

It was great to take a walk both in the morning & evening along these futuristic buildings with impressive architecture & open spaces surrounded by beautiful pools of cool water!
titleopinion:
Arts & Sciences In Harmony!. It was great to take a walk both in the morning & evening along these futuristic buildings with impressive architecture & open spaces surrounded by beautiful pools of cool water!

quote: Brilliant architecture, not so brilliant museum
reviewnospace:
This is definitely a place you have to go to if you go to Valencia, the architecture is amazing, everything goes in harmony, truly stunning.

The visit obviously doesn't stop at that, this is a review based on the science part only, I didn't go in the aquarium or other activities offered.

After doing a few science museums, I thought this would be the daddy of them all. It wasn't.

Most of the experiments are broken, there is quite a lot of repetition in there, the only real interactive part is the part where you walk in, the rest might as well not be visited as it's very dated.

It should take about 2 hours to do we were told, it took us under an hour. There is a lot of space that is not developed and it could really have potential, just not exploited to the max.

After hearing other people talking, the other parts are meant to be amazing, the aquarium is meant to take up to 4 hours to look around, unbelievable.

All in all, it's a great place to visit for photos, but the science part is to be avoided if you are into interactive experiments.

reviewnospace: The entire area is well used by visitors and citizens throughout the day so it always feels like something is going on. There is loads of space, so if it's a quiet walk or a bike ride you fancy or a visit to a formal attraction (the aquarium and the science museum are highly recommended) there is something for you. The architecture is stunning, amazing, strange, wonderful and imaginative. Such a great contrast to the rest of Valencia.

The architecture is stunning, amazing, strange, wonderful and imaginative. Such a great contrast to the rest of Valencia.

reviewnospace: Went to arts and sciences for the day. Firstly like other reviews say- it's worth the visit to see the buildings even if you don't go inside. We went to the museum, oceanographic aquarium and the cinema hemispheric and they were all great. Long day however, yes you will need the whole day to do all three but you can space it over 2 or 3 days I believe. If I were to pick one over the other though I would first choose to do aquarium (the dolphin show was cool!) then second hemispheric ( look at movie times and make sure you are early and get your ticket changed if you have a multi pass ticket - you can only see one movie under this) lastly the museum - there is a lot to see- very cool though- different to other museums!

reviewnospace:
What an amazing place - to see it appear as we cycled there was great! Massive structures, very impressive! But it did seem a bit like a big white elephant - superb spaces that seemed tired and under used. The museum and Oceanographic were the 2 we chose to buy tickets for - 100 euros for the 4 of us (a one use ticket, once you've been into one you cannot go back!) - and the museum was a little sparse - there were some interesting and interactive exhibits but not a patch on the Science Museum in London. We did eat in the cafe at the museum - I would rate this as OK. The Oceanagraphique was good - plenty of amazing fish and animals, the dolphin display was good (is this conservation through commercialism?) although I don't necessarily agree with it. The "under sea" walk ways were brilliant.
There were other buildings - the Hemispheric - what a space and what a space with nothing going on! The "winter garden" above the car park was good but only half open. All in all I was glad that we went as the buildings alone were great but I wouldn't pay to "go in" again.
titleopinion:

reviewnospace: The architecture of this collection of buildings is unbelievable. At the least, one should come here to walk around the outside and take in the beautiful facades. There is kayaking and other water activities in the water area outside of the science building, but i didn't partake in that. I went to the science building and oceanografic building. The science building was certainly interesting, with many different exhibits covering everything from electricity to DNA. I will admit that this building seemed to cater more toward children and their learning. I even saw a couple of class field trips inside. Everyone will find something interesting in the Science building, but i was ready to leave after about one hour. The oceanografic complex was much more interesting to me. They have different exhibits separated by the animals' region. Parts of the park served as entertainment venues, like the dolphin shows. But others seems focused more on marine science. So it really is up to you what your experience is here. In total, i was at the city less than three hours and felt completely satisfied with what i saw. This attraction should absolutely not be missed as the architecture is insane and certainly unique, but the content in the buildings is worth the visit, but not amazing.

reviewnospace: This is what is best in Valencia and should not be missed at any cost. Built by Santiago Calatrava, the whole place is a collection of beautiful examples of architecture. Apart from the beautiful views and the gardens and water bodies it also houses lots of information and each building is dedicated to various sections. It easily eats up half of your day so keep a good amount of time for this alone. Also be armed with a whole lot of memory space for your camera because this is a photographer’s paradise.

reviewnospace: Santiago Calatrava certainly has done his hometown proud with the incredible designs he created for the City of Arts and Sciences. The buildings are stunning and in dramatic contrast to the old world colonial designs found throughout Spain. There are so many spectacular photographic angles that you can fill up a photo card and still not feel as if you've done the place justice. Take the time to go inside the Agora to see the exhibit on how each building or element was designed and built. To be honest, I chose to visit Valencia largely because of these buildings. I was not disappointed, and I don't believe you will be either.

reviewnospace:
Valencia!!! A month of staying here is not enough to see everything.
Great place, great photos. Visited cinema ( 3 of my friends fell asleep in the middle, I don't know why, it was GREAT film about science, different types of vision and so on) Oceanografic great too. Big one, with sharks and rays, funny seals and belugas.. Children are very happy there. We didn't have time for the museum and other attractions. We went there 2 times - evening and morning next day. (you can by ticket for 2 or 3 attractions and it's cheaper. you can mark the dates. For example - cinema today, oceanographic and science museum tomorrow) It will take the whole day to visit everything. Better plan at least 2 days. It's ideal like we did - about 6 in the evening we managed to go to hemisphere, saw the sunset and the beauty of the place at night ( there are nice cafe in front of the museum and attraction for children in the pool) and next morning we came for the rest.

(you can by ticket for 2 or 3 attractions and it's cheaper. you can mark the dates. For example - cinema today, oceanographic and science museum tomorrow) It will take the whole day to visit everything. Better plan at least 2 days. It's ideal like we did - about 6 in the evening we managed to go to hemisphere, saw the sunset and the beauty of the place at night ( there are nice cafe in front of the museum and attraction for children in the pool) and next morning we came for the rest.

reviewnospace: Wandered around for good couple of hours just staring at the stunning designs. 100s of photos to review now to prove it!
titleopinion: Beautiful Architecture. Wandered around for good couple of hours just staring at the stunning designs. 100s of photos to review now to prove it!

reviewnospace: We did not go back into any of the buildings this time. However, the architecture is impressive and worth a stroll down the sidewalk to see them from different angles.

reviewnospace: a must see! Especially the oceanographic and the science museum, you can buy a combined ticket and also save a little, but it is definitely worth of every euro.

reviewnospace: If you come to Valencia, you have to go here. This place is so futuristic and so modern. I even got to see George Clooney filming a movie here, that was lucky. reviewnospace: I visited the city of arts and science december 2013. Hemisferic is worth a visit, interesting documentary films. You can also visit Oceanografic and the museum of art and science (You can buy one ticket including all these attractions).

reviewnospace: We were really impressed by the architecture ot this complex. It consists of several buildings. The area is quite extended, so reserve a full day, if you want to visit everything.
titleopinion: Impressive architecture!. We were really impressed by the architecture ot this complex. It consists of several buildings. The area is quite extended, so reserve a full day, if you want to visit everything.

reviewnospace: The City of Arts and Sciences is a MUST if you visit Valencia. We are a family of 4 (3 years old and 5 years old) and it was a wonderful experience for the whole family. The Aquarium is amazing, the dolphin show great and we spend there the whole day. We visited the Science museum the next day and we were fascinated by the many interactive activities available with the kids. We spend there the whole day and we took the opportunity also to take a ride with the "train" situated just outside the museum around the park. Really nice.

reviewnospace: I simply loved the short time I had to spend. It is aesthetically amazing inside and out. There are plenty of interesting and mind boggling exhibitions. A must see!!!!
titleopinion: Absolutely spectacular. I simply loved the short time I had to spend. It is aesthetically amazing inside and out. There are plenty of interesting and mind boggling exhibitions. A must see!!!!

quote: stunning - even if you don't go in the buildings!
reviewnospace: We walked through the park that houses these buildings three times - the first two to get to the beach. On the third visit, we went "through" the buildings rather than around - and they are stunning!! Every angle is a "must take photo". There was a photo exhibition in one of the buildings - which was good - so, even if you don't go in, go for a walk!! The path that goes around them, that is, through the park, just doesn't give you the same views or appreciation.

reviewnospace:
As we haven't actually gone in the museums housed at the City of Arts and Sciences, this review is only on the merits of the complex's architecture. On that topic alone, it's worth a half-day visit if you're into modern architecture.

The complex--designed by architects Santiago Calatrava and Félix Candela and completed in 1998--is a soaring modern marvel, with concrete buttresses, glass, and expansive emerald shallow pools, and the most unique suspension bridge on the planet. The day we visited (July, 2014) was overcast, so we plan to return before we leave Valencia to get some brighter pictures: I imagine the sunny buildings reflected in the pools to make for superb photos.

The adjacent Palau de les Artes Reina Sofia, looking like a space ship just landed out of a Star Wars movie, would be a perfect compliment to the City of Arts and Sciences except for it's rusting metal side. Or then again, is it supposed to be like that?

Note: there's no fee for wandering around the exterior and grounds of the complex, only for entering the museums.
titleopinion:
Great Destination for Architecture Buffs. As we haven't actually gone in the museums housed at the City of Arts and Sciences, this review is only on the merits of the complex's architecture. On that topic alone, it's worth a half-day visit if you're into modern architecture.

reviewnospace: Didn't spend long here, but lots of interesting things to see and do. The buildings themselves are very unusual and worth seeing, if nothing else.

quote: Guided tour by Valeria Valdebenito of AMBIA TOURS
reviewnospace: If you would like a guided tour of this city I would recommend Valeria Valdebenito She has that personal touch,She was very informative and as a native of the city she just knew everything you wanted to know plus more!As we were on a cruise she was restricted by our schedule time ashore but she left that taste with me for to return for more. We visit so many places and leave without kowing too much where we have been!

reviewnospace: I just read that the City of the Arts and Sciences occupies a space of a little less than 2 km. and I believe it! We saw some folks bicycling (I think you can rent them there) and that would be the best way to get around as there is indeed a lot of walking. One must try to visit from one end of the complex to the other - from the Palau de les Arts to the Oceanografic. We went to the Palau de les Artes and just missed the tour. It is in the morning, but I'm sorry I can't find my notes regarding the times and days. It is a fantastic structure and I'm sure well worth going on the tour - I think there is a small fee. There are long, stunning pools in the center of the complex - so many wonderful photo opportunities. There are places to eat, restrooms and gift shops. We didn't visit the Oceanografic as we had come from Lisbon and went to the Aquarium there, but it seems there are several buildings, each featuring fish from different oceans/parts of the world. Even if you just walk around, it is well worth a visit.

Really nice by sun set!
It's great to walk and enjoy all the different views from so many angles.. Just from the outside is enough, most things are quite expensive.

reviewnospace: I know of few ( any?) places in the world with such a beautiful public investment in the arts and sciences. I'm no curator, and can't judge the content of the exhibits and displays, but the buildings and public spaces created to house them is unsurpassed. This is truly a global gem that should not be missed on a visit to Valencia.
titleopinion: A spectacular public investment!. I know of few ( any?) places in the world with such a beautiful public investment in the arts and sciences. I'm no curator, and can't judge the content of the exhibits and displays, but the buildings and public spaces created to house them is unsurpassed. This is truly a global gem that should not be missed on a visit to Valencia.

quote: allow more time than you think
reviewnospace:
we were visiting with our 6yo son, who is VERY easily bored, so we weren't sure how long he would last.
HOWEVER, we spent over 4 hours, looking at everything we could, and still hadn't seen everything... he was very upset that we had to leave, as it had reached closing time.
the exhibits were very interactive, and kept my sons attention much longer than expected. we found that there was adequate english language signage to keep us informed about each display, and loved the way you could actually get hands on with many of them.
this was one of our favourite attractions in Valencia!

reviewnospace:
Massive space but not much in it. Most of the exhibits were hard to follow as the English was very brief compared with the Spanish text. Our kids enjoyed it to some extent but would not wish to go back.
Might be good if you take in all the facilities of the centre including acquarium.
titleopinion:
science centre not great. Massive space but not much in it. Most of the exhibits were hard to follow as the English was very brief compared with the Spanish text. Our kids enjoyed it to some extent but would not wish to go back.
Might be good if you take in all the facilities of the centre including acquarium.

quote: Great piece of architecture, nice museum
reviewnospace:
As you can see from the pictures it is a great piece of architecture. The fish-like structures look as futuristic in real life as they look in the pictures, partly enforced by the open space with great 'pools' surrounding the building. The only problem I had with the outside: it needs maintenance pretty bad (rust on the planes that should be spotless and the 'pools' are dirty in some places).

The science museum is fun, but not everything is interesting. There are 3,5 floors, of which 2,5 with exhibitions. The first floor is the best: a kid-friendly, hands on approach (literally: take hand sanitizer with you) to the science behind everyday objects. I don't have kids, but I would take them here if I did. And it's definitly not only for kids: even adults can refresh/expand their knowledge ;)
They also had a part about furniture, but i found it quite uninteresting.

The floor between the first and the topfloor consist of prices, awards and certificates of people that won Nobel-prizes. I think that unless you knew these people before you visited, you (like us) would take the escalator to te next floor right away.

The top floor is divided in 'chromosomes' and 'space'. The chromosomes part had lots of information on little signs, but it felt to me like reading a biology textbook instead of being 'immersed in the world of chromosomes'. For us it was too much information to be entertaining.

The space-part was filled with scale-models and had a (temporary?) walk-in exhibition supported by the ESA with a timeline of the universe. Personally this was one of my favorite parts.

Throughout the museum there were things to play with: ideal for when mum and dad want to read something without someone hanging on their sleeves.

Clearly the building was designed for it's exterior, because there were many open, useless spaces in the museum. Hanging a fighter jet, a hot air balloon, a Wright-brothers airplane and Davinci's flightmachine helped filling it, but it was still pretty weird.

All in all a must-see (buildings) and a must do (the museum)!

reviewnospace: I liked the buildings, the space around it but unfortunately these buildings need to be maintained and it looks like there is no money for it - pity!

reviewnospace: No visit to Valencia would be complete without visiting the Ciudad de las artes y las ciencias - be prepared for a long, tiring day. Be aware that the food inside is expensive but there are some excellent cafés and restaurants across the road at a fraction of the price.

reviewnospace: Very interesting modern architecture. Easy walk ( but it is a quite long walk) back from the center of Valencia

reviewnospace:

There is a great play area for young children where they can try their building and climbing skills.
Beautiful setting and a fabulous building.

It's a shame that many of the science exhibit were not working when we were there. Still, the buildings were jaw dropping.

reviewnospace:
The city of arts and sciences is quite nice, interesting buildings and the aquarium is wonderful!
Definately go early in the day to beat the crowds, easy to get to by bus. Lots of places to eat nearby and an easy walk ( but it is a long walk) back to the old section of Valencia.

Valencia for three days. The city of arts and sciences is quite nice, interesting buildings and the aquarium is wonderful!
Definately go early in the day to beat the crowds, easy to get to by bus. Lots of places to eat nearby and an easy walk ( but it is a long walk) back to the old section of Valencia.

reviewnospace: It is definitely worth a visit to see these beautiful buildings. We were last here 14 years ago and only one part was completed at the time. We did not go into them this time but the architecture alone is impressive.
titleopinion: Worth a visit. It is definitely worth a visit to see these beautiful buildings. We were last here 14 years ago and only one part was completed at the time. We did not go into them this time but the architecture alone is impressive.

reviewnospace: Set in the wonderful Turia Gardens park (what used to be the main river in Valencia till it was diverted), the City of the Arts and Sciences is a great destination if you are wandering from the old city through the park. Anyone that appreciates modern architecture (like me) would be wowed by this place and its arrangement of buildings and bridges comprising the opera house, science museum, auditorium, oceanarium, imax cinema and more. Just go, stare, and take a good camera for capturing these stunning buildings against that stunning Valencia blue sky!
titleopinion: Calatrava's masterpiece. Set in the wonderful Turia Gardens park (what used to be the main river in Valencia till it was diverted), the City of the Arts and Sciences is a great destination if you are wandering from the old city through the park. Anyone that appreciates modern architecture (like me) would be wowed by this place and its arrangement of buildings and bridges comprising the opera house, science museum, auditorium, oceanarium, imax cinema and more. Just go, stare, and take a good camera for capturing these stunning buildings against that stunning Valencia blue sky!

quote: Pinch Yourself, This is Spain, not USA
reviewnospace:
When we started our long walk to the city of sciences it was more of destination to encourage exercise but when we got there WOW.
It is big, it is brash, it is engaging and I loved it.
The form and structure of the buildings are akin to those you see in rich cities such as Dubai, Qatar and LA, yet you are in Spain.

There is one price for entry to everything, a steep €29 each but well worth it. Take a visit one of the theme restaurants and that will set you back a further €80 ish so it is by no means a cheap date.

I have seen many aquariums but none as good as this one. We saw species never seen before the cutest of these being a Sawfish.
Just take the full tour, enjoy lunch and soak up the brilliant atmosphere.

quote: Museo de Las Sciencias and Oceanographic.
reviewnospace: Bought tickets for the Museo de las Sciencias Principe Filipe and the Oceanographic. Visited the Oceanographic first and we were very impressed by everything on show here. Great dolphin show. Small sharks, whales, tropical fish etc. Great assortment. However, the Museum of Sciences was very disappointing. Lots of the exhibits not working. Probably at least half of the interactive ones. Waste of money. It could be good but sadly is seriously neglected.
titleopinion: Museo de Las Sciencias and Oceanographic.. Bought tickets for the Museo de las Sciencias Principe Filipe and the Oceanographic. Visited the Oceanographic first and we were very impressed by everything on show here. Great dolphin show. Small sharks, whales, tropical fish etc. Great assortment. However, the Museum of Sciences was very disappointing. Lots of the exhibits not working. Probably at least half of the interactive ones. Waste of money. It could be good but sadly is seriously neglected.

reviewnospace: Spectacular structures! Definitely worth visiting. We have mainly walked outdoors to enjoy the stunning views from different sites of the construction.
titleopinion: What a place!. Spectacular structures! Definitely worth visiting. We have mainly walked outdoors to enjoy the stunning views from different sites of the construction.

reviewnospace: You can buy tickets to go to 3 parts of the city - the Hemisperic, the Museo de las Sciencias Principe Filipe and the Oceanographic. If I were you, I'd just buy a ticket for the Oceonagraphic. The Henispheric is an IMAX cinema which shows films every day (but unless your Spanish is very good, there's not much point in going). The Museo is full of interactive exhibits and would be great for kids, if only half the stuff weren't broken down (and the food prices in the canteen!). The Oceanographic is a sealife centre - lots of acquaria, sea lions, dolphins (plus shows at 15:45 and 18:15). There's a lot to see (going through the tunnels under some of the tanks was very impressive), so give yourselves at least 2-3 hours to get through it all.
titleopinion: Externally - wow! Internally - wot?. You can buy tickets to go to 3 parts of the city - the Hemisperic, the Museo de las Sciencias Principe Filipe and the Oceanographic.
