I would not waste my money again on the exhibition but I would definitely recommend a visit to marvel at the architecture.

reviewnospace:
The City of Arts and Sciences in Valencia is one of Europe's very best modern public works. It is a series of unbelievable pieces of architecture in a stunning watery surround. City of Arts and Sciences compares favourably with public works of any era and is an incredible monument to the artistic and architectural ambition of the Valencians.

The City is located at the southern end of the Turia Gardens. It is a nice but quite long walk to get there. Unfortunately the City was not accompanied by a metro station. There are some buses including a tourist transfer to and from the beach.

For those who can make it, access is generally pretty good. Each of the buidings is accessible though a surprisingly high proportion of the lifts were out of order especially from street level to entry level. A long curved ramp provides secondary access for those who don't do stairs.

Taking the route in from the Turia the first building is the opera. It is incredible but it is just the first architectural masterpiece. It is so impressive to see so many great pieces of modern architecture lined up one after the other. The strong steel, the clean pale colour, the calming influence of the water create an almost science fiction-like feel of modern beauty.

One slight negative is the route from the back of the science museum to the aquarium. There is a route that keeps on going through the City but annoyingly the signpost takes the traveller up to street level and across a main road, clearly spoiling the idyllic atmosphere. Also in this section is the Agora event centre, easily the worst maintained of the buildings. The Agora is only five years old but looks a little rough around the edges already.

The final piece of the City is the aquarium, a fine and ambitious aquatic zoo though not quite offering the majesty of the other external features.

These great and clearly expensive buildings exist in a country struggling to repay its debts. They are artistic masterpieces but inside it is not so great. The internal presentation is only good and does not match what is on the outside. For the traveller experiencing something like this for the first time the internal is much less of an issue but it does speak to the priorities accorded to style over substance.

The City of Arts and Sciences is probably Valencia's most well-known tourist attraction. It is worth a visit for sure as the structural visages are simply incredible.
titleopinion:
Magnificent Municipal Monuments. The City of Arts and Sciences in Valencia is one of Europe's very best modern public works. It is a series of unbelievable pieces of architecture in a stunning watery surround. City of Arts and Sciences compares favourably with public works of any era and is an incredible monument to the artistic and architectural ambition of the Valencians.

The City is located at the southern end of the Turia Gardens. It is a nice but quite long walk to get there. Unfortunately the City was not accompanied by a metro station. There are some buses including a tourist transfer to and from the beach.

For those who can make it, access is generally pretty good. Each of the buidings is accessible though a surprisingly high proportion of the lifts were out of order especially from street level to entry level. A long curved ramp provides secondary access for those who don't do stairs.

Taking the route in from the Turia the first building is the opera. It is incredible but it is just the first architectural masterpiece. It is so impressive to see so many great pieces of modern architecture lined up one after the other. The strong steel, the clean pale colour, the calming influence of the water create an almost science fiction-like feel of modern beauty.

One slight negative is the route from the back of the science museum to the aquarium. There is a route that keeps on going through the City but annoyingly the signpost takes the traveller up to street level and across a main road, clearly spoiling the idyllic atmosphere. Also in this section is the Agora event centre, easily the worst maintained of the buildings. The Agora is only five years old but looks a little rough around the edges already.

The final piece of the City is the aquarium, a fine and ambitious aquatic zoo though not quite offering the majesty of the other external features.

These great and clearly expensive buildings exist in a country struggling to repay its debts. They are artistic masterpieces but inside it is not so great. The internal presentation is only good and does not match what is on the outside. For the traveller experiencing something like this for the first time the internal is much less of an issue but it does speak to the priorities accorded to style over substance.

The City of Arts and Sciences is probably Valencia's most well-known tourist attraction. It is worth a visit for sure as the structural visages are simply incredible.

reviewnospace:
The architecture is simply stunning. You just can't imagine that you are only a few meters from the old town.
I bought a ticket for all attractions (aquarium, science museum and IMAX). The aquarium was great. Many interesting animals, a few good and cheap restaurants and nice souvenir shops.
IMAX was also very nice but the science museum was a huge disappointment. Although situated in the most spectacular of all building it is almost empty inside. Few idiotic exhibits are the only thing that can be related with the science. Most of the exhibits that should be interactive are out of order. What's more the staff at the caffe is lazy and rude. Even the souvenir shop was disappointing. They had books about City of the Arts and Sciences and about Calatrava only in SPANISH.

reviewnospace: I love this city, Valencia is one of the best cities in the world and the City of Arts and Sciences is just what it says in the title. There are museums, opera house, sports areas, performing arts centre, IMAX cinema, science museum, planetarium, laserium and an array of various displays. The Oceanographic is very close and is the largest aquapark in Europe. The whole area is so full of interest that a week would only touch the surface and it should not be forgotten that Valencia has many other attractions too.

quote: This is about the city Valencia
reviewnospace:
Since I have no option of giving a review just for the city of Valencia, I am doing it here as I know it will be viewed by anyone who is planning on a trip there via Tripadvisor.
This is about the gorgeous city of Valencia -
I call it a boutique city. To sum it up in brief:
the architecture is exquisite
the Mercado Central is impressive
the city evokes class. I reckon it is or was a rich city
the shopping great; the fact that it is not a huge city and shopping streets are concentrated in one cluster makes it so convenient
the dry bed of river Turia that is turned into a recreational park impressed me the most. To have kilometres of green space with no traffic within city limits is a huge bonus for the citizens and tourists alike. I envy them for that
the city of science and arts was impressive, the architecture very grand. We were most impressed with the aquarium, Europe's largest. However, the same couldn't be said about the science centre. It felt like they had way too much space to build this massive structure but failed to fill it up with anything that is spectacular enough to write home about
the Zoo was spacious and has a good varieties of animals
the beach wasn't all that great. In fact, there was no life. Perhaps because it was only April end. But even so, I wasn't impressed
the biggest drawback I noticed is that there are too many dog poops. You have to really watch out while walking. We saw a man slipping on it in the middle of a pedestrian path. I felt so sorry for him. And in the park, you have to really watch out too. Perhaps, dog owners should be more considerate to clean after their "babies"
Have I recommended Valencia to friends? - Oh! I've done it to almost everybody I bumped into :-)
Will I visit again? - Definitely

reviewnospace: The Ciudad des las Artes y de las Ciencias (City of the Arts and Sciences) is a fairly recent addition to the cultural life of Valencia, and the large site on the port also includes a performing arts centre, a large aquarium and various other institutions. The structures have a dramatic architectural interest all by themselves, similar to Frank Gehry's art museum in Bilbao. We only had time to visit the "City", and it was time well spent. It compares well with the science museum at La Villette in the north of Paris, including the multi-lingual "Explainers" who enhance the experience. There were lots of kids enjoying the interactive exhibits and learning some basic science painlessly. For an extra 4 euros, this space nerd, and his uncomplaining partner, also went on a Space Academy simulation, which was amazing fun. Highly recommended.
titleopinion: Amazing cultural complex in Valencia. The Ciudad des las Artes y de las Ciencias (City of the Arts and Sciences) is a fairly recent addition to the cultural life of Valencia, and the large site on the port also includes a performing arts centre, a large aquarium and various other institutions. The structures have a dramatic architectural interest all by themselves, similar to Frank Gehry's art museum in Bilbao. We only had time to visit the "City", and it was time well spent. It compares well with the science museum at La Villette in the north of Paris, including the multi-lingual "Explainers" who enhance the experience. There were lots of kids enjoying the interactive exhibits and learning some basic science painlessly. For an extra 4 euros, this space nerd, and his uncomplaining partner, also went on a Space Academy simulation, which was amazing fun. Highly recommended.

reviewnospace:
We got a head's up from friends who were at the CIty and said the museum was primarily for kids so we only went to the Oceanografic. The place is marvelous. You can see fish from tropicals to sharks, mammals such as whales and seals, and of course the obligatory penguins. The place is huge-certainly the largest facility of this type that I have ever been in.It is well worth the trip.
Getting there early will provide you with free street parking, although the walk from your spot may take a while. I did not check out public transportation, but it does exist. Avoiding weekends will prevent long lines at the ticket office. We had to go on a Saturday and the queue was about 15 minutes.
If you like this type of place, give yourself about three hours minimum to walk around. There is plenty of food vending inside for a quick lunch or dinner. We loved watching the belugas and the seals swim around. You can view them from eye level or from above. All in all, an awesome way to spend a day..
titleopinion:
Awesome!. We got a head's up from friends who were at the CIty and said the museum was primarily for kids so we only went to the Oceanografic. The place is marvelous. You can see fish from tropicals to sharks, mammals such as whales and seals, and of course the obligatory penguins. quote: Incredible views and architecture - lots of photo ops
reviewnospace:
This was my main reason for returning to Valencia after a day trip years ago. Buildings are stylish, unique, and make you feel so relaxed. Opera house tour was very fascinating. Love the garden covering the underground parking garage. Blue tiled exhaust vents from the garage resemble old ship smoke stacks. Amazing what they could do with an old diverted river bed; something other cities should do when they get tired of persistent flooding from rivers thru the center of town.

Perfect contemporary complement to the old buildings of Valencia.

reviewnospace: Good enough to spend 4-5 hours with children. The architecture of the building is impressive. Inside only part of the available space has been used for this interactive museum where children can experience and learn about science. Some experiments need renewal, but it’s ok to spend some time. Food inside the Museum is expensive. The “Space Academy” experience (sold as a “gravity cero” experience) is not worthy.
titleopinion: Good Museum. Good enough to spend 4-5 hours with children. The architecture of the building is impressive. Inside only part of the available space has been used for this interactive museum where children can experience and learn about science. Some experiments need renewal, but it’s ok to spend some time. Food inside the Museum is expensive. The “Space Academy” experience (sold as a “gravity cero” experience) is not worthy.

reviewnospace:
Amusing, educational and very well balanced in terms of exhibiton and testing and experimenting.
Didnt like the chicklets idea, although it was generating constantly big crowds and was educational for the kids.

reviewnospace: The buildings of the City of the Arts and Sciences are breathtaking. The architecture is amazing!! Totally worth a visit, especially in a sunny day! You will take great pictures there!
titleopinion: Great Architecture!!. The buildings of the City of the Arts and Sciences are breathtaking. The architecture is amazing!! Totally worth a visit, especially in a sunny day! You will take great pictures there!

reviewnospace: Amazing! Big, cultural, good, the best thing is the oceanografic. The compless, designed by Santiago calatrava is the best building in. The world

reviewnospace:
If you visit Valencia with kids and they get tired of sightseeing or shopping or spending time over tapas at the restaurants your good bet for attracting their attention would be The City of Science.

It is one of those hands on experience scince exhibitions which will definitely catch attention of the whole family. There is a decent restaurant on site ( healthy food choice, not only fast food !) , a playground and places to rest.

Dont go to the Hemisphere if you have been to Imax type of theaters before. Unless for the architecture of the building.

A perfect indoor activity in the rare case of rain.

It;s must see!

reviewnospace: A superbly designed complex of buildings by Santiago Calatrava, the well known local architect. It is a very contemporary and exciting design surrounded by water. Go see the incredible and beautiful suspension bridge in the middle of the complex. Well worth wandering round and taking lots of photos from different angles!

Well worth wandering round and taking lots of photos from different angles!

reviewnospace: We only had a few moments to get close to the museum. People were a little rude so we opted not to go into museum. We were also told that certain areas were shut down. Kind of a bummer since they seem to pride themselves of this museum.

quote: Oceanogràfic was the best part for me
reviewnospace:
We had one day in Valencia as it was a cruise stop for us. Whist others might prefer a walk around the city or a bike tour; we decided to spend the day here. We just got a cab there and back.

We bought tickets to go into the Science Museum and the Oceanogràfic. Which were €29.70 each. We visited Oceanogràfic for the first half of our day and I loved it. We watched a dolphin show (all in Spanish but that didn’t matter) saw all types of ocean animals from seals to penguins. The aquariums were breathtaking and gigantic, they had sharks and whales inside and such an array of sea creatures I could have spent the day just there.

In the afternoon we went to the Science Museum. I did not enjoy this as much. It was far too hot inside and some of the areas were closed off. For me it was nothing to write home about.
Just walking around the area was breathtaking, what amazing design and architecture. There are so many places for you to just sit and take in the scenery. It is suitable for people in wheelchairs or people with pushchairs and opposite a shopping centre were you can get food or drinks (or clothes) if you need to.

quote: Good science display in a wonderful building
reviewnospace:
Perhaps a little generous with the scores but this was a good quality experience.

But a combo ticket to reduce costs (2 or 3 attractions). Get the kids to bring their school student ID for discounts also.

Be aware most things are explained only in Spanish - so time to practice.

I liked the big pendulum showing rotation of the globe !

reviewnospace:
We have been here several times, and every time it is just as beautiful as the previous time. My first suggestion would be to get some information on "City of the Arts and Sciences", whether it is in the form of a tour book or tour guide. Not just seeing the buildings but knowing about them makes the place even more fascinating. You can get some really beautiful pictures at night.
Just one FYI, the metro does not stop near here, but the hop on and hop off bus has a route that does stop here.
titleopinion:

My first suggestion would be to get some information on "City of the Arts and Sciences", whether it is in the form of a tour book or tour guide. reviewnospace:
The Hemisferic 3D theater provides wonderful science-related projections, and the intriguing physics experiments you can interact with in the Príncipe Felipe Science Museum are sure to be a wonderful treat for both children, as well as for the inquisitive adult.

At the same time, you will be left in amazement by the surreal aesthetics of the complex, reflecting a trademark Calatrava design.
titleopinion:
For one and for all.... The Hemisferic 3D theater provides wonderful science-related projections, and the intriguing physics experiments you can interact with in the Príncipe Felipe Science Museum are sure to be a wonderful treat for both children, as well as for the inquisitive adult.

At the same time, you will be left in amazement by the surreal aesthetics of the complex, reflecting a trademark Calatrava design.

reviewnospace: Just go and take a walk around this place, its stunning :-) its like being on the set of a futuristic film set. Plenty of places to sit and just take in the architecture. Great place to visit and great place to spend a afternoon trying to figure out how they built all those wonderful angles and shapes, enjoy :-)
titleopinion: Stunning !. Just go and take a walk around this place, its stunning :-) its like being on the set of a futuristic film set. Plenty of places to sit and just take in the architecture. Great place to visit and great place to spend a afternoon trying to figure out how they built all those wonderful angles and shapes, enjoy :-)

Full of school groups as well. I'd save my money and take pictures of the buliding from the outside but go to the aquarium down the road, which is better value for money.

Full of school groups as well. I'd save my money and take pictures of the buliding from the outside but go to the aquarium down the road, which is better value for money.

A group of daring buildings that fit together in perfect harmony and are a delight to wander around and appreciate. As one might expect from the presence of Oceanografic, water plays an integral part in blending the buildings together.

quote: Nice building, not so great as a museum.
reviewnospace: Very good choice for kids and schools, but not very interesting for adults tourists. The gat design raised the bar a bit too much perhaps, and i was expecting more.

reviewnospace: The city of arts and sciences lies in the Jardin del Turia, the beautiful city park. The Calatrava architecture is very impressive. You must certainly take the guided tour in the opera house.
titleopinion: Certainly worth a visit. The city of arts and sciences lies in the Jardin del Turia, the beautiful city park. The Calatrava architecture is very impressive. You must certainly take the guided tour in the opera house.

reviewnospace: The City of Arts and Sciences was worth a visit, at a minimum, to take a look at the buildings. It's modern and distinctly different from other attractions you will see in Spain. The science museum has mostly Spanish, so it didn't work as well for me. The Oceanophafic (I was told) the best aquarium for Europe. Size wise, it's not big, but you do see different things. I like the dolphins and the birds areas the best. If you have a few hours, it's worth a visit.
titleopinion: Nice modern architecture. The City of Arts and Sciences was worth a visit, at a minimum, to take a look at the buildings. reviewnospace: Plenty to occupy yourself for about 3 - 4 hours, but could be shortened or extended depending on your particular interests
titleopinion: Short visit. Plenty to occupy yourself for about 3 - 4 hours, but could be shortened or extended depending on your particular interests

quote: City of Arts and Sciences, Valencia, Spain
reviewnospace:
Ciudad de Las Artes y Las Ciencias is an amazing marriage of art, science and mathematics
created by architects Santiago Calatrava and Felix Candela. It is one of those places that when you visit it stuns you with the unexpected and delights you with the awe of it's beauty. Approaching the complex from the El Pont de l'Assut de l'Or (suspension bridg) you are surrounded by gardens and water features. The l'Agora, a covered plaza, hosts concerts and sporting events like the Valencia Open 500. The L'Umbracle (2001) features indigenous plants and "Walk of the Sculptures". Yoko Ono has a piece on display. The oldest contstructed building is the L'Hemisferic (1998) which has a digital 3D screen which is 12 x 6 meters. Amazing viewing experience. There is also a planetarium housed in the building. . It costs about 9 Euros. L' Oceanographic (2003) has a variety of ocean environments with beluga whales, walrus, sharks and rays. Each environment is connected by tunnels which allow you to see the sea creatures above and to the side of you. It is the largest aquarium in Europe. It costs about 28 Euros. El Museu de les Ciencies Principe Felipes is the science museum. There are three floors. The 2nd and 3rd floor have science exhibits and it costs 8 Euros. Finally there is the El Palau de les Artes Sofia (2005) is a helmet shaped building. It hosts opera and other performing arts while you sit in leather seats designed by Ferrari. They offer online combination tickets of many kinds. Oceanographic, Hemisferic and Science Museum for 36.25 Euro. Children 4-12 years have a reduced rate and 0-3 years of age are free. Just walking around viewing the complex is a treat. It is one of the highlights of Valencia, Spain.
titleopinion:

quote: Never expect to see something like this outside a medieval city
reviewnospace: Amazing,cutting edge architecture. Did not get to go inside - regret that we missed that experience. Maybe next time....
titleopinion: Never expect to see something like this outside a medieval city. Amazing,cutting edge architecture. Did not get to go inside - regret that we missed that experience. Maybe next time....

quote: Spectacular aquarium at city of arts and sciences
reviewnospace: The aquarium was excellent. It focusses on live marine life in big tanks rather than interpretive stuff you get at other places. The shark tunnel and the beluga environment were highlights.
titleopinion: Spectacular aquarium at city of arts and sciences. The aquarium was excellent. It focusses on live marine life in big tanks rather than interpretive stuff you get at other places. The shark tunnel and the beluga environment were highlights.

quote: Like something from a Tati film!
reviewnospace: Very clever construction - somewhat surreal. so modernist I had to sak why? A magnificent project however and another superb place to visit in the Turia development. It's also a stone's throw from the Grand Prix circuit!
titleopinion: Like something from a Tati film!. Very clever construction - somewhat surreal. so modernist I had to sak why? A magnificent project however and another superb place to visit in the Turia development. It's also a stone's throw from the Grand Prix circuit!

reviewnospace: The architecture here is truly stunning. You must see this if you are in Valencia and if you are not there now then go just to see this. Very modern and very expensive no doubt, but worth it.
titleopinion: Amazing architecture. The architecture here is truly stunning. You must see this if you are in Valencia and if you are not there now then go just to see this. Very modern and very expensive no doubt, but worth it.

reviewnospace: Firstly, the architecture is just sublime, it dominates the skyline and is very iconic. Then, once you go inside there are many, many things to see and do, all of them fun. In particular, the Valencia CF section which was really enjoyable for our entire family!
titleopinion: Such fun!. Firstly, the architecture is just sublime, it dominates the skyline and is very iconic. Then, once you go inside there are many, many things to see and do, all of them fun. In particular, the Valencia CF section which was really enjoyable for our entire family!

location: Rada de Moraira, Comunidad Valenciana, Spain
reviewnospace: This place has so much to offer on a trip to Valencia firstly for its incredible architecture, where ever you stand you see something new. We have visited the science museum which is one of the best I've been too, plenty to do and interact with for our inquisitive 5 yr old including a superhero enclosure by Marvel, very reasonably priced. The Oceanographic is also brilliant bit pricier but great experience in lovely setting also serves good food on site.

We have visited the science museum which is one of the best I've been too, plenty to do and interact with for our inquisitive 5 yr old including a superhero enclosure by Marvel, very reasonably priced. The Oceanographic is also brilliant bit pricier but great experience in lovely setting also serves good food on site.

reviewnospace:
Wonderfull design, inspiring area!
We walked from the old town, through the garden (the dry river), and all the way down to the City of Arts and Sciences. Takes about 40 minutes. You can sit down in the park end enjoy a glass of wine if you need a break.

The City of Arts and Science is spectacular!
I would reccommend to walk around the area, be inspired - and to enter the aquarium.
The Dophin show is ok, but most of all - to see the sharks swimming around you when you walk in the tunnel - is worth the entrance fee.

A must do when you are in Valencia!

titleopinion: Interesting, but very expensive. It's a really interesting place to visit and the architecture is great, but it is really overpriced for what it is. You do need to see it on a sunny day and it is now starting to look old and cracked.

titleopinion: Oceanografica!. When you factor in the scenery, the intimacy with the animals, and the dolphin show (en espanol), this was the best aquarium I have been to; hands down.

reviewnospace: Just walking around the buildings is inspiring. I don't think a trip to Valencia is complete without visiting this part of the city even if you never enter any of the buildings.
titleopinion: Beautiful Architecture. Just walking around the buildings is inspiring. I don't think a trip to Valencia is complete without visiting this part of the city even if you never enter any of the buildings.

reviewnospace:
We were in Valencia for a day on our cruise itinery. Although we didnt go into the actual buildings just seeing them up close was enough for us. The whole complex is simply spectacular even more so in reality than I could have imagined. The attention to detail and the sheer scale of the work that went into putting all those tiny white and blue tile chips onto those large buildings is in itself mind boggling! I mean, what were they thinking??

This one of the globe's true wonders of construction and man's creativity. The added bonus you get is that it is situated in one of the most beautiful, user friendly cities in Europe.

We had a great time!
titleopinion:

quote: Great architecture but save your money
reviewnospace: Most of the outside space was taken up by a car company displaying and advertising its line. Rampant commercialism at its worst. It totally destroyed our one day visit as we specifically came to valencia to visit this complex. If they are so hard up for money to restrict access to multiple parts of the complex for a private company to advertise then they should never accept entrance fees to buildings and attractions which are off limits due to these activities. I would never recommend anyone pay for admission (science centre had many non working displays - in the areas which were not blocked off due to the car company ads) oceonographic had many short paths blocked off forcing long detour's between displays and the main central part of the long complex was blocked off with security (ensuring no one uninvited got near the new cars) making paying people walk around the outside of the complex in order to get from one building (science centre) to another (theater). Not an enjoyable experience at all. Do go see the outside but do not waste your euro on going inside.

However if you find yorself in Valencia it is definitely worth seeing this science fiction environment, it is beautiful from an architectural point of view and I'm not even very interested in architecture. I'd heard that the entrance fee to the different centres is quite high so I decided not to go inside. However it was well seeing the exterior. It's like seeing several Sydney Opera Houses all together in a fantasy science fiction world. With the walk down there from the centre.

This richly imaginative complex of white buildings holds museums of Science, Marine life, a performance center and a

Futuristic Architecture in New Valencia. This richly imaginative complex of white buildings holds museums of Science, Marine life, a performance center and a

reviewnospace: The buildings in the City of Arts and Sciences were designed by the famous Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava and are some of the most iconic buildings in Spain. It is worth walking around all the buildings to enjoy the various vistas and reflections in the water even if not visiting the inside of buildings.
titleopinion: Iconic archirtecture. The buildings in the City of Arts and Sciences were designed by the famous Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava and are some of the most iconic buildings in Spain. It is worth walking around all the buildings to enjoy the various vistas and reflections in the water even if not visiting the inside of buildings.

quote: An amazing architectural indulgence that has cost this city a future of impossible debt
reviewnospace:
Yes it is very impressive. A futuristic city of fantasy. White concrete sculpted into buildings of immense beauty and creation. The area is situated at the bottom end of the Turia park and is surrounded by shallow lakes that reflect these glaringly white palaces. It all started with the science museum and the IMax theatre. I have to say the science museum is not one of Europes best by a long way. Next came the opera house, followed by the sports arena, neither of which host sufficient events to show a significant return. There are many open air concerts in this area and various exhibitions. It is worth walking round the area for an hour or so and having a coffee in the park and just taking it all in. The Oceanografic park adjoining blends in very well with the overall architectural concept. I like all the metallic sculptures dotted round the park. But what on earth went on in those council meetings. When you add up the bills for the City of Science, the infrastructure for the Americas Cup and the motor racing circuit, boy you are in the realms of cuckoo land debt. It a shame that many schools won't get built and many hospitals will have their budgets cut. All because of the inflated ego of the Valencian town hall. Enjoy
Pedroofpobla

reviewnospace: This an architectural masterpiece that defies description. There are several space age buildings that seem to rise out of Turia Park. they include a science museum, a spectacular opera house with four theatres, a planetarium and a building for changing exhibits. Futuristic in white and blue tiles pictures and words do not do it justice.

reviewnospace: since last coming to valencia when the surrounding area was being developed, it has been totally transformed. this is a highlight, and an absolute must to visit. you can just spend some time walking around the complex for free, though be prepared for heat if this is in mid-summer at a time the sun is high in the sky. it manages to be quiet and relaxing in many areas, and exceptionally clean, making the white structures seem somewhat surreal. the various buidlings offer something for everyone. if coming from the centre, then carry on out of town to the beach afterwards.

quote: Worth walking around - no admission required!
reviewnospace:
You literally can't miss this attraction, and you don't have to!

We were traveling on a budget and so passed on the admission - I think it was something like 25 euro each. But the buildings are amazing from the outside - really nice to walk around. There are bikes available also.

Valencia is a city to enjoy on foot and/or bus. It's a bit of a walk from the old town to the Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias, but doable and enjoyable. There is a walkway along the old river course.

reviewnospace: Valencia is a fantastic city, probably the highlight for us was city of arts and sciences with its amazing architecture.The river running through Valencia was prone to flooding and with modern day engineering was diverted around the city leaving a dry riverbed ...voila.. This then was transformed into probably one of the finest public amenities in any city in the world. You have the Aqua dome with performing dolphins, hundreds of different species of fish in huge tanks that you can walk under and almost touch. There is an array of exotic birds, tortoises etc.. a great way to spend a day. Up to road ( 5 mins walk) you have an i-max theatre and public park. The park has gym/training areas with gym equipment for public use.The Science buildings the concert hall the bridges now crossing the dry riverbed are all really beautiful. If architecture is your thing then Valencia is well worth a visit. Being a pretty level city the bicycle is a great way to get around and these can be picked up and dropped off at dozens of different locations around the city..probably every couple of hundred yards. You can buy a card for about €20 and use these bikes as you wish.Pick up and drop off great. More and more cities are now making these available. The Zoo in Valencia is another good day out and also last but by no means least Valencia has a great port area and beach...If your lucky your visit may even coincide with the formula 1 race in late June.

quote: Worth visiting for the exterior, not interior
reviewnospace: If you like architecture this is a cannot-miss location in Valencia. It's a long walk from the city center, or you can catch a bus that will drop you off a few blocks away and can walk from there. The grounds are beautiful and the buildings really are stunning. That being said, I can't really recommend you pay for the museum of science or planetarium, as we found the exhibits only moderately interesting. The museum just doesn't make use of the space inside, and when we went nearly half of the hands-on exhibits were 'out of service'. Go for the views, and just walk around the grounds.

We just visited the science museum which I personally thought was decent value for the length of time we spent there. However my score reflects the fact that several of the exhibits were out of order, with the number of visiters they must get there is really no excuse for this as I can't imagine many of the broken things were that expensive to fix. Bearing that it turns a 4 star review into a 3 star. None the less I still would recommend giving it a chance yourself.

I didn't bother to go to see any exhibitions, given low season no specific exhibitions on, personally I don't like permanent exhibits.

reviewnospace: It's on its way of being 10 times more expensive than it was sold for to Valencia, and definitely doesn't worth all that money: nobody knows where it went and it should have been invested in other fields, especially seeing how troubled Valencian region is now. Saying that, what's left is truly original and something one has to see when in Valencia. Very nice walking areas, a bit of tribute to Gaudi style, and curves everywhere. The ticket price of the attractions is too expensive, and for us the science museum didn't fulfill our expectations. Saying that, we did had a great time. Views are gorgeous, and it's a complex that we will remember.

reviewnospace:
I am not going to rave about the architecture of this building, which is significant but just about how boring the so-called scientific exhibits were. That half of the interactive ones were not working. That the presentation had "lost its way". That the entrance fee was expensive. That we expected more and got less than we hoped.

The exhibits were designed for children, but in my opinion many went way over their heads. Too difficult for them to appreciate.

That the European Space Agency presentation was boring.

What on Earth have Marvel comic superheroes got to do with Science?

reviewnospace:
Back in the 1990-ies when money was easy to get and confidence was high some cities were caught by a certain sense of hybris and started to construct incredibly ambitious buildings.
Valencia was no exeption to this and luckily they entrusted their project to a very talented architect who did a great job.
On gthe south eastern edge of the city a whole series of buildings was constructed, looking like space ships and containing all kinds of attractions.
It is very worhtwhile to walk around here , make photographs and visit the attractions, even though, apart from the great oceanographic, they are not too special.

If this is anything to go by we would love to go back and visit the other elements of the City of Arts.

reviewnospace:
We spent an unforgettable week in this lovely city, and of course the main attraction being the Calatrava complex. The aquarium is the best we have seen, comparable only to the Lisbon aquarium, another Calatrava protect.
tHe science museum was interesting, not the best in the world, but the architecture makes it unique. In general, it was a pleasure just walking through the gardens, long long walks in spring. May be that in summer it is not so enjoyable.
Valencia in general is modern, clean, without traffic jams. How do they do it?everyone rides bicycles.
It was one of our best vacations and I are looking forward to coming back to Valencia.
titleopinion:
Beautiful. We spent an unforgettable week in this lovely city, and of course the main attraction being the Calatrava complex. The aquarium is the best we have seen, comparable only to the Lisbon aquarium, another Calatrava protect.
tHe science museum was interesting, not the best in the world, but the architecture makes it unique. In general, it was a pleasure just walking through the gardens, long long walks in spring. May be that in summer it is not so enjoyable.
Valencia in general is modern, clean, without traffic jams. How do they do it?everyone rides bicycles.
It was one of our best vacations and I are looking forward to coming back to Valencia.

quote: Take a day to do all of this amazing area
reviewnospace: The whole area is a tremendous collection of architecture. You can visit the Oceanografic, the Science Museum and the Hemisfera on a combed ticket.
titleopinion: Take a day to do all of this amazing area. The whole area is a tremendous collection of architecture. You can visit the Oceanografic, the Science Museum and the Hemisfera on a combed ticket.

reviewnospace: Very modern and the Acquarium is a great experience. But prepar yourself to walk, because that place is big!!!
titleopinion: Amazing place!!!. Very modern and the Acquarium is a great experience. But prepar yourself to walk, because that place is big!!!

reviewnospace: We walked here along the sunken garden route, which is made from the old dried river bed of the town, this was very enjoyable, but take your time in the heat .. Coming across these buildings is like seeing a mirage, these new strange architectural shapes looming up ahead of you..They are very interesting structures, but the whole space is eerily quiet and deserted, massive wide concourses, reflecting pools, white tiles gleaming in the sun.... but no one ? this place should be filled with people, not empty cordoned off with the odd security guard looking listless, come on town council .. sort it out .. and get a decent cafe down there... not that porta cabin...

Doggy friendly and pushchair friendly as well as good area for small people walking practice. We didn't make it into any of the buildings but it was enough to feel the space age atmosphere from the outside. And it was fun to feel like you were in Logan's run!

If you like to make pictures, this place is very rewarding, try to go during the day and during the sun set.

quote: 1 of the top highlights in Valencia

reviewnospace: Very large aquarium with many different buildings and exhibits. The Dolphin show is better than the one at Seaworld.
titleopinion: Nice Aquarium. Very large aquarium with many different buildings and exhibits. The Dolphin show is better than the one at Seaworld.

reviewnospace: We decided to spend the day in the arts and sciences center to see the marveled modern architecture. So we visited the science museum and the aquarium. I admit that it is a matter of taste and familiarity with architecture in general, but we found the design of the comlex totally unatractive and unfunctional from the point of "form follows function". Although it is obvious that a lot of money and thought was put into it, the feeling that we got from the colosal buildings is unfriendlyness, redundancy of building material, and and even animosity. The arts center looks like a head of a cyber worrier, and the science building renders the association of shark jaws. Nevertheless grown-up and kids alike can pass an enjoyable day in the science museum, and the aquarium.
titleopinion: Disappointing architecture. We decided to spend the day in the arts and sciences center to see the marveled modern architecture. So we visited the science museum and the aquarium. reviewnospace:
We visited the Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias in April 2012. The buildings are wonderful - it's easy to knock modern architecture and to compare it unfavourably with much older work, but the designs here are breathtaking. All are set in a dried up riverbed which has been turned into a long park which snakes along the edge of the older city of Valencia. It's worth taking a stroll along the length of the park, away from the Ciudad de A y C and there is at least on cafe in the park as well as ice creams if you do so on a hot day.

The main purpose of our visit was to go to the three main buildings - the Oceanografico (sea life centre), the Museo de las Ciencias (science museum) and the Hemisferico (an IMAX cinema). I'm going to review each separately on Trip Advisor but it's worth mentioning here that you can get tickets for each individual attraction, or for two, or for all three. We did the latter. If you do the same, be aware that when you buy the ticket, you will need to decide which of the films being shown at the Hemisferico you want to see, so this ties you down to being there at a specific time. We underestimated how much time we would spend in the Oceanografico, so didn't make the film showing! It's worth noting as well that, so far as I can remember, the joint ticket covered us for one admission to each attraction, but we could have used the ticket for the science museum on the following day instead of cramming this into one day, as we did. I think full details of the conditions of entry are on their website (although I don't think it makes clear that you can't just turn up to the Hemisferico whenever you fancy!).
titleopinion:

quote: Modern area of Valencia - well worth a visit.
reviewnospace: It's nice to walk around this area and take photos. It's located in the large park that has been created around the north and east side of Valencia in the old river bed. The buildings are very futuristic and very impressive. We didn't go in the IMAX or the Arts and Science museums, but had we understood the ticket options prior to arriving at the Oceangraphic aquarium we'd probably have chosen the combined IMAX ticket option, but as we were already at the aquarium we didn't want to go back to the IMAX and then return to the aquarium later. This would have been necessary to see the viewing of the IMAX film we wanted to see, so we just went aquarium in the end. I'd suggest looking into the details before you arrive.

reviewnospace: The Oceangrafic (Aquarium) is rated amongst the top ten in the world and it does not disappoint. I don't know if the rest of the location has been rated but it is well done and a "must see" if you are in Valencia. It's interesting to see the contrast between the old parts of the city and then see this new facility that's well architected and a beautiful site.

reviewnospace: Even if you don't go in to any of the buildings, a visit to Valencia really wouldn't be complete without a trip to the City of Arts and Sciences. Just wander around the complex and take in the fantastic architecture and landscaping. I myself went into the Science Museum, which had a range of interesting exhibitions, all with good English translations. It was good value for money too - 8 euros for an adult for entry, with some good combi-tickets if you want to visit other parts of the park.
titleopinion: A must-see. Even if you don't go in to any of the buildings, a visit to Valencia really wouldn't be complete without a trip to the City of Arts and Sciences. Just wander around the complex and take in the fantastic architecture and landscaping. reviewnospace:
It's certainly a must-visit site in Valencia. This complex is something out of this world, so beautiful and unique it is! Not only does it give aesthetic pleasure, but there are some interesting museums and places to go. We bought a ticket that included visits to the Museum of Science, Hemisferic, Oceanografic + night show of synchronized swimming with dolphins.

The Museum of Science will definitely be interesting for children - it's one of those museums where it's permitted to touch everything, and it's pretty entertaining.

Hemisferic is a planetarium, but when we visited it served as a 3D cinema that projected popular science movies. I really enjoyed it, but at first I got glasses that didn't work - I went out to search for personnel but nobody was there- the place was deserted! Somehow I found a storage room and changed it myself, but it was weird that all the staff disappeared)

To everybody interested in sea life and aquariums I strongly advise to visit Oceanografic - it is a whole complex of aquariums with all sorts of fish imaginable. There are 2 tunnels - one with tropical fish and one with sharks (the latter is so exciting!). We spent there half of a day but I bet we could have spent more if we weren't tired.
The show of synchronized swimming with dolphins is very gripping and unusal, if you have a chance to experience it, don't miss it!

Divided by a pool from the Museum of Science, the Umbracle terrace serves as a park at day time and as a club at night. The entrance cost 13 euro but that didn't prevent us from returning there several times more: the atmosphere of the place, the view on the complex by night are awesome. For those who are tired of heat there's a club Mya on the first floor with air-conditioning. But we preferred staying on the second floor that offered a great view.

So if you ever visit Valencia, don't forget to take a look at la Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias!

simply amazing, there is no such a place in the world.

quote: Museu de las Ciencias Principe Filipe
reviewnospace: We visited the museum and had an excellent time. Especially like the Tesla Cage. Didn´t had time to visit more.
titleopinion: Museu de las Ciencias Principe Filipe. We visited the museum and had an excellent time. Especially like the Tesla Cage. Didn´t had time to visit more.

reviewnospace: Great to walk around the various buildings, with nice shallow water pools and a lot of impressive architecture with open space - nice contrast to the old city
titleopinion: Great views. Great to walk around the various buildings, with nice shallow water pools and a lot of impressive architecture with open space - nice contrast to the old city

reviewnospace:
Amazing.The buildings look like in SF movies.There are 6 objectivs: Hemisferic-an IMAX cinema; Oceanografic-a huge wonderful aquarium,the most beautiful I've ever seen;Science Museum;Arts Palace;Agora-a multifunctional building and Umbracle-a gardened esplanade.
You need more than one day to see all of them.
Don't miss the dolphin show in Oceanografic,it's wonderful!
titleopinion:
Stunning. Amazing.The buildings look like in SF movies.There are 6 objectivs: Hemisferic-an IMAX cinema; Oceanografic-a huge wonderful aquarium,the most beautiful I've ever seen;Science Museum;Arts Palace;Agora-a multifunctional building and Umbracle-a gardened esplanade.
You need more than one day to see all of them.
Don't miss the dolphin show in Oceanografic,it's wonderful!

reviewnospace: Was an awesome set of buildings, worth seeing even just from the outside. We went into the aquarium and the science museum part. The aquarium was probably our favourite, it was so big and had a really good set up for the place. Well worth a trip!
titleopinion: Very Cool. Was an awesome set of buildings, worth seeing even just from the outside. We went into the aquarium and the science museum part. The aquarium was probably our favourite, it was so big and had a really good set up for the place. Well worth a trip!

reviewnospace: As you approach the buildings the view is breathtaking. It is very much worth a visit at night too just to see the lighting effects on the water. Each attraction charges its own entrance fee so can work out a bit expensive. Itsprobably worth a couple of visits rather than try to do it all in one day. The aquarium is incredible especially the tunnels which make you feel you are surrounded by the animals. My neice ran away when a shark swam over her head. The dolphin show is great fun with the usual proviso that if you sit in the front rows you are going to get wet. The only thing is in the summer it can get very hot so take care and drink lots. I'd also take food in if you have lots of kids in your group as that can make for a very expensive day. All in all an excellent day or two out!
titleopinion: Absolutely amazing. As you approach the buildings the view is breathtaking. It is very much worth a visit at night too just to see the lighting effects on the water. Each attraction charges its own entrance fee so can work out a bit expensive. Itsprobably worth a couple of visits rather than try to do it all in one day. The aquarium is incredible especially the tunnels which make you feel you are surrounded by the animals. My neice ran away when a shark swam over her head. The dolphin show is great fun with the usual proviso that if you sit in the front rows you are going to get wet. The only thing is in the summer it can get very hot so take care and drink lots. I'd also take food in if you have lots of kids in your group as that can make for a very expensive day. All in all an excellent day or two out!

reviewnospace: Probably the only real attraction in Valencia but it is really really amazing! Architecture is beautiful to walk through and the park is great to have picnic or just wandering around. Full of life and animals! Rent a bike, go running or even just taste an ice-cream are fantastic activities!

Architecture is beautiful to walk through and the park is great to have picnic or just wandering around. Full of life and animals! Rent a bike, go running or even just taste an ice-cream are fantastic activities!

reviewnospace: Amazing architecture worth walking around, the science museum is very child orientated so bear that in mind if your an adult couple

reviewnospace: Initially thought it looked like a massive building with no substance, but actually could have spent longer in there reading about the various exhibits. Booked for this and aquatic centre and only had 6 hours to do both - not actually enough time - recommend you go.

reviewnospace: We visited the outside of the site in the early afternoon and to say the buildings were impressive is an understatement. The design and structural look will take your breath away. Great photo opportunity which will allow you to look like an extra out of star wars!

reviewnospace:
I have seen pictures before the trip, yet I am still totally amazed by its sheer size and ultra modernism, Valencia architect Santiago Calatrava designed 4 of the 5 buildings here. He is the also the architect of New Year City new World Trade Center Transportation Hub, I am sure the Transportation Hub will become a new NYC landmark as the City of Arts and Sciences here.

I didn't get a chance to go into any of the Museum. We were also told this place was simply spectacular with lighting at night. You may want to visit again at night.

reviewnospace: We walked around the complex for a few hours soaking it all in - we did not actually visit any of the museums themselves - we heard from others the science museum really wasn't worth it, and being from Tampa, Florida, where we have a great Aquarium, the Oceanopraphic didn't really appeal to us either. But we thoroughly enjoyed marveling at the building design. It's something to see!

We walked around the complex for a few hours soaking it all in - we did not actually visit any of the museums themselves - we heard from others the science museum really wasn't worth it, and being from Tampa, Florida, where we have a great Aquarium, the Oceanopraphic didn't really appeal to us either. But we thoroughly enjoyed marveling at the building design. It's something to see!

quote: External charm by far outweighs the interior
reviewnospace:
The complex cost £800m and from the outside it looks nice, clean and modern.

The grounds and architecture are world class and sit nicely on the old Turia river bed.

Unfortunately inside there wasn't much to see.

We decided that the best thing was to walk the F1 track and then go to the beach.
titleopinion:
External charm by far outweighs the interior. The complex cost £800m and from the outside it looks nice, clean and modern.

The grounds and architecture are world class and sit nicely on the old Turia river bed.

Unfortunately inside there wasn't much to see.

We decided that the best thing was to walk the F1 track and then go to the beach.

reviewnospace: We walked here from downtown Valencia. It's a bit of a hike but if you have the time, it's a nice walk through the park. One you get here you are blown away by the spectacular design. There is so much to take in. Architecturally it is a great concept and wonderful to behold. You could stay here for hours and not see it all. We went back the next day to check out the Oceanographic, Europe's largest aquarium. It is actually 10 different buildings so if you were hoping to walk indoors on a hot day, be warned.It is a massive complex with lots to see. It's also very interactive. You can go inside the bird complex where the birds roam free. The dolphin show is great, but gets packed so get there early. If you are aquarium fans, it's a must see.
titleopinion: Great tourism in one spot. We walked here from downtown Valencia. It's a bit of a hike but if you have the time, it's a nice walk through the park. One you get here you are blown away by the spectacular design. There is so much to take in. Architecturally it is a great concept and wonderful to behold. You could stay here for hours and not see it all. We went back the next day to check out the Oceanographic, Europe's largest aquarium. It is actually 10 different buildings so if you were hoping to walk indoors on a hot day, be warned.It is a massive complex with lots to see. It's also very interactive. You can go inside the bird complex where the birds roam free. The dolphin show is great, but gets packed so get there early. If you are aquarium fans, it's a must see.

reviewnospace: The city of arts and sciences combines beautiful architecture with entertainment and education. Highly recommended if you are fan of architecture.The Oceanographic is the best building to visit and worth every penny you pay, make sure you attend the dolphin show. If you are not with kids don't bother paying the entrance for the other buildings. i definitely recommend to visit it while in Valencia.
titleopinion: Fine architecture. The city of arts and sciences combines beautiful architecture with entertainment and education. Highly recommended if you are fan of architecture.The Oceanographic is the best building to visit and worth every penny you pay, make sure you attend the dolphin show. If you are not with kids don't bother paying the entrance for the other buildings. i definitely recommend to visit it while in Valencia.

reviewnospace:
Wondered in the area and it's quite impressive if you like modern, futuristic buildings.
Didn't do into any of the building though.

Great place to visit by day and by night, on both times you'll snap some great photos!
titleopinion:
Futuristic Valencia. Wondered in the area and it's quite impressive if you like modern, futuristic buildings.
Didn't do into any of the building though.

quote: Great place to have fun and learn
reviewnospace: The City of Arts and Sciences is a fun place for grown ups and children alike. The building complex is futuristic and a great triumph of the human imagination. It is time well spent to walk around and take in the sights. Given our limited time we only visited the Oceanografico which far exceeded our expectations.
titleopinion: Great place to have fun and learn. The City of Arts and Sciences is a fun place for grown ups and children alike. The building complex is futuristic and a great triumph of the human imagination. It is time well spent to walk around and take in the sights. Given our limited time we only visited the Oceanografico which far exceeded our expectations.

reviewnospace: Billions of tons of concrete add up to a spectacular place to visit. Love it or hate it, it's spectacular. Don't bother paying to go into any of the buildings, the best part is definitely just wandering around outside - preferably in the cool of the evening armed with a decent camera.
titleopinion: Modernist Valencia. Billions of tons of concrete add up to a spectacular place to visit. Love it or hate it, it's spectacular. Don't bother paying to go into any of the buildings, the best part is definitely just wandering around outside - preferably in the cool of the evening armed with a decent camera.

reviewnospace:
Whilst the city of arts and sciences is now ten years old, it looks and feels like something from the future! Think of a family of Sydney Opera houses.

We spent the whole afternoon(1-7pm) exploring the science museum and it was something my family would have struggled to do in British Museums. The whole thing was more interactive than anyplace I'd been before and still very deverse and extremely informative. Very large space never felt very busy although a lot of people about.

Disappointed that the Art museum was closed for summer schedule, mid July- late August and the Hemisphere was having maintenance on the walkways around so didn't go in but still had plenty of walking around the gardens and the buildings to enjoy and finish our third day in the city.
titleopinion:

We spent the whole afternoon(1-7pm) exploring the science museum and it was something my family would have struggled to do in British Museums. The whole thing was more interactive than anyplace I'd been before and still very deverse and extremely informative. Very large space never felt very busy although a lot of people about.

Disappointed that the Art museum was closed for summer schedule, mid July- late August and the Hemisphere was having maintenance on the walkways around so didn't go in but still had plenty of walking around the gardens and the buildings to enjoy and finish our third day in the city.

reviewnospace: This interactive science museum was lots of fun and had things to appeal to all age groups. It's all indoors, so it's also a good choice for a hot afternoon.
titleopinion: Hands on fun. This interactive science museum was lots of fun and had things to appeal to all age groups. It's all indoors, so it's also a good choice for a hot afternoon.

quote: Not as good as the one we visited in germany
reviewnospace:
Very impressive buildings, there are a coupe of tips , buy the space adventure 2 euros per person and quite interesting. Not that many interactive things for none spainish speakers. The building activity site allows 25 kids in per hour and the activity starts on the hour every hour. The electricity demo is only in spanish. Toilets are only either on the 3rd ( top floor) or in the entrance hall which is not too big a problem as you can exit and enter as manyti'es as you want. There are 2 food outlets, the is a snack type place sandwiches, paste dish or two , cold drinks, drinks the other is a proper restuarant but a 13.45 it was still not open, opened at about 14.00 so be prepared for a late lunch if you want something other than a sandwich.
Even with thevfew problems still worth a visit.
Note parking cost 2 euro per hour so try and park in the street if you dont want to be rpped off for parking.
titleopinion:
Not as good as the one we visited in germany. Very impressive buildings, there are a coupe of tips , buy the space adventure 2 euros per person and quite interesting. Not that many interactive things for none spainish speakers. The building activity site allows 25 kids in per hour and the activity starts on the hour every hour. The electricity demo is only in spanish. Toilets are only either on the 3rd ( top floor) or in the entrance hall which is not too big a problem as you can exit and enter as manyti'es as you want. There are 2 food outlets, the is a snack type place sandwiches, paste dish or two , cold drinks, drinks the other is a proper restuarant but a 13.45 it was still not open, opened at about 14.00 so be prepared for a late lunch if you want something other than a sandwich.
Even with thevfew problems still worth a visit.
Note parking cost 2 euro per hour so try and park in the street if you dont want to be rpped off for parking.

quote: Impressive on the outside, less on the inside
reviewnospace:
Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias is one of the most impressive architectural complexes I have ever seen. As a photographer I spend a lot of time there walking around for some stunning pictures.

That being said: the insides of the buildings are not that special. Based on the exquisit architecture you expect a lot from the contents of the buildings too, but I was a little disappointed with the science museum. It felt empty because it is so big. It is fun for kids though with lots of interactive activities like testing your balance, creating your own footprint and making noises with your muscles.

The Oceanografic was pretty, but as I live next to a zoo in Rotterdam with a big Oceanium it was not that special for me. Although I liked the enormous fishtanks full of special fish and beautiful seastars.

The Hemisphere was a big disappointment for me. I was expecting a unique visual experience but they only projected the movie on a small 3 by 3 metres screen instead of on the whole globe (which was what I was expecting). What was also annoying was that the movie was blaring in Spanish through the theatre. You get headphones though on which you can chose your preferred language but even the nyou will hear the Spanish one through your chosen language.

All in all a very pretty complex and definitely a must see, but I think they could have done a lot better job on the actual contents
titleopinion:
Impressive on the outside, less on the inside. Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias is one of the most impressive architectural complexes I have ever seen. As a photographer I spend a lot of time there walking around for some stunning pictures.

That being said: the insides of the buildings are not that special. Based on the exquisit architecture you expect a lot from the contents of the buildings too, but I was a little disappointed with the science museum. It felt empty because it is so big. The Hemisphere was a big disappointment for me. I was expecting a unique visual experience but they only projected the movie on a small 3 by 3 metres screen instead of on the whole globe (which was what I was expecting). What was also annoying was that the movie was blaring in Spanish through the theatre. You get headphones though on which you can chose your preferred language but even the nyou will hear the Spanish one through your chosen language.

All in all a very pretty complex and definitely a must see, but I think they could have done a lot better job on the actual contents

reviewnospace: The overall conception of this cultural centre is amazing, like nowhere else we have seen. It is visually stunning. The Oceanographic is a great place to spend a few hours though not easy to navigate. One quibble: although a lot of locals are away in August, we still expected the complex to be much busier than it was. I don't know whether this is down to pricing but walking around in the heat of summer we were struck by how little there is in the way of outdoor cafes/refreshments/kiosks and by the constant attempts of officials to stop people dipping their feet in the huge pools of water that are a beautiful feature of the complex. So extraordinary as it all was, we also had a feeling that the place was somewhat lifeless and took itself too seriously.
titleopinion: Outstanding attraction. The overall conception of this cultural centre is amazing, like nowhere else we have seen. It is visually stunning. The Oceanographic is a great place to spend a few hours though not easy to navigate. One quibble: although a lot of locals are away in August, we still expected the complex to be much busier than it was. I don't know whether this is down to pricing but walking around in the heat of summer we were struck by how little there is in the way of outdoor cafes/refreshments/kiosks and by the constant attempts of officials to stop people dipping their feet in the huge pools of water that are a beautiful feature of the complex. So extraordinary as it all was, we also had a feeling that the place was somewhat lifeless and took itself too seriously.

quote: It take as many hours as you have to enjoy completely
reviewnospace:
We went there in afternoon with idea to spend 2 hrs in Science museum and 4 in Oceanographic. But there we found out that the Science museum is not closing at midnight as the Oceanographic but few hours earlier.
4 hrs is enough for Oceanographic including Dolphins show. belugas are wonderful and I never had chance to see them before. Also itcs the only place you can sit down and enjoy those perfect creatures. The rest of Oceanographic was nothing special for me.
Science museum is interactive and I red it takes 2 hrs but we spent there 7! The first floor was a bit out of date. Intelligent homes are not revolutionary inventions today. The third floor is in spanish but the last one was so interesting.
So take your time and have fun!

You can buy combined tickets and for two days also.

quote: Nice for kids (and maybe even bigger kids too)
reviewnospace: This reminded me of other child-focused science museums I had been to before when my children were younger, but maybe even a bit more diverse. It was very nice; I just wish we had more time to explore some of the other museums in the cluster. I think we all found something we liked best. For my husband and I it was the series of exhibits on Nobel Prize winners (and the Marvel comic section). We didn't go for the extra movie section--too much added expense.

reviewnospace: If you went to Valencia , you have to visit the city of art & sciences....When you go there you must see the Oceanografic . An awesome aquarum , dolphins show & many marvel species...ticket is Euro 25 for adult...you will enjoy your time , no doubt.

quote: Specially the building that makes this museum.
reviewnospace:
The museum Art and Science is specially worth the visit because of the beautiful building. The experience you get in the museum about the building is incredible. The museum itself is nice but not that special.

There is a lot to do about science specially for children this is a great place. There are interactive games and they can learn a lot about science.

It's a place for young and old and the location makes this museum a must do if you are in Valencia.

reviewnospace: Everything was perfect. Must see this place. Must see Science museum, Hemispheric, Oceanographic and botanical gardens.
titleopinion: Perfect. Everything was perfect. Must see this place. Must see Science museum, Hemispheric, Oceanographic and botanical gardens.

reviewnospace: Worth a visit - even if you don't enter them. They are wonderful buildings to look at and are lovely to wander around in the early evening.
titleopinion: Fantastic. Worth a visit - even if you don't enter them. They are wonderful buildings to look at and are lovely to wander around in the early evening.

reviewnospace: We were mostly after the views. These buildings are so amazing, and we couldn't get enough of them.
titleopinion: A short trip to Valencia. We were mostly after the views. These buildings are so amazing, and we couldn't get enough of them.

quote: Spend a day at the City of the Arts & Sciences
reviewnospace: Outstanding architecture to explore. We really enjoyed the aquarium.
titleopinion: Spend a day at the City of the Arts & Sciences. Outstanding architecture to explore. We really enjoyed the aquarium.

quote: This is the icing on the cake which is provided by the former river turia
reviewnospace: The architecture is breathtaking and the setting outstanding and I was lucky enough to initially see the development as my plane descended over the City of Valencia. The dry riverbed includes a wide range of facilities adjacent to the City, with the range of buildings at the City of Arts and Sciences providing architectural excellence, incorporating cultural, scientific and educational facilities.
titleopinion: This is the icing on the cake which is provided by the former river turia. The architecture is breathtaking and the setting outstanding and I was lucky enough to initially see the development as my plane descended over the City of Valencia. quote: So much to see, one day is not enough.
reviewnospace: There are so many places to take in: the museum of fine arts, the planetarium, the science museum, the aquarium...you'll need more than a day to explore all the venues on this site. But even if you are not sure you want to dish out the cash for the steep ticket(s) price(s), it is worth taking a stroll around the area...the buildings are stunning!
titleopinion: So much to see, one day is not enough.. There are so many places to take in: the museum of fine arts, the planetarium, the science museum, the aquarium...you'll need more than a day to explore all the venues on this site. But even if you are not sure you want to dish out the cash for the steep ticket(s) price(s), it is worth taking a stroll around the area...the buildings are stunning!

reviewnospace: This is one of the amazing architectural icons by Félix Candela and the world renowned architect Santiago Calavatra. The entire site is breathtaking: sitting on the former riverbed of the river Turia, the site comprises 7 elements. It includes an interactive science museum, an open-air oceanographic park, a suspension bridge, an IMAX, a landscaped walk, an opera house and performing arts center and a covered plaza for concerts and sporting events. It's a place for family.
titleopinion: Amazing architecture. This is one of the amazing architectural icons by Félix Candela and the world renowned architect Santiago Calavatra. The entire site is breathtaking: sitting on the former riverbed of the river Turia, the site comprises 7 elements. It includes an interactive science museum, an open-air oceanographic park, a suspension bridge, an IMAX, a landscaped walk, an opera house and performing arts center and a covered plaza for concerts and sporting events. It's a place for family.

reviewnospace: The architecture is stunning, the layout amazing, took a road-train trip up the old riverbed on which it is built, learned history of the bridges we went under, from modern to 700 years old. Well worth a visit.
titleopinion: Nothing like it anywhere else.. The architecture is stunning, the layout amazing, took a road-train trip up the old riverbed on which it is built, learned history of the bridges we went under, from modern to 700 years old. Well worth a visit.

reviewnospace: I recommend to rent a bicycle and ride along the park until you get to Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias.
titleopinion: Amazing place. I recommend to rent a bicycle and ride along the park until you get to Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias.

quote: Valencia - Spanish Culture at its best
reviewnospace: One hour from our place at Casa Diana in Monte Pego is Valencia, fantastic city with excellent links by train and us. Once in the city the cafe culture is simply the best spend hours just people watching, and all the time be amazed by this city steeped in history. Travel by bus, or 45 minute walk through the paved park area that was once a river running to the harbour, and you will find a wonderful Oceanographic and cultural centre. Wonderful modern architecture. The dolphin display is simply brilliant. To visit the whole site for a family of 5 is quite expensive, and you will struggle to fit in everything in one day. Our tip on first visit go to the Oceanographic, and book on line as you can get many great deals. Check our http://www.cac.es/oceanografic/ definitely on our must do list and that of our friends of Casa Diana.

quote: Science fiction as architecture brought to earth with over-the-top drama!
reviewnospace:
My wife & I visited the City of Arts & Sciences for about 2 hours on a tour that was part of an 11-day Mediterranean cruise. Our tour guide - assisted by a Spanish-speaking architecture student - was mediocre, but the buildings & their setting were nevertheless breathtaking. This looked like science fiction as architecture brought to earth with over-the-top drama. We walked briefly through the museum, but otherwise did not go inside any of the buildings. The imagination was remarkable!

We were most fascinated by the Hemisferic, which at night is illuminated & reflected in a surrounding pool so that it looks like a giant eye - &, in fact, the "eye" has rows of windows that can open & close as though they were eye lashes!

If you appreciate modern architecture at its most provocative, the City of Arts & Sciences is a must-see, but schedule the better part of a day to do it justice.
titleopinion:
Science fiction as architecture brought to earth with over-the-top drama!. My wife & I visited the City of Arts & Sciences for about 2 hours on a tour that was part of an 11-day Mediterranean cruise. Our tour guide - assisted by a Spanish-speaking architecture student - was mediocre, but the buildings & their setting were nevertheless breathtaking. This looked like science fiction as architecture brought to earth with over-the-top drama. We walked briefly through the museum, but otherwise did not go inside any of the buildings. The imagination was remarkable!

We were most fascinated by the Hemisferic, which at night is illuminated & reflected in a surrounding pool so that it looks like a giant eye - &, in fact, the "eye" has rows of windows that can open & close as though they were eye lashes!

If you appreciate modern architecture at its most provocative, the City of Arts & Sciences is a must-see, but schedule the better part of a day to do it justice.

quote: The most unique and amazing architecture ever
reviewnospace:
This place made me feel like I have done some time travel and landed in a time ahead of us by 50 yrs... or maybe another planet in space!

The awe inspiring City of Arts and Sciences is a cultural and architectural complex designed by Santiago Calatrava and Felix Candela. Spread out over two kilometers along the bed of the former River Turia, the complex, with its striking architecture are incredible in reality, No photographs does any justice to this place.

The space like City of Arts and Sciences has a number of buildings where travellers can immerse themselves in different aspects of art, nature, science and technology. There are 5 different buildings: THE HEMISFERIC (an Imax theatre, planetarium and laserium built in the shape of an eye), THE UMBRACLE (a landscaped walkway which includes plant species indigenous to Valencia and an outdoor art gallery with sculptures from contemporary artists), THE PRINCIPE FELIPE SCIENCE MUSEUM (an interactive museum of science which looks like the skeleton of a whale), THE OCEANOGRAFIC (an open air oceanographic park - the largest aquarium in Europe with over 500 marine species) and THE PALAU DE LES ARTS REINA SOFIA (an opera house and performing arts centre).

This is a must must must visit place when in Valencia!!

quote: Interesting but it could be better
reviewnospace: As a science fanatic, I was expecting even more. On the other hand, my visit was hampered by the presence of my family and this means i had to spend only 5 or 6 hours inside. There are at least 2 dozens really fun experiences and hundreds more that are interesting. The second floor is the worse and more boring. The third floor is gigantic and alone would deserve half a day. The best age for children here is probably 11+ but younger ones still can enjoy some nice experiences if you are prepared to explain a lot of things. If you have no idea of what is going on, well, i think your 6 y.o. children will soon be bored. The price is very good and you can have customized visits: each presentation costs 2 euro more: i didn't take advantage of them but i think they should be good. Restaurant inside is quite lousy but the people are very very kind and nice. A COMPLETE disappointment was the shop inside: i was looking for something science related and interesting but the shop has almost nothing worthwhile
