quote: A very large and interesting series of exhibitions
reviewnospace:
Set inside a stunning building, the exhibitions themselves are interesting as well. Exhibitions about medical tech and the human body, with interactive elements such as balance challenges and 3D computer imaging share the floors with interesting and mind-expanding exhibits on many other subject, most of which also encourage interaction. These included exhibits on light refraction, airflow and water flow, particles, sports abilities, human (and natural) evolution, DNA, brain function, space (including specific space rides for kids) and huge models of rockets, a jet, an old Wright-style flyer, and at the time we visited a huge Marvel Superheroes display that sucked you into the world of the characters with huge art panels from the comics, and large models (some of iffy resemblance) and examined the science behind invisibility, electricity, implants etc in reference to the characters- well presented and a lot of fun.
The Indiana Jones exhibition is temporary for a few months but well worth a visit with costumes, props (Ark of the Covenant prop, Crystal Skull skeleton, Mutt's motorbike from Kingdom of the Crystal Skull, and many costumes from the films etc). It also houses a more academic exhibition on real archeological finds like the stories behind the Nazca lines and other famous digs. Be advised - photo's aren't permitted inside the Indy exhibit (although we did find a few people taking crafty snapshots anyway!).
Fascinating and worth setting aside a good 4 hours for the whole science museum.

quote: Visually extraordinary and filled with interesting exhibits
reviewnospace:
The City of the Arts and Sciences is a catch-all title for the complex that includes the science museum, the hemisferic cinema, and the oceanografic aquarium among others.
It's worth a visit just to marvel at the buildings alone, but some of them are fantastic attractions in their own right.
It sits in landscaped gardens, and is deceptively large. Tickets can be purchased to view the museum, hemisferic and oceanografic (and at the moment also the temporary Indiana Jones archeology & movie exhibition). The tickets are a touch expensive, but each attraction (with the exception of the hemisferic) is quite a time-sink and well worth the visit. The stunning Umbracle ribbed walkway filled with plants (and at night it's own chill-out bar and nightclub) is free to access in the daytime, and is gorgeous.
A must-see.

quote: An oasis in the middle of the city
reviewnospace: The name says it all - aquarium, park, IMAX theatre, sports and children's play areas, plenty of space to relax, walk, run or cycle.
titleopinion: An oasis in the middle of the city. The name says it all - aquarium, park, IMAX theatre, sports and children's play areas, plenty of space to relax, walk, run or cycle.

reviewnospace: Awe-inspiring architecture that seems to take Valencia into the 22nd-century. I remember the reaction I gave when I first approached the area - just utter awe. The futuristic architecture is quite a contrast from the City Centre and it's historical buildings; however, it was very refreshing. Not only that, but they are functional buildings. The Aquarium is NOT TO BE MISSED. I suggest planning an entire day just dedicated to this area. I spent a total of 12 hours over two-days at the City fo Arts and Sciences and still found I could have stayed longer. I implore anyone who is considering a trip to Spain to visit Valencia and the City of Arts and Sciences.

quote: Impressive and Great To Explore by Bike
reviewnospace: We rented bikes and cycled through the park from the old town. We were really happy we did, as it made it really easy to get around to different vantage points. We didn't go inside any of the buildings but spent around 2 hours around the complex and felt that was enough time.

reviewnospace:
The reviews were right, you either love or hate Valencia. The Old city is nice, but not really something anybody would compare to either Seville or Granada. Some nice churches, a couple of ancient towers, but not really something worth a mayor detour, maybe just an afternoon stroll.
The City of the Arts however, is the kind of complex people would look at, 500 years from now (if it’s still standing) and say, "wow! I cant believe they built that in those days!"
This complex is the kind of money losing enterprise that could not possibly be built today in the US. We went on a Saturday and walked everywhere with barely two to three hundred people in the entire complex, built to accommodate probably tens of thousands. The only crowd been at the Opera where the Queen of Spain was attending a performance. The beauty and ingenuity of the structures makes this a must for any architecture buff.
The exibitions are world class and anyone with children would spend an entire day here doing something where everyone in the family can learn about art, science and the world they live in.

THe dolphin show was a bit of a disappointment though.

For this reason, I would suggest not to try to do some other activity in the same day you visit the aquarium. We made the mistake of getting the tickets for the hemispherium but we had to cancel it (no refund) because we didn't have time to get there.

quote: A nice place to pass the afternoon
reviewnospace:
Went to the scientific museum the other day. Surprisingly, it was quite interactive. Had a little bit of everything...Loved the tie-in with the Marvel Comics! Considering it was so freaking hot outside, I couldn't think of a better place to be than in the museum. I especially enjoyed the Indiana Jones exhibition. To see the exhibit costs an additional fee. But considering I loved the movies, I couldn't resist. After the museum closed, the parks surrounding the museum are a must to stroll around while sipping orxata or eating gelato.

Note: If you arrive by train, you can get a 10% discount off of your museum admission if you show them your renfe ticket at the ticket office. BUT...it only works on the day you arrive. Though you can do what I did, and purchase the ticket for a future date.
titleopinion:
A nice place to pass the afternoon. Went to the scientific museum the other day. Surprisingly, it was quite interactive. Had a little bit of everything...Loved the tie-in with the Marvel Comics! Considering it was so freaking hot outside, I couldn't think of a better place to be than in the museum. I especially enjoyed the Indiana Jones exhibition. To see the exhibit costs an additional fee. But considering I loved the movies, I couldn't resist. After the museum closed, the parks surrounding the museum are a must to stroll around while sipping orxata or eating gelato.

Note: If you arrive by train, you can get a 10% discount off of your museum admission if you show them your renfe ticket at the ticket office. BUT...it only works on the day you arrive. Though you can do what I did, and purchase the ticket for a future date.

reviewnospace: Situated in the old River Turia riverbed (the river has been redirected), an amazingly architectural building. It is worth going just to see the outside of it, but inside is a great museum, with regularly changing exhibitions, many of them interactive. Our favourite was the Indiana Jones exhibition, which was wonderful. You could look at the still exhibits in just over and hour, or take part in a archeology adventure which took us the better part of 3 hours, we loved it so much we explored every bit of it. Before that, there had been a dinosaur exhibit, which my husband said was equally well done and informative. A part of this set up is the Hemispheric, another wonderfully designed building which shows great 3D movies of natural and scientific subjects. Also in the old riverbed, there are many other wonderful buildings, parks, and even a zoo, making this a great whole day out.

quote: Lots to do, see and explore.
reviewnospace:
This is a great place to amuse the kids for a few hours. We added this on to a visit to Oceanografic next door.

Strange looking but striking building on the dry Turia river bed in the city centre next to Hemisferic, Oceanografic etc.

Great displays and shows but I would advise doing your some homework before visiting. A good plan of what you want to see would be in order here. Plenty of things to broaden the mind and some really interesting exhibits.

You could nearly spend a full day on it's own here exploring. 3 floors of really interesting stuff.

Cafeteria on the ground floor for drinks and snacks is fine but we found the building overall to be very warm (all that glass probably).

Don't get too embroiled in the science here as you might lose the kids :-)

reviewnospace: This is most of all an amazing architectural theme park. Whilst other towns have commissioned one iconic new building (like Bilbao) to attract tourists, Valencia has chosen to build five. Foster, Calatrava (a native Valencian) & Co have built stunning constructions out of glass, steel and concrete which all recall to some extent organic structures. The new opera is overarched by a huge concrete leave and looks like a flower that is about to open itself, the science museum plays with the repetition of elements that could be inspired by fibres of leaves and the agora looks like the back of an exotic fish, not to forget the hemispheric, which is designed as a huge eye. All this together is a stunning view when you approach the site from the old town. As a European you are immediately proud that architecture like this is nowadays not exclusively built in Arab countries and in Shanghai. At the same time, one cannot ignore that this ultramodern complex must have cost a fortune, "un rinon" as Spaniards would say.
titleopinion: Stunning - utopian. This is most of all an amazing architectural theme park. Whilst other towns have commissioned one iconic new building (like Bilbao) to attract tourists, Valencia has chosen to build five. Foster, Calatrava (a native Valencian) & Co have built stunning constructions out of glass, steel and concrete which all recall to some extent organic structures. The new opera is overarched by a huge concrete leave and looks like a flower that is about to open itself, the science museum plays with the repetition of elements that could be inspired by fibres of leaves and the agora looks like the back of an exotic fish, not to forget the hemispheric, which is designed as a huge eye. All this together is a stunning view when you approach the site from the old town. As a European you are immediately proud that architecture like this is nowadays not exclusively built in Arab countries and in Shanghai. At the same time, one cannot ignore that this ultramodern complex must have cost a fortune, "un rinon" as Spaniards would say.

There are cycle paths that lead all the way to the beach. Enjoyed the whole experience and would re-visit again, next time to check out the inside of the ‘City’ and its' exhibits!

quote: Eye catching architecture and nice museums too
reviewnospace: We visited this 'city' for the first time last year and returned again this year just to have a walk around the park. It really is a 'city' inside a city- it is so huge! The entry fees are pricey, but it's understandable for the cost of the place and the upkeep. The science museum was slightly above average- it had some nice interactive exhibits and is decently large (3-4 hours to visit maybe?) but it's not the best I've seen. The Oceanographic was nice and the tunnel under the tank is well done. Worth a visit even if you just go to look at the outsides of the buildings.

The Oceanographic was nice and the tunnel under the tank is well done. Worth a visit even if you just go to look at the outsides of the buildings.

reviewnospace:
Santiago Calatrava is an architect from Valencia who designed the City of Arts and Sciences in a very modern design. All the buildings are modern and white. Since we had previously visited the site a few years ago, we decided to spend time at the Oceanografic. This is one of the biggest aquariums in Europe and one of the best in the world. There are many buildings that are set in a huge garden and one goes from one exhibit to another. Many have underground connections between them.

This great aquarium has exhibits that come from all over the world and represent the major oceans and seas. The best are the aquariums showing tropical fish and the ones showing the fish of the Mediterranean. There is a building that is an aviary and one can see many different birds that are colorful there. There are tropical fish, penguins, belugas, sharks, jellyfish, and hundreds of different fish. The exhibits are very well explained in both Spanish and English.

We also went to see the Umbracle where there was a show of dinosaurs that were motorized, so they moved slowly. The Umbracle is a garden on top of the parking garage and there is plenty of modern sculpture beside it.
We also went to take photos at the Hemisferic and the Prince Felipe Science Museum. These are set amid artificial lakes and one can take beautiful photos there.
titleopinion:

This great aquarium has exhibits that come from all over the world and represent the major oceans and seas. We also went to take photos at the Hemisferic and the Prince Felipe Science Museum. These are set amid artificial lakes and one can take beautiful photos there.

reviewnospace: Of course you can visit all the different sections of this centre but you could just admire it from the outside if you are short of time. The architecture is so amazing and is worth a visit just to wonder around and relax. To enter you can buy a ticket for all the parts of the City of Arts and Sciences which is certainly worthwhile doing as you get a good discount. Science centre, slightly disappointing; Hemispheric can be good if you choose the right film for watching on the big screen; Oceanografic, good but not amazing. The reason why I rated it as excellent is really for the whole experience of going around all these attractions in the beautiful surroundings which are a work of state of the art.

reviewnospace: no wonder the iconic arts and sciences buildings in Valencia are so widely used for production photoshoots. Almost everytime I visit and stroll around the gardens, there´s bikini clad girls perched on the latest car model or toe dipping in the shallows of the great pond with the impressive "eye" as a back drop. Great places to wonder about, although thats all you can really do. There is usually a free art exhibition along the prominade which is always worth a stroll through. Some very famous sculptures have showcased their "Bronze Bull" here and some funky cartoon-like sculptures based on Pealla themes. Students love this place which is why I guess you see coach loads of them. But the space is so large and spread out over about 2 miles that you can take a multitude of shots without having to "tut" because someone has walked into frame. The water, iconic architechure, blue sky above and distant light in the city truely made the arts and sciences something to experience in real like, and not just from a magazine cover.

reviewnospace:
I have been in this place in summer. i have to say that the location is amazing. it looks to be in a science movie and be in the future. the buildings are withe with a futuristic look. there is a huge pool between the buildings and it is very nice walk in this area. there is an amazing view from the Calatrava bridge that across the area and divides the science area from the aquarium one. the ticket for both the attractions (museum and aquarium) is expensive..I think that, for a family, is probably too expensive..
the science museum is funny even if when I was there was too crowded. the aquarium is ok, I honestly did expect something more but the glass corridor surrounded by the water with sharks inside is amazing and gives the reason to go to visit it. in general I think that if you go in Valencia you have to visit this area.
titleopinion:
nice to go with kids. the science museum is funny even if when I was there was too crowded. the aquarium is ok, I honestly did expect something more but the glass corridor surrounded by the water with sharks inside is amazing and gives the reason to go to visit it. in general I think that if you go in Valencia you have to visit this area.

reviewnospace: As a Valenciana I am proud of many things in my city, but architect's Calatrava's CAC is a special one and a Must in Valencia! it make me dream as a child... it was the most modern and beautiful thing I ever saw (and still mesmerizes me and I live in Dubai!)... I like the Hemisferic (Imax Cinema), the Umbracle is delightful), the surrounds are amazing, the Opera house is incredible... but the Science Museums is WONDERFUL! go there even if you are not a child, you will enjoy all the experiments you can do there!
titleopinion: Another Must; CAC. As a Valenciana I am proud of many things in my city, but architect's Calatrava's CAC is a special one and a Must in Valencia! it make me dream as a child... it was the most modern and beautiful thing I ever saw (and still mesmerizes me and I live in Dubai!)... I like the Hemisferic (Imax Cinema), the Umbracle is delightful), the surrounds are amazing, the Opera house is incredible... but the Science Museums is WONDERFUL! go there even if you are not a child, you will enjoy all the experiments you can do there!

quote: Dn't try and see the Oceanografic on the same day
reviewnospace: Our visit to the City of Arts & Sciences was squeezed into the end of a tiring day which we had spent exploring the extraordinary Oceanografic across the road. This was not a good idea as we were too tired to see everything. I managed a coupe of floors of the Science Musem but then had to give up. This was a shame as so many of the exhibits were interactive and great fun to play with. Kids would love this museum. Take two days to see this complex and the Oceanografic, as there is so much to see.

quote: The most beautiful part of Valencia - a must!
reviewnospace: When I first saw the pictures of City of the Arts and Sciences, my first reaction was : it's not possible, this is not in Valencia! In fact, it is and it's very impressive: all the building are very original, they reflect into the surrounding lakes. It's like travelling in the future. Also, the Christmas tree is very nice and it also reflects in the water. If you have only one day in Valencia, you should go to the City of the Arts and Sciences!
titleopinion: The most beautiful part of Valencia - a must!. When I first saw the pictures of City of the Arts and Sciences, my first reaction was : it's not possible, this is not in Valencia! In fact, it is and it's very impressive: all the building are very original, they reflect into the surrounding lakes. It's like travelling in the future. Also, the Christmas tree is very nice and it also reflects in the water. If you have only one day in Valencia, you should go to the City of the Arts and Sciences!

reviewnospace:
This area is a must visit if you are an architecture buff like me. The different buildings inside are simply spectacular. I especially loved the Palace of Arts and the Agora. They made splendid photographs.

The Palace of Arts is generally not visitable but the Prince Felipe Science Museum, the Oceanografic and the Hemisferic are definitely worth a visit.

The museum is a fun way of looking at many scientific achievements over the last century and the hemisferic has an imax theater with many different shows. The Oceanografic is largest Marine Life park in Europe.
titleopinion:
A must visit.... This area is a must visit if you are an architecture buff like me. The different buildings inside are simply spectacular. I especially loved the Palace of Arts and the Agora. They made splendid photographs.

The Palace of Arts is generally not visitable but the Prince Felipe Science Museum, the Oceanografic and the Hemisferic are definitely worth a visit.

The museum is a fun way of looking at many scientific achievements over the last century and the hemisferic has an imax theater with many different shows. The Oceanografic is largest Marine Life park in Europe.

reviewnospace: We didn't go to the City of Arts & Sciences for some specific venue or event: we just went to look at it. We found the architecture cold, uninviting and antiseptic. It's comes across as trying too hard. It is grand, however, and photographs well - hence two points instead of one. Of course, if you're a fan of Calatrava, the architect, the place is a must.

It's comes across as trying too hard. It is grand, however, and photographs well - hence two points instead of one. Of course, if you're a fan of Calatrava, the architect, the place is a must.

reviewnospace: Would give 5 stars, but for the walk the night before. Walked around the whole complex and couldn't help but wonder what this will be like in 20 or 30 years; some signs of decay already showing and this felt like a giant playground for an architect ...

quote: Architecturally unique and amazing place--well worth the trip
reviewnospace:
I went to Valencia specifically to visit this architectural wonder park, based on friends' reviews. The views, buildings, and entire area/events around them are stunning (there was a free fair going on under the spectacular bridge while I was visiting).

I would recommend two days to see everything at a comfortable pace. The exhibits and shows are OK (just don't expect the high entertainment value and organisational standards of U.S. theme parks). Tickets are pricey, however, you have the option to enjoy external access to most areas for free (unlike U.S. Theme Parks). Those on a limited budget might want to only pay to enter L'Oceanogràfic (the aquarium complex), as it is by far the best exhibit.
titleopinion:

quote: Use their Boris bikes- a lovely day out
reviewnospace: How amazing that the government of Valencia chose to turn the dried out river into a massive long park instead of a motorway. We picked up bikes from one of the many bike stands in the old town- its really easy to set up and good value. Took us about five minutes to sort and then we were off. We cycle all the way down to the beach (the final bit is not in the park but the cycle paths are fairly good). My partner loves architecture and there is a lot to see in the park. There are plenty of cafes etc for refreshments and its a lovely day out. The buildings are amazing. Its like being in some sort of sci fi film. We didn't go in any but really enjoyed cycling around them. Strongly recommend this as a day out.

We didn't go in any but really enjoyed cycling around them. Strongly recommend this as a day out.

reviewnospace: We went to the city of arts and sciences thinking that we'd only be here for a few hours but we ended up staying the whole day! We got the combined ticket for oceanographic, hemisphere and the science museum. Out of the three, the one we didn't really like was the science museum which seemed boring after the aquarium and the IMAX theatre. We saw Hubble which was recommended by the information lady and we did enjoy it. The aquarium was by far the best part of the day - the shark area was scary!! Highly recommended, as there is something for everyone!

quote: A modern architectural piece of art
reviewnospace:
Its a huge area where you can find a lot to do - be it art, science, flora & fauna etc. or just having a good time with friends/family.
We saw a dolphin show, which was good, went to IMAX show, different animals from different climatic conditions were there in their artificial home environments- including sharks, penguins, seals, tropical birds, colourful fishes, etc.
There is a science museum as well, but we could not visit that because of lack of time.
The whole architecture is awesome and is spread across 1-1.5 kms. long stretch.
It is a whole day attraction where you can spend as much time as you want, but a minimum of 3 hours is required.
I would recommend it to visit in Valencia.

reviewnospace: This is a mind blowing sight. Even the road bridge is beautifully designed. Then there are the beautiful lakes of light blue water linking all the different buildings. On the far side are the Turia Gardens which are pleasant to walk in during the day. There is a "train" to take you around but it is very easy to walk around. I spent an hour just sitting at an outside cafe watching the sunset and the lights coming on. Its free to walk round the ground floor of the Science Museum so you can have a look at the inside too.

reviewnospace:
Santiago Calatrava knows how to make wonderful architecture. The Hemisferic, Science Museum of Prince Felipe, the Agora and the Umbracle, with white buildings in a park like setting with the reflecting pools around the buildings are made to take photos, beautiful photos. This is modern architecture at its best!

The Hemisferic has beautiful Imax movies. The Science Museum has great science exhibits that educate and at the same time entertain, both for children and adults. The Umbracle has a tropical garden on top of the parking garage. There are modern and colorful sculptures along one of its edges.

This is really a place to be entertained.

quote: Fantastic Architecture -- Slightly dissapointing Value for Content
reviewnospace:
I visited this with a combo ticket including the adjacent marine park and came away satisfied -- but not absolutely blown away.

A very good effort is made to communicate scientific knowledge in all major fields (i.e., using Marvel comic heros and Spanish Futbol).

I did feel, however, that the City fathers wanted an architectural monument to "band" Valencia with an internationally-recognized iconic image---and this they certainly have.

The use of all the airy, large air volumes under the roofs, however, seemed wasted to me. This may bode well for the future, however, as they have a lot of square meters for new science exhibits and attractions in the future (like maybe they can add a small Imax or at least a planetarium show ???

One major fault is that there are not bathrooms on all levels....I found this out when needing one on the first floor--and had to run up to the 3rd level; something that might force accidents with smaller children !
titleopinion:

quote: Spectacular ....but. Also watch out for bag snatchers in the park
reviewnospace:
The buildings are a must see - an easy trip on the bus from Xativa. An absolute forture has been spent here and it shows. Fantastic vistas in each direction.
The content did not live to the outward appearance . Please see my review on the Principe Felipe review page (the centre forms part of this complex).

Be aware, one of our group had her bag snatched in the gardens (there seem to be a lot of rough sleepers in the bushes) - I guess it can happen anywhere, so lock anything of value in the hotel safe before you go out.

reviewnospace:
A truly mind-blowing confection of some of Europe's most awesome architecture, the City of Arts and Science in Valencia,It's an amazing sight to visit, if you don't get in it's free, but to get into the buildings you gotta pay.

Santiago Calatrava, who master-minded most of the complex, says 'I am proud of the fact that people can walk through and around the main buildings without paying. It is a city to be discovered by promenading.
titleopinion:
AMAZING. A truly mind-blowing confection of some of Europe's most awesome architecture, the City of Arts and Science in Valencia,It's an amazing sight to visit, if you don't get in it's free, but to get into the buildings you gotta pay.

Santiago Calatrava, who master-minded most of the complex, says 'I am proud of the fact that people can walk through and around the main buildings without paying. It is a city to be discovered by promenading.

reviewnospace:
The buildings and the water features are wonderful but the Science exhibition did not live up to our expectations. Some of the exhibits did not seem to work . Be warned we went to the Electricity presentation and it was only in Spanish , its difficult to follow if you do not speak Spanish.
The staff were friendly and helpful.
My reccommendation is, if you have school aged children then this would be great for them.
Wear comfortable shoes and dont forget your camera.!
titleopinion:

reviewnospace: It was verry nice to walk here and see this buildings.
titleopinion: A verry nice expirience. It was verry nice to walk here and see this buildings.

reviewnospace:
I went there because I love architecture, and Santiago Calatrava has been always one of my favorite architects, the complex is inside the old turia river channel, now the gardens of the turia, which is a long central park in Valencia full of trees and grass everywhere, so it’s a very nice location.
the buildings are amazing and very clean, I know they might have some architectural errors but still I appreciate very much Calatrava's work here, especially in the Palau de les arts, seeing it in real life is so different than seeing it in pictures, it's magnificent and huge!

I truly recommend visiting this complex if you are in Valencia, it is worth the time spent in it, and if you are not the type of person who enjoys analyzing architecture, you can still take some quite impressive pictures to show off among your friends.

quote: It seems like you have traveled to a futuristic time zone.
reviewnospace:
The amazing complex of buildings designed by leading architects including Salvador Calatrava is a step into the future. I visited the opera house to hear a performance and strolled the grounds to see some of the interesting landscape designs. The opera house contained a blend of traditional motifs such as a liberal use of mosaics with dramatic new innovative ones. The acoustics were excellent and the performance of Fidelio was world class.
Other buildings contain activities for the whole family including an Aquarium, one of Europe's largest and a biosphere where life on earth can be studied.
The City of Arts and Science is making Valencia a must see place on any itinerary of Spain

reviewnospace: The City of Arts and Sciences is quite simply breathtaking. Although we did not visit all the museum just the outside is impressive. We did go the Oceanografic park and there is a dinosaur park too but we ran out of time. A visit is a must...!!
titleopinion: Unbelievable...!!!. The City of Arts and Sciences is quite simply breathtaking. Although we did not visit all the museum just the outside is impressive. We did go the Oceanografic park and there is a dinosaur park too but we ran out of time. A visit is a must...!!

reviewnospace: This was the most boring place I have ever been. It was expensive to enter and none of the exhibits had any wow factor. My advice would be to just walk around the outside and then go relax on the beach instead or explore the downtown.
titleopinion: A Major Let Down. This was the most boring place I have ever been. It was expensive to enter and none of the exhibits had any wow factor. My advice would be to just walk around the outside and then go relax on the beach instead or explore the downtown.

reviewnospace:
A must-see attraction in Valencia. We visited the Oceanographic and the Science Park. The oceanographic also includes dolphin shows, the aquarium and other marine animals.

The Science Park is very interactive and allows science to be approached in a different perspective. I am not a very science person myself and really enjoyed the visit.

Attractions are open by day, but I also recommend an evening trip to the area. The illuminated attractions are fantastic. You cannot miss a sight of Valencia's landmark area!

Very recommended!

reviewnospace:
Our trip was for 2 days. 1st day in Valencia and 2nd day in Buñol for La Tomatina. Since we didnt had lot of time in Valencia, we were looking for just one or two places to visit easily rather than choosing many places and running from one to another. So we chosed the City of the Arts and Sciences and it was a good option. Try to reserve one whole day for the city and do it easily..

There is a Hemispheric where u can enjoy informative 3D shows, many topics. There is a Science Museum, mainly for school going students and ofcourse for people who are not in science field. You have an Oceanographic part with large aquarriums, polar animals, and a very attractive dolphin show. There is a Dinosaur park, again informative one. They did small animations with Dinosaur dummies. There are restaurants and bars in the city. You can do small shoping as well. The architecture of the whole city is really attractive. I paid a total of 32 euros as ticket for everything inside, it really worths. You can also take separate tickets for single attractions.

I strongly recmment the 15 minute video in the oceanograhic part which explains how they take care of the fishes and aquatic animals, birds etc.

¡Buen viaje,
Ameen.

quote: Go and you will not be disappointed
reviewnospace: Amazing architecture. No wonder Spain is almost bankrupt. These buildings rival any Arts and Science centre you would see in other parts of the world. You can spend 1/2 day there without any problems. Beautifully airconditoned for the summer months and child friendly. The pools are amazing although no swimming is allowed. It is a credit to Valencia to have this structure in their city. They completely changed the water table and moved the river away from the Arts and Science buildings.

reviewnospace:
What to say, you need to visit it, like you are in another world. Science museum is must to visit it because it is very interactive and educational. Like shadow room, gravitation zero, thunder room and many other interesting things not only for adults but for kids also. Museum was packed in August with tourists.

Hemispheric is IMAX cinema and planetarium also.

Bridge is looking faboulous and there are still Agora, Oceanografic and I cant remember the name of first building.

reviewnospace: This is like an educational city within a city. The buildings alone are worth just sightseeing. They are gorgeous! And there's so much to do also. From the museum of science, to the largest aquarium in Europe, to the IMAX to do something during the summer to stay cool ;)
titleopinion: Truly Spectacular!. This is like an educational city within a city. The buildings alone are worth just sightseeing. They are gorgeous! And there's so much to do also. From the museum of science, to the largest aquarium in Europe, to the IMAX to do something during the summer to stay cool ;)

reviewnospace: Take the Valencia metro to Alameda station and walk the old river bed through parks, gardens, fountains, enjoying a green oasis in the middle of a bustling city. Approaching the Ciudad feels like you are entering another world. It is truly spectacular a testament to what good modern architecture can produce. We travelled with 2 teenage boys who went to the aquarium and were very impressed. We were content to stroll around taking the whole place in. I had read reviews about how expensive it is but we ate very reasonably in a large shopping centre just across the road. Sales were on as well so we got shops as well as culture! One tip, try to stay on till dusk when the lights come on and the overall impression is even more spectacular. Amazing place, has to be seen.

quote: Amazing place and definitely worth a visit!
reviewnospace:
This must be one of the most beautiful modern places in Europe. Set on a grand scale, it requires a lot of walking but is worth the effort. It includes a massive ocean park with dolphin show, a science museum great for the kids, a super IMAX movie theatre, and an exhibition centre that changes about every 6 months. The ground surrounding it are beautiful as well and perfect for a bike ride or picnic. It is full of locals exercising or just lounging around.

We have been on several occasions. This time we saw "3D Flying Monsters" in the IMAX and it was fantastic. The exhibition was Dinosaurs and dissappointing - maybe better for very young children who are really into dinosaurs.

This is definitely not to be missed during a visit to Spain and even worthy of a special trip! Its just 10 minutes (maybe less) to the city centre, so easy to tie in.

reviewnospace: Over all the City of Arts and Sciences was a gear experience. Yes, the entry fee to the Oceanografic isn't cheap but we thought it was a great attraction - well maintained, clean and with an amazing range of creatures. I notice some reviewers found it disappointing but I guess it depends what you're comparing it with. The Science Museum was interesting although perhaps there could have been more translation into English but the building is fantastic and the views are amazing. Over all this area of the city is a fascinating asset to Valencia.

The Science Museum was interesting although perhaps there could have been more translation into English but the building is fantastic and the views are amazing. reviewnospace: A spectacular building dedicated to promoting the performing arts.It is an impressive example of modern architecture. The best relaxing place to walk day or night. VIVA Santiago Calatrava.
titleopinion: amazing architecture!!!. A spectacular building dedicated to promoting the performing arts.It is an impressive example of modern architecture. The best relaxing place to walk day or night. VIVA Santiago Calatrava.

reviewnospace:
I have just been to Valencia to see Puccini´s La Tosca at the Palau de les Artes, it was fabulous! The Opera was our first so I have no real points of reference, but it surpassed all expectations. Maybe the Main Auditorium was a little modern for my liking, but it was accoustically perfect and the opera wonderful! The Arquetecture was stunning and a real adventure to look around.

The second day we went to the visit the Oceanographic part of the park and what a day! Completely exceeded all expectations again. The staff were so helpful, friendly and approachable and we ended up spending the whole day there, 2 hours of which were spent watching the Dolfins and learning about them with the educational "chat" they hold about the animals. We didnt eat there, however there seemed to be a lot of choice.

My one suggestion would be to ask about any shows as you go in and pay attention to anything that might be closed. We didnt realize about the Dolfin shows which are twice a day and missed the 1st one at 12 but were lucky enough to catch the second one at 16.30. The Red Sea area was closed when we went also. The tunnels are fantastic and the information abundant, a real education and fun alike for adults or children (we had no children, just us!) Wear comfy shoes and sun cream if its warm as there is a lot outside. You can go into the bird enclosure as well which is not obvious at first but great fun!! Taxi rank is outside and taxi to train station only €8.00 afterwards. Fabulous day!

reviewnospace:
Unfortunately, we didn't have enough time to visit the interior of those grand, unusual buildings, but we enjoyed a stroll just around the pools surrounding the whole area.

We had seen pictures of the City of the Arts and Sciences before going to Valencia, but when you get there and see them in person...well...it's really astonishing!
I'm not able to say whether the museums and aquarium are worth a visit, but I can definitely recommend not to miss this Valencian landmark. Don't forget to bring your camera!

As we only visited the external spaces, it took us one hour or less, but if you visit the interiors, I guess they would need one half day or more.

I'm marking "free" as for "Is this attraction free or not?", but that's just because walking around is allowed without paying. Of course, to visit the museums and aquarium you have to pay (I think it's possible to choose single or integrated tickets depending on what you'd like to visit).

quote: World-class Architecture, and rather elementary exhibits.
reviewnospace:
This is one of the World's most fantastic new cluster of buildings, with soaring, ambitious architecture, but the contents are not worth such an unworldly buildings. The contents seem to be designed for school-level children, whereas I had expected it to house the proud achievements of a justifiably proud people.

The Oceanográfico (the largest aquarium in Europe with over 500 marine species) is very well-designed, but contains very common fishes.

The Hemisfèric (IMAX cinema and digital projections) was excellent but had a waiting spaces which was boiling hot with no ventilation.

I could not see the Umbracle (a landscaped vantage point and car park), as I walked to the museum from my nearby hotel.

The Príncipe Felipe Science Museum (an innovative centre of interactive science), is also a disappointment, as its contents are just a tad better than a college science exhibition.

I could not enter the Palau de les Arts Reina Sofía, nor the Ágora, which is said to "give the complex a multifunctional space".

The washrooms were quite pathetic throughout.
